Cream: Vietnamese coffee, salted caramel, pumpkin pie, coconut lemongrass, chocolate cardamom cinnamon, chocolate sea salt, saffron rosewater, and pistachio honey.

I love pistachio, so I tried the pistachio honey.  It was all-natural tasting and not overly sweet like most popsicles are.  Overall, Meltdown is a great little establishment near the French Market and is perfect for cooling off during all the hot New Orleans days.  Healthy too.

Chef's Table Catering of Philadelphia catered my friend's wedding ceremony cocktail hour and dinner reception. It was a vegetarian buffet, a first for me at a wedding reception (and I've been to a lot). I'm not a big fan of vegetarian food (as a meal), so I think it's pretty impressive that Chef's Table was able to cater a spread of vegetarian food that I thought was quite good. Some items, in particular, were fantastic.

The cocktail hour took place at the ceremony site, Chinese Christian Church and Center in Chinatown North/Callowhill (Vine Campus) (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinese-christian-church-and-center-philadelphia). Chef's Table set up a bar with two bartenders and a small self-serve buffet of hors d'oeuvres just inside the entrance of the sanctuary.

Cocktail hour menu:
* Antipasto tray - soppressata, pepperoni, sharp Provolone, Italian Fontina, grilled artichoke hearts, marinated olives, button mushrooms, and artichoke hearts
* Crudite tray - assorted raw and blanched vegetables
* Mezza tray - stuffed grape leaves and green olives with lemon and coriander, hummus, baba ghanoush, muhammara

I thought the spread of hors d'oeuvres was great. The foods were very fresh and healthy. I like eating raw veggies and appreciated the variety that included not only standard veggies like broccoli and grape tomatoes, but also endives and beets. The stuffed grape leaves were scrumptious, but the star of the show was the muhammara. Muhammara is a Middle Eastern red pepper and walnut spread. Chef's Table's version was delicious, full of flavor, with an appetizing, almost creamy, consistency.

The dinner reception took place down the street at the Asian Arts Initiative (https://www.yelp.com/biz/asian-arts-initiative-philadelphia). Chef's Table once again had a two-man bar plus four self-serve dinner stations set up and spread out along the perimeter of the venue.

Dinner reception menu:

Pasta station
* Roasted stone fruit salad - arugula and mixed greens, mango vinaigrette
* Rigatoni with fresh pomodoro sauce - balsamic caramelized onions
* Penne primavera - garlic and olive oil with garden vegetables

Jackfruit "crab" cake station
* Sauteed spinach
* Pakora potato cake - peas and cauliflower

Middle East station
* Moroccan braised seitan - tomatoes, zucchini, yellow squash, peppers, onions, golden raisins, and chickpeas over jasmine rice
* Cajun-spiced butternut squash - tomato caper

Dessert station
* Almond pistachio baklava
* Fruit tarts
* Cardamom apple crumb cakes

Bar menu
* Beer - Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA, Leinenkugel's Summer Shandy, Yuengling, Corona, Shock Top
* Wine - Pinot Noir, red blend, Malbec, Pinot Grigio, Riesling, Sauvignon Blanc, rose
* Spirits - rum, vodka, whiskey, gin, tequila
* "First Sunset" cocktail - orange juice, rum, grenadine, lime slice

Drink station
* Fresh coffee
* Decaf coffee
* Half and half, almond milk
* Hot water - assorted teas

My favorite dish, without a doubt, was the roasted stone fruit salad. I got that dish three times because the peaches were ripe and incredibly juicy and sweet. So good. I also like arugula and greens, so it was a nice combination. The most memorable dish to me was the jackfruit "crab" cake. I'm allergic to crab, so I enjoyed being able to eat this version of "crab" cake. The use of ingredients like jackfruit and offering menu items like muhammara, Moroccan braised seitan, and baklava really showed off the breadth of Chef's Table's offerings. I thought the bride did a wonderful job choosing a menu that was diverse and showed off a number of cuisines from around the world. My second favorite dish was the collection of desserts, all three. They were terrific, high quality. Everything was presented nicely. Overall, I found the dinner menu to be creative, unique, and tasty.

The two bartenders were polite and friendly. As an out-of-town guest, they definitely didn't seem like the stereotypical Philadelphians to me. They were warm and hospitable, both at cocktail hour and at the reception. That kind of hospitality makes a big difference to me. They made Chef's Table look good.

Dilworth Park is located next to Philadelphia City Hall (https://www.yelp.com/biz/city-hall-philadelphia). One could consider it a part of City Hall as the park sits in the same block as the building and acts sort of like a courtyard or open/green space for the building. It's nice. One of our Philly friends proposed this park as a meeting place for us and it was perfect for that.

The park opened in 2014 so it's relatively new. You can tell by the park's modern and aesthetically pleasing design. Most notable to me were the two contemporary glass canopies that served as long ramp entrances/exits to the underground rail system (SEPTA City Hall Station). The park has a cafe, free Wi-Fi, a splash pad, a lawn, and plenty of seating with nicely-manicured trees and landscaping around the perimeter. The splash pad is huge and one of the biggest I've seen. There's a splash pad at adjacent Love Park too (https://www.yelp.com/biz/love-park-philadelphia). In the wintertime, Dilworth's splash pad is covered with an ice skating rink.

We visited on a Sunday evening around 7:30pm and the park was busy. Lots of kids playing in the fountain, lots of folks sitting and hanging out, and lots of pedestrians passing through. We sat in an elevated gravel area with tables and comfortable chairs, shaded by umbrellas and trees. This was a great place for waiting, meeting, and people watching. We strolled through the park before and after. The park is open and spacious. The crowd was diverse. The atmosphere was relaxed. It generally felt clean and safe.

Overall, this is definitely a neat park that one typically wouldn't associate with Philly, but times are changing.

For its historical significance, Independence Hall gets five out of five stars from me. This is the birthplace of America. Both the Declaration of Independence (1776) and the Constitution (1787) were signed here. You can see the room where the documents were signed, an original draft of the Constitution, and even the inkstand used to sign the Declaration of Independence.

Admission is free. Admission is also free to the adjacent Liberty Bell Center (https://www.yelp.com/biz/liberty-bell-center-philadelphia-2). I recommend going to both back-to-back. While the Liberty Bell Center is open on a first-come, first-served basis, admission to Independence Hall is ticketed during most times of the year. Both buildings are run by the National Park Service. Rangers serve as guides and staff. You have to be screened at a security checkpoint in order to enter either building.

Tickets to Independence Hall can be obtained for free at the Independence Visitor Center located about a couple blocks north at the corner of 6th and Market Streets. Same-day ticket distribution begins at 8:30am daily on a first-come, first-served basis. You can also reserve tickets in advance for $1 per ticket (nonrefundable). Check the National Park Service's website for details: https://www.nps.gov/inde/planyourvisit/independencehall.htm.

The tickets are for tours. The first ticketed tour begins at 9am and tours start every 20 minutes until 4:40pm (last ticketed tour of the day). During extended hours (summertime only), no ticket is required from 5-7pm. Tickets also aren't required in the months of January and February and on July 4th, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Eve. The hall is closed on Christmas Day.

Most importantly, Rocky Balboa jumped a park bench outside the south facade in Rocky II (1979). There was even a documentary about it and Rocky filming locations in Philadelphia, released in 2008. It's called Rocky Jumped a Park Bench (2008): https://youtu.be/ryGnmGKbRFo.

I like Benjamin Franklin Parkway. If you've never been to Philadelphia before, I think it's a must-see. If you have time and weather permits, I recommend walking the parkway in its entirety. It's only about a mile long. Its two end points are major attractions: City Hall (technically, John F. Kennedy Plaza or Love Park: https://www.yelp.com/biz/love-park-philadelphia) and the Philadelphia Museum of Art (https://www.yelp.com/biz/philadelphia-museum-of-art-philadelphia).

The Parkway is wide and scenic. It was modeled after the Champs-Elysees in Paris. Unlike the Champs-Elysees, however, Benjamin Franklin Parkway isn't lined with as many buildings, but instead more trees. Many parks and fountains are situated on the Parkway's path, from Love Park to Eakins Oval. Along with parks and fountains, there are several museums and other sights and attractions along the Parkway. They include the Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul, Logan Circle (a.k.a. Logan Square), the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University, the Franklin Institute, and the Rodin Museum. The latter is home to a historic statue, The Thinker. This part of town is officially known as the Parkway Museums District.

If you're sightseeing in Philly for the first time, I suggest starting at City Hall (https://www.yelp.com/biz/city-hall-philadelphia). The midpoint of the Parkway is the aforementioned Logan Circle (https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-circle-philadelphia-2), home of the beautiful Swann Memorial Fountain (https://www.yelp.com/biz/swann-memorial-fountain-philadelphia-2). The stretch of parkway between Logan Circle and the Philadelphia Museum of Art is lined with flags of countries from all over the world. Not every country is represented. According to the city's Parkway Council Foundation, the flags represented are those "with significant populations in Philadelphia" (http://www.parkwaymuseumsdistrictphiladelphia.org/About-the-Parkway/FAQs/25/#q5).

Growing up, I was first introduced to Benjamin Franklin Parkway, unknowingly, through the Rocky movies. Rocky II (1979) in particular highlights the Parkway with Sylvester Stallone running with a bunch of kids around Swann Memorial Fountain (Logan Circle) and then up the Parkway, past The Thinker (Rodin Museum) and Washington Monument (Eakins Oval), and up the famous art museum steps: https://youtu.be/ABg0c_E7OOI?t=282. Fittingly, the steps are known as the Rocky Steps: https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia. These steps are probably the highlight of the Parkway for me. There's a great view of the parkway, fountains, and city from the top.

If you're into history, Elfreth's Alley is a cool spot in Philly that's worth checking out. It's a pedestrian-only alleyway lined with colonial-era homes; 32 to be exact. Walking on the short street is like taking a trip back in time. The alley is located on the east side of Center City, near the Ben Franklin Bridge, Delaware River, and Pennsylvania-New Jersey border. It's a National Historic Landmark.

We visited around 5pm on a Sunday and the alley wasn't crowded at all. At times, my fiancee and I were the only ones there. Somewhat to my surprise, our Lyft driver, who has lived in Philly for a number of years, had never heard of Elfreth's Alley before. It's a cobblestone street, originally designed to be a cart path to the river. The multistory brick homes are quaint and well-maintained. The homes were originally occupied by shopkeepers and merchants who operated businesses out of their homes.

According to a plaque posted in the alley, the alley dates back to 1736. The Elfreth's Alley Association describes this as the nation's oldest residential street even though New York's Huguenot Street was settled in the 1600s and has been continuously inhabited.

Two of the 32 homes are used today as a museum and gift shop. The museum is furnished as it would have been in 1760. At the time of writing this review, the museum is open April-October, Friday-Sunday, 12pm-5pm. Admission is cheap: only $3 per adult, $2 per child aged 5-12, and free for children under 5. However, walking the alley is completely free and it's "open" 24/7. The other 29 homes are private residences that are still in use today.

In December 2018, Curbed reported that an end unit was for sale and the asking price was $925,000 (https://philly.curbed.com/2018/12/10/18134400/elfreths-alley-philly-home-house-historic-sale-1700s). In February 2019, Philadelphia Magazine reported on the same house at 139 Elfreth's Alley. The magazine said, "Recent sales on this block have run in the $600,000-$800,000 range." (https://www.phillymag.com/property/2019/02/19/house-for-sale-elfreths-alley-oldest-house/)

Be sure to check out Bladen's Court, a whimsical and charming tree-lined alley within an alley. It dead-ends into a quiet courtyard. Bladen's Court originated between 1749 and 1752. It's named after William Bladen, a biscuit-maker, who owned the property in the early 1800s. Elfreth's Alley is named after Jeremiah Elfreth, a blacksmith, silversmith, land speculator, developer, and property owner.

Elfreth's Alley is conveniently located within walking distance to many of Philly's major historic sites including the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall (5-6 blocks away), the Benjamin Franklin Museum and Christ Church Burial Ground where Ben Franklin is buried (4 blocks away), the United States Mint (3 blocks away), and the Betsy Ross House, birthplace of the first American flag (1 block away).

My fiancee and I both made our first visits to Philadelphia recently to attend our friends' weddings. Our friends coincidentally got married less than a couple months apart, so we made two separate trips here in a short time span. We came away from Philly with a different impression of the city than before we visited. The people were nicer, the city was cleaner, and there was more to see and do than either of us expected.

Before we visited Philly, multiple people gave us negative or "meh" opinions of the place. It's dirty. There's not much to see. Some went as far to say it's a s***hole (even from someone who used to live here). Also, as a sports fan, I know Philly fans have a reputation as being some of the rudest and most obnoxious fans around. We didn't attend any sporting events, but the locals we interacted with at the hotels we stayed at, the restaurants we dined at, the rideshares we rode in, and the venues we visited were mostly kind and friendly, sometimes exceptionally so. This was the case both in the city and out in the suburbs (Plymouth Meeting). We did run into a couple bad apples (cashier at Tea Do in Chinatown and one Lyft driver), but they were the exception, not the rule.

As far as stuff to see and do, there was plenty. Philly is like a mini New York or a mini Manhattan. Here, I'll count down my top 10 highlights/favorite things we did in Philly. Our friends, who are locals, as well as wedding guests we met, who are also locals, and another friend of mine, who used to be a local Yelp Elite, recommended most of these spots to us. Great recommendations.

10. Visit the Asian Arts Initiative in Chinatown North.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/asian-arts-initiative-philadelphia

9. Eat kati rolls at Masala Kitchen Kati Rolls and Platters.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/masala-kitchen-kati-rolls-and-platters-philadelphia

8. Brunch at Sabrina's Cafe.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/sabrinas-café-philadelphia-40

7. See Elfreth's Alley.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/elfreths-alley-philadelphia

6. Eat a Philly cheesesteak at Jim's Steaks South Street.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/jims-steaks-south-street-philadelphia

5. Visit the Liberty Bell Center, Independence Hall, and Benjamin Franklin's Grave.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/liberty-bell-center-philadelphia-2
https://www.yelp.com/biz/independence-hall-philadelphia
https://www.yelp.com/biz/benjamin-franklins-grave-philadelphia

4. Eat Israeli food at Dizengoff.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/dizengoff-philadelphia

3. Check out Reading Terminal Market.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/reading-terminal-market-philadelphia

2. Visit the Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/morris-arboretum-philadelphia

1. Walk the Benjamin Franklin Parkway and visit the Philadelphia Museum of Art to see the Rocky Statue and run up the famous Rocky Steps.
https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia
https://www.yelp.com/biz/philadelphia-museum-of-art-philadelphia
https://www.yelp.com/biz/the-rocky-statue-philadelphia
https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia

The city is very walkable and Lyft/Uber rides aren't expensive either. In general, I found prices to be quite reasonable in Philly, from our lodging to  the food. As the birthplace of America, it's chock-full of history. If you've never visited Philly because you had the same impressions I described in the first two paragraphs above, you should reconsider. You might be surprised.

Oh, and for my No. 1 entry above, what can I say? I'm a huge Rocky fan. :)

The Philadelphia Museum of Art is one of the biggest attractions in Philadelphia. At a minimum, it takes hours to explore, but can easily take days if you visit the Anne d'Harnoncourt Sculpture Garden behind the main building, the nearby Perelman Building (photography, fashion, textiles, contemporary design) and Rodin Museum (about 150 sculptures by Auguste Rodin, including The Thinker out front), and two historic houses, Cedar Grove and Mount Pleasant. All are owned by the city.

At the time of writing this review, two-day general admission allows you access to all of the above buildings and costs:

$20 for adults (age 19+)
$18 for seniors (age 65+)
$14 for students and youth (valid with student ID or age 13-18)
Free for kids (age 12 and under)

On the first Sunday of every month, 10am-5pm, and every Wednesday, 5-8:45pm, admission is "pay what you wish." The main building is open six days a week, typically closed every Monday, but open most holidays like Memorial Day and Labor Day. Along with being open Wednesday nights for "pay what you wish," the main building is also open on Friday nights for live music and drinks. Parking at the main building's on-site garage is only $5 on Wednesday and Friday nights with validation from the Visitor Services desk.

The standard parking rate is $12 for the first four hours plus $2 for each additional hour. The entrance to the parking deck is located on Anne d'Harnoncourt Drive, close to Kelly Drive. Follow the signs.

The museum is one of the largest and most visited in the world. The main building itself is gargantuan and a work of art. It looks like a grand and magnificent Greek temple with towering columns, majestic fountains, and manicured gardens. While the main building opened in 1928, it's probably best known for its appearances in the Rocky movies beginning in 1976. Since then, the wide stairway leading up to the front of the museum has been known as the Rocky Steps (https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia). The popular Rocky Statue (https://www.yelp.com/biz/the-rocky-statue-philadelphia) is located at the base of the stairs, off to the right (if facing the museum).

At the end of Rocky V (1990), Sylvester Stallone and his son, Sage Stallone, are in front of the main building. Sylvester says to his son, "Look at this, you know. I've been running up and down these steps for 20 years and I never knew there was valuable pictures in this building, you know." In response, Sage says, "Well, you're never too old to learn something new. You're going to love Picasso," as they walk towards the museum (https://youtu.be/I7nWj8Q_FgI). The museum houses over a quarter-million pieces of art from Asia to Europe, Impressionist to Renaissance; there are hundreds of galleries spanning thousands of years. Some of the more well-known artists whose work is on display include the aforementioned Pablo Picasso, Marcel Duchamp (this is home to the largest Duchamp collection in the world), Salvador Dali, and Vincent van Gogh.

If you have time, walk around to the west side of the building. There's a small forest with benches where you can sit down and relax. It's peaceful and serene. My fiancee loved that little wispy and willowy area.

My friends and I had a splendiferous time at the Backyard Axe Throwing League in East Nashville. The Backyard Axe Throwing League, also known as BATL, is a chain of axe throwing facilities that originated in Toronto. They started in 2006. I'm not sure when this BATL location opened in Nashville, but I think it's fairly new.

This was my 3rd axe throwing experience. All have been at different businesses. Each business has had its pros and cons. So far, I think BATL has been the best one I've been to. I really like their digital scoring system. Each set of throwing lanes has a big display that updates with live scoring down to which section of the target is hit. While scoring data is input manually by staff assigned to each lane, I think it's still pretty cool.

In the last year or so, axe throwing has been trending, at least in the Southeast. If you've never tried it, it's a lot of fun and great for groups. It's kind of like bowling or Topgolf, but the best comparison is darts, except instead of throwing darts, you're throwing hand axes. It sounds dangerous, but it's really not if you and your friends listen to the staff and follow the rules. Of course, you have to sign waivers. Remember to wear closed-toe shoes. No sandals/flip-flops.

Our group of nine paid $38.89 per person for an approximately 2-hour session of axe throwing (it was more like 2 hours and 15 minutes). The BATL staff member assigned to our group was Hope. She was our coach. She laid out the ground rules and taught us the proper way to throw axes. She monitored our lanes the entire time we were there and kept track of scoring for us (they have a specific scoring system).

There are 2 kinds of axes you can throw here. One is the standard hand axe which is what you use most of the time. The other is a "big f***ing axe" (BFA) which, if I recall correctly, is used for dramatic tie breakers. Hope also let us take turns throwing the BFA after our game was over just for fun. When the BFA comes out, a loud announcement is made so other lanes hear, and your throwing lane is temporarily chained off and extended due to the axe's size. The BFA pretty much requires two hands and extra room in order to be thrown. It's significantly bigger and heavier than the regular hand axes.

Hope was a skookum axe throwing coach. She was almost like a drill sergeant, relentlessly encouraging us for continual improvement with what seemed like an endless amount of energy. I have to hand it to her. She did a great job. We played round-robin 1v1 matches to determine standings. Each match consisted of 3 rounds. Each round consisted of 5 throws. The top 4 in the standings eventually got bracketed into a tournament and faced off to determine who would be crowned champion.

Compared to the other 2 axe throwing places I've been to, BATL comes right in the middle in terms of how difficult it was to get the axes to stick on the wooden targets. Some targets are more accepting than others. Some are more beat up and hard while others are "fresher" and softer. All the places I've been to periodically spray their targets with water. I suspect this is to soften the targets and make them easier to hit.

BATL has a full bar serving beer (including draft and many local selections) plus liquor, a canned cocktail, and canned, poured, and bottles of wine. They serve food too.

Check available throwing times and book your reservation here: https://batlgrounds.com/axe-throwing-nashville/. Enjoy!

Dick & Jenny's is located in New Orleans' Uptown.  Their focus is on upscale Louisiana cuisine, but in a casual setting.  As such, the restaurant is located in an old wooden cottage.  Small, intimate, and candle-lit.  We had a reservation for a large group of 12 on a Saturday night.  We arrived early and the table was already setup and waiting for us.

The menu is seasonal with a handful of items: appetizers, soups/salads, entrees, and desserts.  They also have specials not on the menu, one of which included a calamari starter that we ended up ordering.  Among the items I tried:

Corn-fried calamari - served with spicy sauce on top of spinach
Corn-fried Louisiana oysters - also included cole slaw and remoulade (mayonnaise-based French sauce)
Seared duck breast - served with two slices of Louisiana alligator sausage, dirty rice, greens, and smoked sage demi-glace (rich brown French sauce)

The table also gets complimentary corn bread and French rolls.  The corn bread is served in soft, fluffy blocks.  It was some of the best corn bread I've had in a while.  The blocks were moist, delicate, and crumble in your hand.  Loved the fried oysters and they are best eaten with the slaw and remoulade at the same time.  The oysters were light and crispy.  The duck breast and alligator sausage were amazing.  The duck breast was thick yet tender and the alligator sausage was very flavorful.  They were perfect with both the greens and rice.  Everyone loved their dishes.  Check out the photos I've uploaded with this review to see what I'm talking about.

As mentioned previously, the restaurant is upscale, but has a casual atmosphere.  The tables are small.  Water is served in mason jars.  Service was great, from the host to the servers.  We cabbed it here, so I can't say much about the parking, although I didn't see any valet or parking lot.  Looked like just street parking around the restaurant.  Overall, an excellent dining experience.

Jonathan Best Gourmet Grocer is an old-school, specialty food shop located inside Reading Terminal Market. It's situated near the northwest corner of the market, near where most of the Pennsylvania Dutch merchants are, between Martin's and Umi.

This compact grocery store has tall, narrow aisles with racks and shelves densely-packed with product. Like the market, it's old and well-worn. The shop sells ready-to-eat, grab-and-go soups, salads, and sandwiches. They have a fridge with beverages -- perfect for a quick refreshment while exploring the market/city. In addition, they stock a unique variety of food products, from oils and vinegars, to pastas and sauces; special chocolates and spices too. During our visit, prices seemed reasonable and affordable, especially for in the city. I picked up a cold bottled drink from the market-facing fridge and paid in cash. I can't remember if this place is strictly cash-only.

There used to be a 30-plus-year-old Jonathan Best Gourmet Grocer location in Chestnut Hill (northwest Philly), but it closed March 31, 2013. This location remains.

Service was fine.

Our experiences with TSA PreCheck at Terminal D at Philadelphia International Airport (PHL) have been excellent. Five stars.

We flew Delta out of Philly for a couple trips recently. On the first trip out, we showed up to the TSA PreCheck Terminal D line around 11:00am on an ordinary Monday (when I say "ordinary," I mean not a holiday or special occasion). We were through security in less than 10 minutes and that included a shift change and two bag inspections ahead of us. Awesome.

The second trip out, we showed up around 2:10pm on an ordinary Sunday. There was no line, no wait to meet the first set of TSA agents (the ones who check your ID and where you scan your boarding pass) and there was hardly a line to go through bag and body screening. Getting through security that time was almost instant. Amazing.

My limited interactions with the TSA agents, from the folks who checked the boarding passes on my phone to see if they had the little TSA PreCheck logo to the folks who waved me through the body scanner, were fine. No issues.

Great job, TSA and PHL. If only security was this quick and easy everywhere every time.

Bellerive Country Club was site of the 2018 PGA Championship, one of the more memorable golf majors in recent history due to the drama that unfolded that championship Sunday.

In light traffic, Bellerive is located about 20-30 minutes west of the city of St. Louis and only 15-20 minutes southwest of the airport.

This is a private club that was established in 1897. The current golf course was designed by Robert Trent Jones Sr. and opened in 1960. Since then, the club has hosted three majors: the 1965 US Open, the 74th PGA Championship in 1992, and the 100th PGA Championship in 2018. It's also hosted two senior majors, the 2004 US Senior Open and the 2013 Senior PGA Championship, as well as the 2008 BMW Championship, the second-to-last tournament of the FedExCup Playoffs.

Brooks Koepka (-16) won the 2018 PGA Championship by two strokes over Tiger Woods (-14) who finished in sole possession of 2nd place. On Sunday, Tiger shot the best score of his career in the final round of a major (64). Unfortunately, it was too little, too late against a dominant force like Koepka who refused to give up the lead. It was very exciting to watch, especially at the time. Tiger was getting closer and closer to winning his 15th major, his first in what would have been 10 years. Less than a month prior, he had sole possession of the lead early in the final round of the Open Championship at Carnoustie. After several winless and absent years on Tour, the possibility of Tiger winning a major championship had become real again.

The month after the 2018 PGA Championship at Bellerive, Tiger won his first PGA Tour event since 2013 with a victory at the Tour Championship at East Lake in Atlanta. He followed that up with his historic Masters win the following April (2019). And the rest is history.

Brooks Koepka, meanwhile, went on to repeat by winning the 2019 PGA Championship at Bethpage Black and finished tied for 2nd behind Tiger at the Masters in 2019.

The bubble tea we had from Tea Do was good. We enjoyed it.

One of our friends, who currently lives in Philly, brought us here. It was a good choice. Another one of our friends, who used to live in Philly, considers this Philly's first "legit" bubble tea place. It opened in 2012. It's located in Chinatown, just one block north of Friendship Gate: https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinatown-friendship-gate-philadelphia.

Outside, the corner storefront has a cool mural of a dragon. Inside, the place was packed. Almost every seat was taken - and this was on a Sunday night around 8:10pm. Like a lot of bubble tea shops, Tea Do isn't big, but it does have seating. There are a handful of high tables and low/coffee tables. Several years old now, there's nothing too remarkable about the interior.

The menu is sizable with over 76 drinks to choose from. They include Tea Do specialties (special drinks unique to this brand), smoothies, milk bubble tea, popping bubble drinks, green tea drinks, black tea drinks, and aloe vera drinks. All drinks come in regular and large sizes. Most specialties and smoothies run $4.25 each for regular and $5.25 each for large, milk teas $3.50 regular / $4.50 large, and other drinks $3.75 regular / $4.75 large. There are 17 topping options and 16 of them cost $0.50 each (white pearl jelly is $0.75).

In addition to the regular menu, there was a blackboard menu on the counter. During our visit, it advertised Tiger milk tea, winter melon green tea, Johnny tea, and chrysanthemum tea plus apple and yogurt popping boba and almond milk substitute. There was no description of the Tiger and Johnny teas, so you'd have to ask the staff.

I tried three drinks:

* Grasshopper (large, $5.25)
* Taro bubble milk tea (large, $4.50)
* Oolong bubble milk tea (regular, $3.75)

I enjoyed all the drinks and would recommend all three of them. Across the board, I thought the tea and topping quality was good. Good tea flavor and fresh, appetizing toppings with ideal textures.

The Grasshopper was different than what I'm used to (I usually order milk bubble teas). The Grasshopper is made with green tea, green apple, pear, green tea jelly, and lychee jelly. The drink was mildly sweet, a little bit tart, ice cold, and very refreshing. It hit the spot for me. I think my fiancee liked it the best of the drinks we ordered.

The taro bubble milk tea and the oolong bubble milk tea were both solid. No complaints here. Both drinks had a smooth, non-powdery consistency with nice flavor and ideal sweetness (for me). The boba was excellent; soft and delectably chewy.

Service was fine. The apathetic cashier could've been friendlier. He didn't have a great attitude. If we didn't tell him what size we wanted our drinks, he would've made them all large. He didn't ask us what sizes we wanted. Our order was filled quick.

According to Tea Do's website, this location in Philly is the first location. There are six other locations in the Northeast including one in Boston Chinatown: https://www.teadocafe.com/locations-1.

TL;DR - Tea Do is good.

Wow. Why can't all Mediterranean and Middle Eastern restaurants be this good? Dizengoff is an Israeli restaurant with *the* best hummus I've had to date, anywhere, and probably the best pita too. This place is simply outstanding. Stop reading and go. Now. (After writing over 3,400 Yelp reviews over the past 11+ years, I've never written that before.)

This is a small fast-casual restaurant that opened in Center City in 2014. A second location opened inside the Whole Foods behind the Rodin Museum in 2016. It's named after Dizengoff Street, a major street in Tel Aviv (the street, in turn, is named after the first mayor of Tel Aviv).

We showed up on a Saturday around 12:45pm. All seats inside were taken. Then again, there are only about 15-20 seats inside. We got lucky and scored some seats at the communal table shortly after placing our order. The line to order was short, but there was a steady stream of customers the entire time we were there (we left by 1:30pm). Staff keeps the line moving. This place is popular and does good business. It's a well-oiled machine. There are four small umbrella-covered tables outside on the sidewalk, but the weather was so hot that no one was sitting at them.

This is a trendy spot with a sort of hipstery vibe. Dizengoff's logo is bright pink and the front door frame and patio furniture are a bold orange color. The storefront has a retractable door that presumably cranks open when the weather is nice. Inside, there's an open kitchen featuring a Wood Stove brand oven where all the fresh, scratch-made pitas are baked.

The menu is short and simple. They serve hummus in five different varieties/toppings -- tehina, chicken, pepper, cucumber, and cauliflower -- priced at $10-13 each. All menu prices include tax. I think the food is affordable especially when you consider its quality and deliciousness. Each order of hummus includes fresh-baked pita and two sides, one of which is a Jerusalem salad with pickle, and the other a surprise (well, to us they were). Most Mediterranean and Middle Eastern restaurants serve hummus as an appetizer or side, but here it's an entree and it's good.

You can make small additions to any hummus order such as extra pita ($1), egg ($1), and pita chips ($3) and you can add any topping on the side. In addition, they offer Za'atar roasted chicken dinners to-go ($36) and shakshuka, a North African dish made with eggs poached in a tomato-chili pepper sauce, on Sundays. Alcoholic beverages (beer, white wine, rose) are available for $4-8 each and they sell a frozen lemonana synonymous to, I think, the Middle Eastern limonana drink which is a frozen mint lemonade ($4 without booze, $8 with). Happy hour runs daily, 6-8pm.

We ordered one hummus with tehina and egg ($10 + $1 = $11) and one hummus with chicken ($13). Both orders were phenomenal. Along with the pita and Jerusalem salads with pickles mentioned above, the hummus with tehina and egg came with a marinated cucumber side salad and the hummus with chicken came with a roasted red pepper side salad. We noticed these sides were the same as the "cucumber" and "pepper" hummus toppings listed on the menu. I'm not sure how they decided which ones we'd get (they didn't ask us), but we liked the variety and enjoyed them both. They were flavorful and delicious.

Each order was served on its on tray. The arrangement of the dishes and the presentation of each individual dish was colorful and beautiful. The food tasted as good as it looked: excellent all around. Everything tasted incredibly fresh and high quality. The hummus was super smooth, creamy, and delectable. It had an extra bit of tehina (same as tahini or toasted ground sesame seeds) flavor. Both the hummus with tehina and egg and the hummus with chicken were nicely seasoned and packed with mouthwatering flavor. The jammy soft-boiled egg was cooked perfectly. The chicken was tasty; it didn't overpower the hummus and complemented it well. The pita was served hot/warm, each serving in its own paper sleeve. The pita had exited the oven just minutes (seconds?) before being served to us. They were soft and pillowy and were appetizingly charred/toasted on the outside. So good.

I also had a frozen lemonana ($4). It was tart and refreshing. I think it's worth getting and perfect for hot summer days. It's like a minty lemonade slushy.

Not only was the food great, but the service was too. We didn't get his name, but the cashier who served us was very friendly and helpful. White guy, curly hair, glasses, pink Dizengoff shirt. The young blonde girl busing tables was nice and sweet too.

When it comes to taste, price, and service, Dizengoff is a must-try restaurant in Philly, in my opinion.

As a huge fan of the Rocky movies, from the original Rocky (1976), which won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1977, to the latest installment, Creed II (2018), visiting the Rocky Statue and Rocky Steps (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rocky-steps-philadelphia) were my biggest priorities on my first visit to Philadelphia. Yes, I love Rocky that much. The movies are entertaining, nostalgic, and inspirational and the music, especially the songs by Bill Conti, are iconic and some of the absolute best in cinematic history (and in all of music, in my opinion).

At the time of writing this review, the Rocky Statue is located at the bottom of the famous Rocky Steps at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. If facing the front of the museum, the statue is located off to the right in a special fenced-in area. It's funny. There are several historic statues, fountains, and buildings/museums in the area, but the most popular one is from pop culture: the Rocky Statue.

We visited the statue on a Sunday around 3pm. It was obvious where the statue was because there was a line for it (there wasn't a line for anything else in the vicinity). "Admission" is free. You just have to wait in line if you want to get an up-close look and/or take a picture with the statue. When we visited, there was an employee, who looked like he worked for the museum, manning the statue area. I think he was there to keep the line in order and moving. However, the line did a good job of regulating itself. I'm glad he was there though, just in case. We entered the line at 3:07pm and I got my picture snapped with the statue at 3:22pm, so we waited a total of 15 minutes. Not bad.

Rocky fans might remember the statue's unveiling in Rocky III (1983): https://youtu.be/hxnifQ7EdxY. Actually, three statues were cast in the early 80s, originally commissioned by Sylvester Stallone in 1980. The statue at the art museum was the one used in the movie, donated to the City of Philadelphia by Stallone. The statue bounced around the city over the years before returning to the art museum in 2006, coincident with the release of Rocky Balboa (2006).

The statue is bronze and stands 8 feet, 6 inches tall. The brick and concrete base has a plaque with a quote from a powerful scene in that movie (https://youtu.be/mk82j1jQw_8). The plaque reads:

"ROCKY BALBOA

It's not how hard you hit, it's how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward. That's how winning is done.

This statue is dedicated to the great city of Philadelphia and the brotherhood of its people.

Sylvester Stallone
2006"

It was awesome to see the statue in person and an honor to take a picture with it. The public outdoor space the museum set aside for the statue is clean, well-maintained, and landscaped. It was nicer than I expected.

There were Rocky lookalikes hanging out around the statue and steps. I happened to run into two that I know and met years ago at Dragon Con in Atlanta: @lonstermash and @thelordhumungus (on Instagram). What a small world. The love for Rocky is universal.

We attended a wedding reception on the top floor (third) of the Asian Arts Initiative ("AAI") and had a great time. The AAI is located in Philadelphia's Chinatown North (Callowhill) neighborhood, attached to a Best Western Plus which was perfect for wedding guests. The center sits on Vine which parallels I-676. It has nice views of the downtown Philly skyline to east and south, especially from the top floor.

The AAI is a nonprofit organization. It serves as a community center with an art gallery, workshops, meeting spaces, and theater. The art gallery is located on the first floor and is open weekdays, 10am-6pm. The organization is inclusive, works to promote racial equity, and encourages discourse about the Asian-American experience.

Like many buildings in Center City, the AAI building is old and creaky. There are both stairs and an elevator. The stairwell on the lower level had a funky, sewer-like smell. The stairwell had cool, colorful murals.

The wedding reception took over pretty much the entire third floor space. The open layout had all-white walls and wood (or wood laminate) flooring. The ceiling was decorated in string lights, there was ambient blue and purple lighting up some of the walls, and six windows provided views facing south towards city skyscrapers. There were white tablecloths, candles and flowers, white folding chairs, bar and catering stations set up along the perimeter by Chef's Table Catering of Philadelphia (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chefs-table-catering-philadelphia), a DJ, sound and lighting system, and photo booth.

The ductwork was exposed and generally, the room had a sort of loft or factory feel to it. The reception went off without a hitch. Dinner flowed well, sound was good for mics and music, and lighting was dimmed/turned off for dancing. The reception ran from 6pm to 9pm. During this time, the front door to the center, which otherwise would have been closed, was open. There was a lady stationed at the front desk and she was helpful. The floor was a little warm. I'm not sure if the AC was working or not.

There were two restrooms. At this event, they were designated one per sex though I think normally, they're gender-neutral. The ladies got the multi-stall restroom while the guys got the single-stall restroom. This caused a backup for the guys at one point. I think we could have also used restrooms on the other two floors if we had to.

My friends and I had a lot of fun playing the "Nashville" room at The Escape Game Nashville. With several escape room rookies on our team of six, we still managed to beat the room in only 42 minutes 11 seconds (17 minutes 49 seconds left on the clock). I thought that was impressive considering this room was rated a "7/10" difficulty by the company.

The Escape Game is an escape room chain with several locations around the country including Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Minneapolis, and Orlando. There are two locations in Nashville: (1) the Berry Hill location in South Nashville which opened in 2014 and (2) this newer location in downtown Nashville which opened in 2015.

Surface lot parking is available adjacent to this location, but it's not free. We took Uber, but we should have taken Lyft because The Escape Game partnered with Lyft to offer discounts. If you've never used Lyft before, you can visit this link, https://www.lyft.com/invite/escapedt, or download the app and enter code EscapeDT to get $5 off your ride to or from The Escape Game. If you already have Lyft, you can enter code TEG10 on the app and save 10% on your ride to or from The Escape Game.

Currently, this location offers four rooms:

* Gold Rush - 2-7 players, 7/10 difficulty
* The Heist - 2-8 players, 8/10 difficulty
* Nashville - 2-7 players, 7/10 difficulty
* Prison Break - 2-8 players, 9/10 difficulty

If you've never played an escape room game before, they're a lot of fun. You get "locked" in a room and have 60 minutes to escape. You're really not locked in case there's an emergency; it's just for fun. You have to solve clues and riddles and uncover secrets in order to escape. It's a lot like playing one of those old-school point-and-click adventure games on a computer, except these are actual mocked-up rooms with props and working gadgets. If you get stuck, you can ask for up to three hints from your "game master," an employee of The Escape Game who watches you and your team via closed-circuit video.

We chose the Nashville room because 5/6 of us were visiting Nashville from out of town, so we wanted to get the full Music City experience.

The Nashville room was the 55th escape room I've played since I started playing escape rooms in 2014. So, I have a lot of rooms to compare Nashville to. Honestly, over the years, a lot of the rooms have started blending together for me. Generally speaking, I thought the Nashville room was solidly built. The quality of the construction and the props were good to very good. The room is made to look like a music producer's office and music studio, so there are musical instruments, speakers and sound equipment, a recording booth, and more. It's pretty cool. As far as the game design, I thought the clues and riddles were fair and they flowed well. There was a decent story and objective: you and your teammates are a band who have to find the producer's one last contract.

Out of the dozens of rooms I've played, I give credit to the Nashville room for being unique. It's the first and so far only music-themed escape room I've played. A couple other rooms here, The Heist and Prison Break, are more generic. Other escape room companies offer similar-themed rooms. Nashville is one-of-a-kind in this regard. Aside from that, nothing about the Nashville experience made it stand out from many of the other rooms I've done. For example, there was no memorable, ingenious puzzle or some sort of dramatic or unforgettable moment. It was simply a fun room, which in my experience, most escape rooms are.

The Escape Game Nashville's rate is $31.99 plus tax per person to play one room. This worked out to be $35 per person for our group. To date, it's the most expensive escape room I've played. I've paid $30 and up for several rooms, but the majority I've played have been under $30 whether it be a business' regular rate or a discounted rate through something like Groupon. At the time of writing this review, I've paid an average of $20.15 per room for 56 rooms including this one. Most of the rooms have been in metro Atlanta: https://www.yelp.com/collection/n0eJ13G2Zc8qBxAZB9Mm0w.

If you don't fully book all slots in a room, there's a chance you'll be teamed up with someone you don't know. For example, the 6 of us booked the Nashville room which can accommodate up to 7, so there was a chance a random person could have joined us to fill the last slot. Just something to keep in mind.

Apart from the high price when compared to other escape room games, I did find The Escape Game Nashville to be enjoyable and recommend it for any group (friends, family, coworkers) looking for a fun activity to do. Everyone in our group had a good time.

We had Sunday brunch at James and I thought it was A-OK. This is a relatively new New American restaurant and bar (opened September 2016) that is located just two blocks south of Logan Circle (a.k.a. Logan Square). The name is fitting because it's named after James Logan, the 14th mayor of Philadelphia. It's a modern take on American fare with an elevated tavern atmosphere.

This is a nice-looking, spacious restaurant with a sizable bar and both indoor and outdoor seating. Outdoor seating consists of umbrella-covered tables on the sidewalk. The interior has an assortment of booths, tables, high-tops, and TVs. This place works just as well for groups as it does one-on-one dates. Refined yet casual is a good way to describe the environment.

Brunch is served Saturday and Sunday, 11am-3pm. A bar menu (food) is offered daily, 3-5pm. Most brunch plates run $13-20 each. Expect to spend about $9-13 each for soups and salads and $16-18 each on sandwiches and burgers, all day. Dinner entrees will set you back $22-27 each. So, this isn't a cheap restaurant, but it's not very expensive either.

We were part of a large brunch party (about 20-30 of us) and a special preset menu was prepared for us. We took up three tables in the dining room. The menu was three courses:

First Course
* Individual fruit salads - seasonal fruit, berries, mint

Second Course (choice of)
* Frittata - spinach, mozzarella, artichokes
* James French toast - vanilla, cinnamon, whipped cream, maple syrup
* Brunch burger - ground short rib and brisket, Taylor pork roll, Cabot cheddar, sunny-side-up egg

Dessert (choice of)
* Apple pie
* Chocolate cake
(Perhaps more choices, I forget...)

In general, I thought the food was fine. No complaints. Everything was plated and presented nicely.

The "seasonal" fruit in the individual fruit salads consisted of watermelon, cantaloupe, honeydew, pineapple, strawberry, and blackberry. All of the fruits were ripe and fresh, comparable to a fruit salad one can get at a grocery store. I liked this light and healthy option. However, from a sit-down restaurant, I expected some creativity or something unique to set it apart from being essentially a plain fruit salad.

Of the second course options, I tried two: the frittata and James French toast. Both were good. These dishes were a little on the heavier side, particularly the French toast which was like a dessert. The French toast was prepared with challah bread, I believe. The consistency was somewhat dense. Not among the best French toast I've had, but not bad either. I liked the frittata better, but it could have used an extra ingredient like meat or something. Again, not bad. The frittata came with a side of chopped skillet potatoes, peppers, and onions. We asked for a side of ketchup to go with those.

For dessert, I tried both the apple pie and chocolate cake. The desserts looked wonderful. The apple pie was yummy, but it was fairly dense and cold, like it had just been removed from the fridge. Same with the chocolate cake. The chocolate cake was super rich. While tasty, I could only take a few bites of it. Same for my friends.

For drinks, I had both an OJ and iced coffee. The glass of OJ came with a slice of orange which was a nice little touch. The drinks were par for the course.

Service was great. There were at least a couple servers working our large group and they were polite and attentive.

In the end, I found our meal here to be satisfactory. While the food wasn't amazing nor memorable, I still thought it was decent and sufficed for what it was (brunch). I liked the design of the restaurant, inside and out, and the service was on point. Restrooms were clean too.

Swann Memorial Fountain is a Philadelphia landmark. If you've never been to Philly before, I recommend checking it out. It's located in the center and is the highlight of Logan Circle (https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-circle-philadelphia-2) a.k.a. Logan Square, the midpoint of the scenic and wide Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia). The fountain opened in 1924 and is named after Dr. Wilson Cary Swann, founder of the Philadelphia Fountain Society. The society provided sources of fresh drinking water for the city.

My fiancee and I visited this fountain on a sunny and hot Sunday afternoon after having brunch at the nearby James Restaurant & Bar (https://www.yelp.com/biz/james-restaurant-and-bar-philadelphia). The fountain and surrounding park were filled with both locals and tourists; a popular spot for sure. There were lots of families and many children swimming and playing in the fountain despite there being signs that said no swimming was allowed. What's up with that?

This fountain reminds me of Buckingham Fountain in Chicago (https://www.yelp.com/biz/buckingham-fountain-chicago) due to its vintage, size, design, and art style. Buckingham Fountain opened in 1927, is huge, and was designed in art deco style, all very similar or the same as this fountain. Both fountains have multiple spouts that spew water way up high. Buckingham's center spout shoots water as high as 150 feet, while Swann's center spout shoots "only" as high as 50 feet. Buckingham has sea horse water jets while Swann has frogs, turtles, fish, and swan jets. Buckingham has water shows, but Swann does not. Apparently, people swim in the Swann, but not in the Buckingham.

Statues of Native Americans in the center of the fountain represent three nearby waterways: the Delaware River (man), Schuylkill River (woman), and Wissahickon Creek (girl). The man who designed this fountain, Alexander Stirling Calder, is the son of Alexander Milne Calder, who designed the statue of William Penn which sits atop City Hall.

This is a scenic spot and it's great for taking photos. The fountain is mostly bright blue, there are several spouts/jets of water, and you have a nice 360-degree view of the city, from City Hall to the south to the Philadelphia Museum of Art to the north. There are many sights and attractions nearby. For sightseers, I recommend walking the entire length of Benjamin Franklin Parkway (the aforementioned city hall and museum are the termini). Benches, grass, and trees surround the fountain. The fountain was clean and in good working condition during our visit.

The Pearl is located near the French Quarter just off Canal St.  It's been around for 80 years and serves traditional Louisiana Creole cuisine.  The menu is simple one-pager with catfish, oyster, and gumbo appetizers, a variety of sandwiches and po' boys, and about 10 different entrees.

I tried the jambalaya (seasoned rice with chicken and sausage).  The rice grains were thick and fluffy.  Chicken and sausage were tender and the plate was surrounded with a tangy red sauce.  Overall, it made for an appetizing plate.  Also tried the raw oysters - yummy.

The interior of the restaurant reminds you of a 1950s-style diner with neon lights and curvy architecture.  We got fantastic service despite rolling in just as they were about to close.  We had a big group of 10 and the waitress was proactive in separating our checks.

The French Market is an old outdoor marketplace located in the lower part of the French Quarter.  I think it's mostly a tourist trap as most of the vendors are selling cheap New Orleans souvenirs (t-shirts, jewelry, magnets, small statues, etc.) at inflated prices.  Despite what many people say, you can bargain with the shop owners if you really want something.  I asked for the price on a set of Georgia Tech beads out of curiosity and as I walked away, the seller yelled a lower price at me to try and get me to come back.

The only good items in the market are probably at the local food stalls and produce vendors.  When I visited, they had a bunch of pumpkins ready to go and we saw several locals coming here to buy their batch of pumpkins.  You can also buy alligator on a stick here, although it looked a little suspect.  It's not a terrible place to visit just to say you've been here, but you can easily skip this place if you're visiting NOLA and crunched for time.

I'm giving Bourbon St. four stars not because of the stench of rotten trash and sewage that permeates the entire strip, the plethora of souvenir shops with nothing but junk, the dirty bars with sticky floors and overpriced alcohol, or the tiny uneven sidewalks littered with trash.  I'm giving Bourbon St. four stars because of the people from all walks of life who come to party on this street night in and night out.  Bourbon St. stretches about 12 blocks, so it's a good distance of nothing but clubs, bars, strip clubs, souvenir shops, and restaurants.  It makes for a great place to party and people watch.

If there was ever a perfect bar hopping street, this is it.  You can carry your open containers from bar to bar, although the bouncers at some bars won't let you carry in certain drinks such as the popular hand grenades (rum, gin, vodka, grain alcohol, and melon liquor) since they can take a long time to drink.  Along with the hand grenades, which can be purchased at four different Tropical Isle bars along the street, the hurricanes (lime juice, passion fruit syrup, and rum) at Pat O'Brien's are also a very popular drink in NOLA.

I went to Bourbon St. three nights in a row and each night was eventful, whether it was a fight breaking out with bloodied shirts and faces, tiny drunk bachelorettes getting their bodies slammed against brick walls by huge 300-pound bouncers, policemen riding in on horses into the middle of the street and trampling people, prostitutes blatantly soliciting themselves, out-of-town tokers from Mississippi State telling you that North Carolina is not considered a Southern state because it has "North" in the name and the state is above the Mason-Dixon (false), big girls and small girls booty dancing on way too tiny stages, police cars with lights flashing and sirens blasting trying to make their way down the middle of the pedestrian-packed street, women disguised in masks grabbing random men's crotches as they walk by, Saudi Arabians with afros and braces approaching you at clubs, people puking and relieving themselves in narrow alleyways, bums coming up to your face and talking complete nonsense, people running into street poles and breaking their noses, etc. etc. etc.

awful awful food. For the love of God, please DO NOT eat the prime rib. It was disgusting. I don't care if it comes with a baked potato or it has an attractive price of $13.99 DON'T EAT IT

It was DRY, Salty and covered in huge chunks of fat.

It tasted like a huge slab of thick beef jerky. No lies.

Came here for NYE dinner. I was very impressed with my dishes and just as equally impressed with the bill.

I had the lamb which was done two ways. braised lamb shoulder and seared lamb chops accompanied by grilled artichoke hearts and brussel sprouts.

The lamb was super tender, moist and seasoned perfectly! 

I also got the hamachi ceviche with fried plantains. Very good with a nice kick of heat. 

Over all dinner for 6, bottle of wine, 2 desserts and 4 appetizers came out to about $460 which was NOT bad at all. The food was definitely worth it and we all agreed that we would come back.

extra star for our server but other than that the experience here was awful... I came here with a big group and maybe that took the staff by surprise but waiting almost a hour for our food to come out is not ok. When the food finally came out we noticed that half of our entrees were almost cold. Steaks were way over cooked, appetizers were cold and even my sprite was flat. How can you give out flat soda? I had to ask for another because it was just lime, sugar and water. I ordered a salad with seared scallops. I received oily arugula with RAW scallops. I actually asked if the chef could cook the scallops a little longer. I got a brand new salad which was nice but it took almost 2 hours for the salad to come out all together (from ordering to finally getting the 2nd salad). Everyone was done eating so I just packed my salad to go. 

A soggy salad is just awful. I ended up not even touching it. 

I honestly never EVER send back food. In fact this was my first time ever doing that and I felt awful doing it but that is just how bad the food was here. I feel bad giving this place a bad review because our server was seriously top notch....

Save your time and don't come here if its snowing. Its super cold out, the park looks empty and almost desert like and definitely take my advice and do not walk from downtown. It is NOT walking distance from downtown when it is 30 degrees out. Granted, this park did look nice, no bums were seen at all (they were probably frozen.) but it wasn't as great as I pictured it from the reviews. 

I say skip out on this place and do the river walk instead by downtown. Its just the same thing but safer and definitely walking distance from downtown.

saw the "awful awful burger" on the travel channel.  Scoped this place out before lunch and the nugget itself smelled awful awful literally awful awful.

Held my nose and made my way to the back to see the restaurant area then left to gamble.

Met up my friends here for a late lunch and it was packed. Waited almost 15 minutes for the food to come to the counter. I almost fell asleep but a man screaming at the top of his lungs "CHOCOLATE MILKSHAKES!" and other diner words woke me up. It was actually pretty annoying and he sounded actually very mad as if he was yelling like no one was paying attention to him.

The burger itself was whatevers. Nothing like I imagined it to be. There was all this hype put into it and in the end all I got was a mediocre burger served to me on top of soggy fries in a smelly casino.

I love this place. I found it on yelp while in reno this past weekend. This has to be one of the best little places to have breakfast.

Its located in a tiny strip mall next to a bar. There are limited indoor seats so come earlier or you might have to take your food to go.

I had the "special" which was a rendition of eggs benedict. a piece of crispy toast, topped with a nice piece of ham which was topped with 2 over easy eggs. Instead of hollandaise sauce there was a great chorizo gravy covering the eggs. It was marvelous. It was probably the best breakfast I have had in years if not ever. My bf had the el jefe which was just a breakfast burrito with chorizo, bacon, ham, eggs and fresh salsa verde. 

Both dishes were spectacular. To top it off they serve coffee, fresh baked ham and cheese scones, croissants and even have gelato. The service was great also. The young lady was very attentive, nice and made us feel comfortable even though we were obvious out of townies.

Try this place out if you're in the area. You won't be disappointed

Came back here today with some friends and once again this place is nothing but amazing. Some of my friends are picky when it comes to food but everyone thoroughly enjoyed their breakfast! I highly recommended the 5th street benedict which I got last time and it didn't fail to impress my friends. The sandwiches were amazing and this time we finally got to get some chocolate croissants and ham & cheese scones. Once again, the service was great. Super friendly and made everyone feel comfortable. I'm so glad that we got the chance to come back here for breakfast because I probably won't be back in the area till next year (at the soonest that is).. I'll definitely miss the great breakfast that they serve here..

Come to San Jose and open up a location here!! Thanks in advance haha.

OK... Take it from a Korean.. an out of townie Korean. Best Jampong I have ever had. Now first of all, where the hell is sparks and why do they have a Korean restaurant here and WHY is it so far from me?! 

I live 7 hours away but I would DEFINITELY eat here all the time if I lived closer. I was pleasantly surprised that the jampong was that delicious. I've had so many different jampongs around the area (Bay Area) and we are Korean infested and if Ktown can't get Jampong right but Sparks, NV can get it right then something is wrong...

Jampong: Spicy Seafood Noodle Soup. 

I was in reno for the weekend and my bf and I were craving Korean food to save us from the blizzard and almost sub zero weather. We yelped Jampong and holy hell it led us to this place. YES, I was hesitant on trying this place but seriously.. SERIOUSLY the best Jampong I have ever tasted and I've been eating it since forever.

The Bibimbap was good also but I didn't try any of the "staple" Korean dishes like bulgogi or kalbi. If they can master Jampong and Bibimbap then I have no doubt that their bulgogi or kalbi are nothing but excellent. 

I also couldn't help notice that there wasn't a lot of koreans around the area.. or in that fact, asians so if you are looking to try Korean food this is some damn good Korean food. 

WHO WOULD OF KNOWN that SPARKS, NV would have the best tasting Korean food...

ALSO its super cheap. Jampong where I'm from is $12.. At Hana Garden it was around $8!! wtf...

This place is a breath of fresh air from all of those huge popular ski resorts. The staff is super friendly and there aren't major lines for the ski lifts. The park is actually pretty big and since there aren't a lot of people the snow doesn't get packed as fast as other places. I came up here for NYE weekend with some friends. The snow was amazing!!! I broke my bindings last year and decided to just rent a board for the day. It was a very decent price for about $30.... Not bad!! They don't have lockers but they have a $2 bucket rental. They give you a poker chip with your assigned box # on it and they keep your stuff in the back.. 

The food is whatever, there is limited seating inside. They have 2 bunny slopes which are really tiny and i honestly have no idea how anyone could learn on those but over all the park is very well kept.

I would definitely choose this place over northstar or alpine. Less people, better snow and cheaper prices!

this place really isn't that bad. Its connected to circus circus and el dorado so everything that you possibly need is in walking distance (except for a dam starbucks..) There were some downsides with the hotel though... The water was barely hot. We called down to the front desk and they said they were having problems with their "boilers" and "water heaters" and that we should just run the water for 15 minutes till it gets hot. It barely got hot. We took luke warm showers the entire weekend.. it was awful.

The walls are paper thin. We had the honor of being placed next door to a screaming child. The child's screams sounded like you were in a horror flick. 

We had the exact same room as our friends but they had furniture that we didn't have. When we called into the front desk asking about the missing furniture they questioned us like we stole it. 

Overall it is probably the better hotel on the little strip but when it comes down to it they need to make major adjustments and renovations fast!

This place is so much fun. I randomly ran into this rink while trying to hunt down a Wells Fargo ATM machine in downtown Reno this past weekend. I was constantly Yelping "Ice Skating" because I really wanted to go while on vacation and it was such a pleasant surprise to run into an outdoor ice skating rink. 

Now this rink is only here from now till Jan 5th for the Holiday Season. Its nicely decorated with a huge Christmas tree and is playing Christmas music. What was just as amazing were the prices. $7 for adults and $2 for skate rentals. They give you a wrist band so you can leave and come back within the day without renting skates again (Just keep your wrist band on). There are potta-potties on the side and also a small concession stand selling hotdogs, candy and drinks.

Its located right on the edge of downtown reno next to the river hence the name "rink on the river". There is a free parking garage right across the street from the rink also. This place attracted not only families but a lot of adults too. It was a fun experience and my bf and I skated for HOURS!

The hours vary by each day and also on the weather. I definitely suggest checking this place out if you're in the area and are sick of gambling, eating and drinking.

First offfffffffff.. This place is amazing. They have everything imaginable here. Indoor driving range, huge arcade for kids, 24 hour bowling alley, laser tag, miniature golf, that human sling shot thing, go karting, all you can eat sushi, buffet, steak house, wine bar, johnny rockets, round table pizza, starbucks, cafe, movie theater (for $3!!!!!), 2 huge sports bars, bull riding machine, live country music and shops. 

Omg that list went on forever. I used the 2 free nights promotion that they just extended to feb (promo code: 2NITES-2) yes you're welcome.. anyways, the rooms aren't fancy fancy but for $25 more a night you get upgraded to their newly remodeled room equipped with a microwave, fridge and flat screen tvs. My friends upgraded.. I didn't but I didn't mind my room which was sans the fridge, microwave and I had a tube tv but who cares it was the same size

Why do I give this place 4 stars instead of 5? location. Yes its in reno so if you come to gamble or get away then this place is perfect for you. 2 minute short drive to downtown reno and lost of food places etc located in the casino.. IF You come here for boarding then this place might not be for you. Yes there were a lot of people here boarding but with bad weather like I got this past weekend we didn't even get the chance to board. The roads were closed half of the time... even when we tried to go to mt rose the closest yet smaller resort near the hotel it was closed due to weather. 

I say chip in some money with some friends, get a hotel in tahoe so you can 100% make it to the snow. It was definitely a disappointment not being able to go boarding but yet being so close to the snow..

Small location but definitely worth the wait!!! The service is super friendly and the food can not be beat! They offer a wide variety of sandwiches, soups and salads. I had a salad with their home made white balsamic vinegarette which was amazzinngggggg. My friends got the gumbo, broccoli chedder soup, a variety of sandwiches, the chili and the chicken tortilla soup. Everyone was very satisfied with their food and it was a great way to start the day!!

"Art, music, and jewelry by New Orleanians"

Very cool little indie-style shop that actually has what the French market promises but doesn't -- local artists' wares. There's a couple [can't remember their names] who make wood pieces with embedded caught beads that are sold here. I got a flaming heart, our friends got a gorgeous fleur de lys, so we both came home with some real one-of-a-kind art by some real local people as a souvenir of our one-of-a-kind trip. Pop City also sells local-made clothing, handmade journals, music, and a bunch of cool jewelry. Highly recommended.

Hours: 6 a.m. to midnight
Runs from New Orleans on the :15 and :45, from Algiers on the hour and half hour.

Best deal in town. Admire the New Orleans skyline as you enjoy a five-minute FREE ferry ride across the Mississippi. Go downstairs to where the cars park [$1 per car], there's a standing area at the front.

Get off in Algiers, take your picture with the big Louis Armstrong statue, walk around a couple blocks and admire the victorians, grab a drink / snack at the Dry Dock http://www.yelp.com/biz/dry-dock-cafe-and-catering-new-orleans , then hop back on the ferry and enjoy the view for another couple minutes.

Had my first chicory and muffaletta here. They were both delicious.
Service was wonderful and the patio seating was shady and worth the wait.

Forgot to order beignets!

Rainbow is the most awesome cheapass clothing store in the world. Not the highest quality but everything is super trendy so it'll be out of style by the time it's falling apart anyway. And it cost you $10 so STFU already.

The one on Canal Street is several times larger than any of the Rainbows I've been to here in the Oakland area; the manager said they weren't even the biggest store in town! I bought bunches of sun dresses and wore them all week. Thank you, Rainbow!

Note: there are two stores, one is all women's clothing, the second store is two stories, kids' stuff and plus sizes.

One of my favorite things we saw in New Orleans -- St. Roch's cemetery, home of The National Shrine of Saint Roch, patron saint of miraculous cures, where they have an altar room filled with marble thank-you tiles and plaster casts of feet and polio braces and eyeballs and big spiders and cockroach parts.

Lots of gorgeous mosaics and statues of saints all around the cemeteries, too.

For more info, see http://strochproject.com/neighborhood.html

"People came to the shrine in large numbers to ask St. Roch for help in cases of affliction, disease and deformities. A small room on the side of the chapel holds a number of offerings left by visitors to the chapel. The tradition was to leave accoutrements of the illness or disability (including, in the past, eyeballs, crutches, and false limbs!) in gratitude for recovery."

NOTE: No joke about closing time, they actually locked us in a few minutes before the posted time. Luckily we have cell phones and there was still someone at the main office [phone numbers posted by the gates] and we didn't have to wait a super long time for the caretaker to come back by. It makes for a great story anyway.

Nice selection, though not as much vintage as I'd expected, it's more current stuff than anything. Good, serviceable stuff, good prices, found a couple things we liked, good range of sizes, a rack of costumery, and lots of boy stuff, too.

My boyfriend wanted to buy a cigar and that's the only reason we stopped in -- I hate cigars. But I'm glad I did, it was interesting watching them made, the staff was all very friendly and not the least bit condescending considering they are experts and we have dumb questions, it was a very cool, relaxing space, and they have the most delightful little museum of cigar arcana in the back. 

Souvenir tip: you can buy their house-brand wooden cigar boxes in a variety of sizes for a couple bucks here, great for your friends who like to craft or stash.

We don't actually dress like this but if you live in New Orleans and are having a California-themed party -- go for it, just don't tell me about it and I won't tell you about what we wear when we have our New Orleans-themed parties. xo.

We went at the tail end of dinner on a weeknight and didn't have to wait at all for a table. Service wasn't slow at all considering that the restaurant was full, we had drinks right away and our food came out quickly enough that we weren't sitting there with our bellies rumbling.

Our server was super chatty and we loved her. The other servers also chimed in on our conversation and that was also awesome. Anyone complaining about how the folks here spend too much time talking instead of serving is in the wrong town and has a stick up their butt and doesn't deserve to eat here.

1. The fried pickles as recommended by Tim P. and my sister: the portions, as pretty much everywhere else we went, were ridiculous. We ordered the appetizer and received a giant bowl of these delicious bites. The couple at the table next to us had ordered the fried okra [also delicious], so we traded off and still had a full take-out container left over.

2. Daughter got a side of red beans and rice [e.g. a giant flippin' platter] and a sausage. Delicious.

3. Chad and I split the mixed plate. I can't even remember anymore what-all came with this -- jambalaya, gumbo, various fried seafood, beans & rice, corn bread, something else probably -- and of course it was a giant mountain of food that was far too much for us. All incredible. Oh! the mac and cheese! I'm not even a huge mac & cheese fan. and OMG BEST EVAR.

4. I'd get just what we had again, except I would bring a couple more people and skip D's side of beans & rice because she could've had some of ours.

5. I bought some pralines, haven't even tried them yet because honestly, New Orleans left me wanting to eat nothing but raw spinach for the next couple months. Hopefully they'll hold up in my fridge for a bit.

6. Super bonus: high school kids' brass band playing in the vacant lot cater-corner.

What everyone else has said -- cute trendwear that's total garbage quality-wise and probably made by small Indonesian children but you get what you pay for. Large selection, lots of frothy lacy things floating around this season, and a bunch of accessories are available. I did not see the Shoe Nami store, which I wanted to because WHAT AN AWESOME NAME.

I can't afford any of it but loved trying it on.

The shopgirls were total candy babes and even sweeter than that.
This is where you can get a bottle of water and candy bar at normal convenience store prices in the quarter.

I am from San Francisco, where all things vintage are picked over, overpriced, and generally straight tore up. I was delighted by the vintage offerings in New Orleans -- affordable! excellent condition! -- and Miss Claudia's was my favorite stop. She has a very nice collection of men's and women's, accessories, and a box of old postcards. I found my dream hat, can't wait til Easter to wear it. Thanks, Miss Claudia, we'll stop by again next time we're in town!

I am pretty sure that this is the place that has lots of beads and if it is, I loved it, they had a great selection of glass and gemstones  along with a bunch of local artist-made jewelry, and more local art in back.

Went to the Goleta location [on Hollister, there are actually two but this was the one that was next to the freeway] -- wow. Up there with SF Bay Area's Thrift Town in terms of AMAZING LEVEL OF ORGANIZATION. All the Pyrex on a shelf, all the traditional Mexi-wear on a special Spanish Days rack, clothes sorted by type/color etc. Loved it.

Minus a star because overall prices were kind of jacked up [I wouldn't have bought anything if they didn't have the half-off blue tags special that day and I didn't see a whole lot of higher-end stuff, much less anything with store tags still on as mentioned in Jillian's review].

One of those places where I wish I'd known what to expect and prepared better for [mainly: wear some dancing shoes] and that I wish I lived closer to.

Vintage cool bowling alley, $18/hour per lane. Full bar, cheap pints of Abita on tap. Bands + dancefloor + lots of folks dancing. Birthday party in the corner, cupcakes for everyone.

One of the highlights of our visit.

This is the kind of place I would never go into but I'd seen several recommendations and it seemed like a "must while in New Orleans" thing so I did end up stopping in, and am so glad -- it made me feel very fancy! It's an old-fashioned ladylike shop, bottles everywhere and smelling papers and bowls of coffee beans to clear your nose. Plenty of florals to choose from, some I'd never heard of. The woman working filled me in on what's what, and I ended up with some of the tea olive perfume which is probably going to remind me of New Orleans forever. Or at least til it runs out, at which point I'll need to go back.

I'm glad places like this exist.

Prime time wait is really long, especially when you just got off a 7-hour flight.
Off-times you can go sit right down.

Tim P. brought us here after talking it up for I don't know how long. Years, probably. 

You know how someone builds something up so much that it ends up being a bit disappointing? That was not the case at all here, Deanie's is FANTASTIC.
