The potatoes [served in place of the usual bread] were delicious, the food portions were ridiculous [Chad and I split a HALF mixed seafood platter and could only eat about half of it], everything was delicious, my daughter's BBQ shrimp pasta was so good, we came back to have it for our last meal before heading home, they have Abita Nitro on tap, and the service is SUPER. Oh and the salad that has the fig sauce on it -- get that. Super yum.

Had several locals recommend this place while we were waiting to get our tire changed last year. Good enough that we found it again when we came back down to SB this summer even though we didn't remember the name or quite where it was [Hollister is a really long street!]. Awesome service, homey decor, great food.

I'm giving Fifi Mahoney's five stars for:

a. Having the best window display in New Orleans.
b. Changing the window display twice during my short stay.

One of these I'm going to stop in and buy a wig.

Beautiful park. The cathedral is so white and the sky is so blue and the grass is so green and the flowers are so pink...it is one of the most picturesque places I've ever been. The mules and carriages lined up on the other side don't hurt, either.

Our friends swear there are hordes of adorable feral cats roaming around all night but we only saw a couple and a bunch of giant cockroaches.

There are usually a couple artists with their work up well into the night; weekends the entire perimeter is lined with them. Palmists are usually out, and you can often catch a parade [wedding times are posted on the front of the cathedral].

The New Orleans visitor center is off to the side, excellent place to stop in for some good tips, those folks really know their town.

Walk up behind the performance area across the street, the Mississippi and a nice riverfront walkway are right there.

My half po boy was two full sandwiches loaded with nice lean roast beef and the sloppiest gravy imaginable. Delicious.

Tried the intriguing neopolitan cheesecake. It has bits of that dried fruitcake fruit in it. Very pretty to photo, didn't like the taste so much, but I was in a food coma after the po boy so I wouldn't trust my judgment here.

The macaroni is pretty tasty, too.

I spent three hours walking around the French Quarter and CBD trying to find working wifi. Not even the Starbuxes have it. Someone pointed me down to Canal Place, et voila! Slow as molasses but you can check your email.

Looks pretty much like every other mall alive, except the food court upstairs, which is straight out of the stone ages but you can get a burger for $3.50 or so, which is about a tenth what you'll pay the second you step back outside.

Minus a star because the glass elevators don't go very far up. Lame.

This tour no longer lives in Algiers, it is across the river just west of the convention center.

We did not go on the tour but wandered around and saw all the big floats from this year's parade. Amazing, crazy stuff. Then someone told us we had to go on the tour if we wanted to wander around but we'd already seen everything at that point so we left. Oops.

Go on the tour, you want to see this stuff.

It looks like something out of Disneyland, except dirtier. There are lots of I don't know whats available if you need them though a lot of them are the same things I saw at other stores, just with jacked-up prices. I don't need any of it anyway.

No pictures allowed inside.

The best thing about the place was lady trannalicious voguing outside in the intersection mid-day -- my boyfriend gave her a hibiscus then ran off like a little boy.

Huge, wonderful selection.

Extremely huge, wonderful selection of charms, especially of the New Orleans locale type -- lots of streetcars and fleur de lys' and cathedrals etc. Wish I'd loaded up on more.

I loved this place and didn't get a chance to go back. We got the whatever the mixed sandwich is with the ham and debris and something else is called and potato salad -- they make it almost the consistency of mashed, which is exactly how I LOVE it -- and were full for days. Juicy and delicious, a bit high-end price-wise but worth it.

Gary's grilled shrimp po boy almost had me jumping over the table, it looked so good.

If you are more used to lighter-style cooking and overdosing on the deep-fried-in-ham style food that permeates New Orleans [not that I don't LOVE it, it was just a big adjustment for me], this is a good [though slight] change of pace, and an excellent break if you are spending the afternoon shopping on Magazine Street.

They have a lot of the same deep fried items offered everywhere else but have a couple of the lighter diner items I'm used to -- fresh steamed broccoli with my grilled chicken breast, a nice caeser salad. All very delicious. Their mashed potatoes were some of the best I've ever had [I am the #1 connoisseur of mashed potatoes, so I know] and service was good.

Ambience: Nice, airy space filled with local art. Weird claw machine with what looks like discarded Beanie Babies, not sure if it works...
This is an awesome, awesome shop. They have some of each kind of kitsch imaginable, and an excellent collection of iron-on-while-you-wait atypical New Orleans T-shirts.

Only saw one real artist selling his own stuff, everything else was china-made plastic manhole jewelry and ugly junk.

The only thing different from a regular swap meet was that no one was selling sweat socks.

We really enjoyed this place!  The service is outstanding and so friendly.  I had the halibut and it was cooked to perfection. My husband had the lamb stew and that was just ok.  He had had better.  The is such a cute place and family ran business.  We really enjoyed the atmosphere and the food!  Try it you won't be sorry.

First time eating here.  Two of us had the burgers and they were amazing.  The French fries are home made and delicious.  One person in our group had the chicken and waffles but did not like at all.  They basically give you a dry waffle with two dry chicken stops on top.  My husband had the Cubano and liked it.  Could use a dill pickle in it.  Service was good.

This steak house is amazing.  We shared a bone in ribeye and a add on small lobster tail!  The stark melted in your mouth. It was cooked to perfection!  The lobster was one of the best I have had. Sweet and delicious.  The potatoes that are pan fried with onions and gravy are quite amazing as well.  I am a baked potato person but these were better!  Ok enough about the food.....lets talk about the service.  We had Marcos as our waiter and he was point on!  Very helpful with us picking the right selection. He knew the menu well and guided us to perfection.  You won't be disappointed in eating here!  One of the best steakhouses I have ever eaten at.

Amazing place for dinner. Our night started with a reservation. When we arrived they did. It have a seat for us but the owner. I belle gave us all a glass of wine and got us a seat a short tome after that. The food was amazing. The service spectacular. Michelle is a gracious owner and treats all as though you were friends forever.  Love the place  and vibe. Great place. We will, be back. Got to meet the cook who is the owner as well. Nice people who love to please its customers.

Loved this place!  The staff was great and good amazing.  I was not impressed either table side guacamole however.  The chips tasted like out of a bag and the guacamole just ok. We had the fillet on a rock with lobster and that was great.  We also had appetizer calamari and it was amazing as well. Great view of water and good drinks.  We will be back for sure.

This place is recommended to us by the hotel. Not impressive whatsoever. I had the prime rib and it was flavorless. The presentation was not appealing.  The baked potato looked like it had been sitting for too long and tasted that way too.  The service was good so that was not the issue. It was mainly the food   I would never come back.

I have not eaten at an outback in a long time. We were visiting here in Boise and we thought OK let's try that outback. I felt like a steak. My daughter got a steak and it was the worst looking piece of meat I've ever encountered at an outback. It was very thin it wasn't really cooked well and it  was chewy. It was just a bad cut of meat. I decided to order the baby back ribs and I kid you not when I took a bite into them I've never had a rib that crunched like a pork rind but it crunched it was so dry and crunchy and crispy and Lathered-with a ton of barbecue sauce.  I've never had ribs that were so horrible. On a good note the salads we're good and what you would expect at Outback. The fresh vegetables were good what you would expect that in Outback.  The service was good and our server was very efficient and friendly. We didn't have the heart to tell him the food was lousy.  The one star is based on food on nothing food was lousy.

This place is simply amazing. Excellent Southern style food sir family-style. Be prepared to sit next to people that you don't now but I feel like that's what makes it a nice place to eat. Their fried chicken was to die for. The meatloaf was amazing. The green beans were super.  The service was excellent. The restaurant is inside of a historic mansion. So when you're done eating you can walk around and look inside the house. It's right by the airport so I we were done eating we set on a lawn chair and watch the planes land and take off and that was pretty fun. I highly recommend this place but come hungry.
Definitely not the best burger in Eagle. Far from it.  Service just ok.  We both had hamburgers.  Very doubtful I will be back.

Here visiting from out of town and this place was recommended to us. We found the food to just be ok.  Service mediocre.  I had the pot pie and it was bland. Priced high for what you get. We had seven in our party but no one raved about any of their meals.

Limited menu. They are in to sauces on everything but up front I will say I don't like too many sauces.  So I ordered a simple hamburger and ask for mayo and mustard and they brought me a hamburger with Ketchup.  Also I asked for plain fried and they served with rosemary.   I love French fries but theirs are dry and too much rosemary. I would not recommend this place. I will say the service was good and we had a very good and nice waitress.

I've always been a fan of Kimpton Properties - cute, boutique-like hotels in prime areas of major cities. Having stayed in a few, I've found some consistencies that I can rely on: lots of art deco accents, very friendly staff, smallish rooms, comfy beds and a complimentary wine hour in the lobby from 5-6pm. 

While I was disappointed that I couldn't check into my room until 4pm, I couldn't blame them for having a busy weekend...it just complicated my schedule a bit. The elevators are slower than snails...at one point I waited on the 20th floor with my suitcase for 15 minutes. I had finally picked up the phone to call the lobby when it finally arrived full to the brim with people and luggage. Eek. 

My room didn't have a refrigerator and the set up was a bit strange...long ziggy hallway and a tiny room area. I ended up bruising both shins trying to shimmy around the bed. The view was nice though and the L'Occitane bath products are always wonderful. 

Overall, Palomar is a lovely place to stay in Philly. Only a stones throw from Rittenhouse Square and smack dab in the center of fab shopping and restaurants, you probably won't be spending too much time in the hotel anyway!

Nestled into the end of a strip mall in Montecito, Sakana is a true hidden gem of the locals scene in Santa Barbara. Pulling up to this unassuming and intimate restaurant right next to a Vons, you'll find a dim-lit and charming interior boasting incredibly creative sushi with picture-perfect presentations. 

Like Nicolette Sheridan, this is what we call a sure thing.

First, the menu is huge. If you're a strict traditionalist then you'll be disappointed since their spin on sushi is quite novel; combining fish, textures and flavors in ways I had never before seen. We ordered the Surfer's roll...twice...maybe three times because every time it hit the table everyone began using their chopsticks as weapons of war. We went on to devour the Red Dragon and Montecito rolls with impatient precision. The ahi tuna appetizer is also worth noting. The sushi is served in press box form so you won't find any seaweed holding things together or impacting the overall taste. Every dish is positioned like artwork with splashes of colorful sauces striped across and as you eat and dip the image on the plate transforms. 

It's not cheap but it's also completely worth the price tag. Plus, they are cool with BYOB so our feast for four ended at under $40 each. For a bonus, see if you can convince your dining companion that the HD fish screen is actually a live feed of the tank in the back kitchen. The fish is fresh enough for it to be convincing...

I'm in Philly. I want cheesesteak. 

But with a limited time schedule and a requirement for credit cards accepted we took a crapshoot and went with Top Tomato for our work lunch delivery needs via GrubHub. 

And it was good. Really, friggin' good. My cheesesteak hoagie came with all the fixin's and despite the lack of Paesano's oomph, I scarfed that sucker down more than happily. Delivery was 15 minutes earlier than quoted and lunch for five landed under $50. Ain't nothin' wrong with that, son.

Is it sacreligious to say that the Philly cheesesteaks here were less than amazing? Perhaps I ordered wrong but then again, is that possible when you're ordering hunks of meat wedged between two oiled up halves of bread?

First off, provolone was an extra dollar which made me forget to order mine with provolone - lame. Then they didn't whiz our stuff like we had asked and PD had to go back for heaping cups of whiz for us to smear ourselves (free of charge thank you) along with hot sauce which didn't appear readily available (thought there were pickle slices galore). I ordered the meat with spinach which actually tasted a lot like meat and garlic bread...weird. The cheese fries were ok but Shake Shack's waffle fries easily kill Jrs. 

So needless to say I was underwhelmed. I love me a cheesesteak but I've had better from Jake's Steaks in San Francisco. Ok, now you 'delphians have at me!

Good place to catch a train if you're running late, great place to wait if you're running early.

Beautiful high ceilings and plenty of food options make this train terminal both quite functional and gorgeous at the same time. Unlike Penn Station (where I wait all too often) there is plenty of seating at 30th. The traffic at the front can get bad if your trying to get in or out during a rush or snow storm but ultimately you'll get in.

Coffee, tea, magazine or coffee. Despite the wait, the Philly folk at Amtrak will help you get where you need to go.

I love me some Philly. 

Sure, we've got gogo dancers here in NYC. And yea, we've got bacon mac 'n' cheese. But then again, I don't know where I can eat that and watch a bare ass jiggle and keep my appetite. Love the 60's inspired throwback dancers shakin' what their mama gave 'em on the lit stage blocks here. Throw in some awesome music, fans blowing everyone's hair back and it is instant music video time. 

And then I find out that drinks are $4 and I figure that I'll have to make a pilgrimage here at least every few months. Yep.

So good that in a short weekend trip for a wedding in Ventura I managed to visit D'Vine twice! 

A low key cafe complete with outdoor seating, a bookshelf of borrowed reads and friendly folks behind the counter; it was exactly what I needed when I was en route to my hotel. The D'Vine Wrap caught my eye and delivered an crucial combination of flavors: salami, turkey, lite ranch dressing, tomatoes, lettuce, cheese...all rolled tight in a spinach wrap. It lasted me through two light meals and was both healthy and satisfying -- not easy to do! 

When hunger hit the next AM I could only think of the speckled sunlight shining on the outdoor patio of D'Vine. A breakfast burrito and iced coffee later and I knew this was a winner. They'll have something for everyone; the worst part is that I can't bring them back with me to NYC -- along with the perfectly sunny weather!

With a 4-star showdown between my Philly phavorites Felicia D, Michelle C and Monica S ... I was shocked by the 3-star average on this über-hip Mex joint off Rittenhouse Square.

Formica countertops, wood paneling and all the other good stuff that makes up an old school side-of-the-road dinner is juxtaposed with a tasty, relatively authentic menu of Mexican eats available almost anytime (before midnight, that is). Full of twenty-somethings and hipsters, this is true Rittenhouse cool. The margaritas are solidly balanced and the eats are hands down delicious. The chips & guacamole is secretly pricey ($14??) but generally decent plate of food from the entree menu, won't run you much more than ten bucks. I noticed a pretty sweet 2-course lunch deal for $9.99 that I'd check out when I'm back in town. I can completely get behind the pollo verde enchilada that had me swooning, despite a late night lack of appetite. 

Sure, it's a little pretentious and gimmicky, but you've gotta appreciate the flair. And if you don't, then at least give a nod to the queso.

A classic surf and turf lunch spot right on the harbor is hard to beat. What makes Brophy Brothers a great choice is the laid back atmosphere, unpretentious style of the patrons and the inevitable feeling of relaxation that comes with a seat outside on a sunny Santa Barbara day. 

Since it's off the main strip it manages to evade the honeymooners, meat heads  and teen goth contingent of State Street. The menu is short and sweet loaded heavy with fresh shellfish options. The dungeness crab was good, as is the seafood linguini but don't expect anything genius coming from the kitchen. Same with the straightforward and simple approach to cocktails. A bloody Mary, oyster shooter and simple shot of tequila is about all you need from bartender.

Roll through for lunch and watch the boats rock in the harbor. It's hard not to have a good time here.

While I usually stay at the Palomar in Rittenhouse Square, I thought I'd work on my Starwood Preferred Guest status and go with Le Meridian on a recent work trip to Philly and it was not a bad pick. While the location isn't as ideal, it's still in a pretty metropolitan area and only 15 minutes from RS anyway. 

I can understand people's complaints about the lobby/entrance as it's set up rather awkwardly with a bar where the reservations desk would be normally when you walk in. A little bit of hunting around the corner and I was able to check-in and get set up with a room key. My room was nicely appointed, though lacking much of a view. The bed was very comfortable and all the electronics worked - though the $9.99/day wireless internet is predictably slow. I love having a coffee machine in the room and they delivered on this as well. 

I didn't get anything from room service or the restaurant, but I'd agree with other reviewers that it appeared pretty pricey. But then again, it is a hotel and I think overpriced food is almost expected. 

The layout of the hotel is interesting, and certainly wasn't built originally for this purpose. Like much of the architecture in Philly there is a modern/antique juxtaposition in the decor. Canopied ceilings with ergonomic chairs, heavy drapery and a slick headboard. But overall, it's incredibly comfortable.

Mister Softee is THE urban ice cream man. Sure, it's basic soft serve ice cream and no, the menu doesn't include wasabi pea dust or pumpkin butter (Oh how I yearn for you always BGICT) but when I'm standing on the street between an $8 cup of Grom gelato, a $5 popsicle from popbar and the $3 cone from the Mister Softee truck...something draws me to the truck. 

You can get plain vanilla or chocolate, chocolate or cherry dipped, sprinkles or one of 8 or so suburban flavors like the Astropop and creamsicle. I went with a root beer float last night and was pleasantly surprised and thankful he gave me the whole can to keep refilling as I devoured. 

I've never heard them play the tinkling music of my youthful summers in California, but when I see the Softee truck I can't help but smile with reverence for this vintage vehicle of sweet, creamy goodness.

Out of town for the month and was craving a pizza. I was staying at the Hilton Garden Inn near the airport and called this Papa John's around 10pm. They couldn't deliver my pizza because of a high robbery alert in the area.. well... :(

YEAAAAA found the best pizza in Houston!!! better than p1nks & r0man0s.

Customer service is bar none!

Granted people have their opinions of their favorite pizza and get all butt hurt if theirs isn't the best. So you just have to try it for yourself and be a ponzo fanatic too :)

Visited this bar during final 4 weekend. Decent bar, but this place is a total sausage fest. If you're looking to be around a good mix of guys and girls, this isn't the place to go. Service was prompt and courteous, can't complain otherwise!

Oh man, their reviews and the pictures don't do it justice: in a bad way! The pictures made it look better than it tasted. I wasn't a fan of their food. Tastes more like bad bar food. I was embarrassed to take my party of 4 here :(

We stopped in based on a tip from another shop (Junkee) and arrived 30 mins before closing looking for tiki mugs, vintage Hawaiian art and Bakelite. When we walked in a woman reminded us that they were to close in 30 minutes and showed me to the mugs which we either already had or were not interested in and a small rack of common colored Bakelite bangles; nothing special. We proceeded to look around and quickly realized that the woman was following us. It was uncomfortable. We did find s large piece of tapa on sale for $200 but by that time my we were so annoyed by the woman following us that we left without buying anything and still had 15 minutes to spare. Although the store is large and 3 stories, there's a lot of garbage that isn't antique and the way the staff treated us was enough to make me not want to come back. The Virginia Street Antique Mall is much better.
Great Tennessee wet ribs! I can't wait to go back. They also had live bands performing which made it fun.
Easy place to get on a ship but you do not need to take a cab if you are close the the Riverwalk .. just walk through and get on it is that easy ...

I think this place will be much better once they iron the kinks out and the newness wears off.  Right now the seating capacity is no where near the demand and they seem to rush everything to turn the tables over.  We ordered 2 pies and a salad.   They had everything come out at the same time so there was no flow to the meal. 

The pizza where good the crust was good but the escarole salad was terrible.   The dressing was flavorless,  the anchovies were old and had been opened for a while but the worst part was the greens.  Escarole salads need to be the younger greens or the hearts.  They server the main leaves which are tough and almost inedible.

Honestly was excited to find an iron chef place in Philly.  I knew I would have to wait to get in but that is something you are used to when it comes to "hot spot" eating.   There was over a 2 hour wait which is not great but still doable.  What was unacceptable was the hostess at the front.  She was flat out rude, could care less about the customer.   No I am sorry about the wait or have a drink at the bar or anything. She never even asked if we wanted to put our name in like most other places in the area.   Someone should coach her to tell her she works in the service industry.  

Shame just a pure shame this hostess is the experience she gives customers when they go there to have an Iron Chef experience.

Fun little downtown cafe for coffee, light lunch, or gelato. I enjoyed a house coffee (served in a ceramic cup, not paper) and Caprese sandwich. It was not small or giant, but was filling and fresh. The interior is fun with art hanging and an all important fire place. I'll add this spot to my 'when nearby next' list for sure.

I confess that I do not know Reno that well, but I am giving 5-stars because I am pretty sure I could not find a better lunch spot if I tried.  Further, this spot offers a great alternative to the casino fare, if you are visiting from out of town.  If you are local, I am certain you have been here on a lunch break a time or ten.

Three adults for $28.83, plus tip.  The food was fresh (a variety of soups prepared daily), the service was quick (despite a crowd) and everything tasted fantastic.  The place is small, so people share tables, but that can be fun.  We met some nice people.

Next time I am in Reno, I will certainly return.
These good people at National provide top notch service every time I'm there.  If there is an issue they get on top of it immediately.  I'll use them any chance I get!

Mark was very responsive and even called me back after 5 PM on a Friday.  He even walked me through (on the phone) what to purchase at Home Depot.  I definitely recommend Mark @ JB Plumbing.  He is responsive, on time, and gives a reasonable price quote along with his recommendations on parts.

After our meal at Pere Antoine's many we walked around the Quarter to get some souvenirs and gifts from our trip. Toulouse Royale isn't like some of the other shops in the Quarter.  The selection seems to be better displayed, better lit, and a more welcoming attitude when you walk in. It seemed to be a one-stop shop with clothing, cards, home decor, food, and Mardi Gras beads. 

I purchased a great t-shirt for $14, and a street car Christmas ornament for $7.  It's definitely for tourist, but surprisingly, the prices aren't as exorbitant as I would see in places like San Francisco or New York.

After eating a large meal at Commander's, we wanted a low-key, fun thing to do for the rest of the afternoon. The Audobon Insectarium came to mind since I had read that it recently opened in June 2008 and would probably be a cool thing to visit.  

Housed on Canal Street in the old Customs Building, the Insectarium offers displays of many live insects that are part of the ecosystem.  The uniqueness and variety of insects are the showcases of the exhibits.  There were bees, beetles, ants, cockroaches, a whole exhibit on termites (which are a big problem in Louisana), some baby alligators, a full room on moths and butterlies, and the best part of the museum:  a walk-in butterfly exhibit. 

Normally, insects scare the bejeezus out of me (I know, I'm a baby), but the Insectarium did an awesome job with displaying their uniqueness in both live, and mounted displays.  

Admission is $15/person, and is worthwhile time for both adults and kids.

This was the final stop to our eat-a-thon of New Orleans.  Located uptown, it is located right off the near end-of-line for the St. Charles streetcar and it literally drops you off right in front of the Camellia Grill. 

We arrived on a Monday morning and lucky for us, we were seated quickly at two seats.  There are no booths in this place--it's all counter which is nice and unique.  It definitely beckons to older, simpler times. 

I ordered a mushroom omelet, and dear Lord, I honestly have to say it was the most buttery, fluffy one that I have ever had before.  It was HUGE, too.  I know I should have been watching what I ate considering the previous days of eatin', but I couldn't resist.  They also don't give you the "home fries" that you might normally see at breakfast places--they just give you a pile of french fries.  The other half had a pecan waffle that was pretty damn good, too, and filled with, well, pecans. 

Service was fantastic, and our server was attentive and made small talk with us as we were looking over the menu.   We were seated next to two other folks that were in town from Boston and we both spoke of our culinary feats/experiences since we arrived in town. 

If you're uptown and need some good breakfast, good company, and good service Camellia Grill definitely should be the place you check.  Check your pretenses at the door, though, cause in a place like this, there's not much room for it.

After our swamp tour, the bus dropped us off in the Quarter, and we walked around to find a place to grab some lunch.  Since the Central Grocery was closed on Sundays, we stumbled upon Pere Antoine and decided it was a safe bet, and headed in. 

We were seated at a table right next to the entrance in one of the windows which gave us a great place for people watching. 

I ordered a half muffaletta sandwich that came with French Fries, and it pretty tasty.  I realize that it was late afternoon, but the fries weren't as crispy as I'd like 'em.  The sandwich was heavier on the olive side, but I enjoyed it as well.  

Service was good, and since we both ordered the same drink, they gave us the "leftovers" which worked out to a full hurricane glass size portion.  

Price-wise for food and drinks, including tax and tip, was $50.  A little on the pricey side, but for being in the heart of the Quarter, I guess it was ok.  

If I were in the area, I wouldn't necessarily seek it out, but worth a stop if you're hungry.

Maybe I'm a brave soul, but I don't mind eating off/at street vendors, and this was the same case as Lucky Dogs.  They are apparently a New Orleans/French Quarter institution and on several corners in the area.  

My other half got Krystal Burger that evening, and I went for the Lucky Dog.  When I approached, one of the vendors friends sized me up, and said, "You want a Lucky Dog with chili and mustard, don't you?".  Not knowing any better, I said, "Sure!  Sounds good!".  

The result was actually pretty decent, but I was surprised with the price at ~$6, and then the vendor asked for a tip.  Strange ... I'm not getting that much service and you expect a tip?  

Be careful if you get one with chili, cause they do put a bit on and can end up on your clothes.  Not like I'm saying that happened to me, or anything. ;-)

The St. Charles Streetcar offers one of the most picturesque views of St. Charles Avenue without having to worry about your car falling into a pothole--while you're inside, anyway.  We took the world's longest used street rail system from our hotel in the CBD down to eat at Commander's, and later on in our trip all the way down to Carrollton to eat at the Camellia Grill, and visit Loyola's campus.  

Prices have gone up a quarter to $1.50 each way, but is well worth the price to be able to see the beautiful mansions that line St. Charles. 

The cars come ~10-15 minutes during peak times, and are an absolute must if you visit New Orleans.  The cars are old school, but are effective and are wonderful reminders of times gone by.

5 FAT STARS for one of the best meals that I have ever had in my life.  We took the St. Charles Street Car and walked the few blocks to the restaurant.  The blue and white awning on the bluish color converted home has an inviting, Southern appeal to it.  Commander's is a dining experience not to be missed. 

Before our visit to New Orleans, we made reservations for 12:30 on a Saturday which worked out to be a Jazz Brunch which was a sort of prix fix meal with a beverage, a soup or salad, an entree, and dessert.  A jazz band wandered through the restaurant as we ate and played some nice jazz music that wasn't too loud, and created a nice ambiance. 

This is not your run-of-the-mill restaurant.  You have to dress-up in nicer clothes--no shorts are allowed.  I wore stuff that I would wear to work, but did notice that there were some younger folks that were wearing golf/polo shirts. 

Here are the selections that I made with the Jazz brunch:

-  Commander's Palace Bloody Mary with the southern twist of pickled okra, and topped off tableside with Finlandia vodka
-  Gumbo -- with oysters, shrimp
-  Eggs Cochon au Lait -  A sage buttermilk biscuit, "debris" pork, poached eggs with cracklin hollandaise sauce 
-  Creole Bread pudding souffle with warm whiskey sauce

I have to say everything was perfect.  Everything that was put in front of me, I devoured, and happily.  I was amazed at how they chose flavors that I never considered together, and it worked so perfectly.  

Now, to the piece de resistance of Commander's:  the service.  I have never in my life received such wonderful, almost perfect service.  They gave us adequate time to make selections, made suggestions when asked, made sure that we received each course of our meal at the same time--I mean exact, same time, and I would say that the room's six or seven servers each visited our table in some sort of way.  Commander's has this down to an art form, and it a wonderful thing to witness.  I even left the table for a moment to use the restroom, and when I returned, they had taken away my old napkin, and replaced it with a brand new one.  Attention to detail!  

This was a dining experience and very worthwhile to try when visiting New Orleans.  Be prepared to shell out some serious money to eat here, it, however, is really worth it.  You will be glad that you did!

I think that the ladies that work here must be nominated to be saints.  They deal with the drunken masses that come to their restaurant from the quarter and serve them these sliders and just stare at them and take their orders. 

They are knock-offs of White Castle burgers, but they certainly hit the spot. I got the #6 meal with 4 sliders burgers, an order of French fries, and a drink, and that was like $6.  They do sell the individual sliders for about $1.30/each, as well. 

They serve breakfast, as well, but they seemed a little scary, so we decided not to partake. 

Good place to grab something if you are within walking distance of the quarter.   It's far enough that you don't have to deal with too many of the masses, but close enough if you want to get your drink on after eating.

This was the first meal that we had on our eat-cation.  We took a five minute walk to Mother's from our hotel and walked-in (well, I did) prepared to get my eat on.  This place is similar to Philippe's in Los Angeles, but with a southern flare. 

If this is your first visit, I suggest that you get the Ferdi's special po boy that has debris (yes, that's what they call it)--the roast beef meat that falls off into the gravy and fully dressed with shredded cabbage, pickles, mayo, Creole mustard, and mustard.  It's like a French Dip sandwich, and it's pretty damn good!  Get the half size if you're eating by yourself, because it's easily a foot long even with the "half-size" and filled to the brim with fillings. 

We also ordered a cup of jambalaya to share between us.  It was slightly spicy but was filled with chicken, andaouille sausage, rice and whatever goodness they put into that little cup.  

I was hungry from a day of travelling, and wolfed down the po boy, AND finished off the jambalaya.  Needless to say, I slept very well that evening!

One thing is that you do need to know what you're doing when you walk-in, cause otherwise you hold-up the line.  Here are some pointers:

-  walk-in and grab a menu
-  fall in line
-  browse through the menu items as you make your way up
-  know what you want before they get to you
-  order from the cashier
-  sit down with your receipt in hand
-  someone from the restaurant will ask you for your receipt and will eventually bring the food out to you
-  if you order gumbo or jambalaya, they will serve it out from the counter you passed as you made it to order, go and grab it

After going back and forth between which hotel to stay at, we settled on the Intercontinental for our four day birthday celebration vacation.  Settled in the Central Business District (CBD) it's about a ten minute walk to Canal Street and the edge of the French Quarter, and within steps of a stop for the St. Charles Street Car line.  The hotel's location is nice so that you don't have to deal with the noise of the Quarter, and the drunks sharing the contents of their drinking adventures on your hotel's front step. 

We had a room on the 11th floor, and it was your basic hotel room, but looked like it had been at least updated recently.  There was a two-room bathroom:  one with the tub and the toilet, and another with the sink.  This is nice so that one person can take care of their business in one room, while the other uses the other.  As other Yelpers indicated, the prices in the mini-bar are outrageous, and a large bottle of Evian was a whopping $7!  Damn!  I just grabbed a bottle of water when I was in the Quarter from Walgreen's and lugged it back to our room. 

I didn't have the issue with the elevators when I was there.  In fact, when we pressed the button for the elevator it was there with a few seconds.   Maybe things had been fixed?  I don't know. 

I'm docking one star from the review because the check-in times are a bit odd and start at 4pm rather than the traditional 3pm.  I know that this is a result of having a 12 o'clock noon check-out time, but if you've flown 2000 miles across the country, and get to the hotel around 3, it would have been really nice if our room was available to relax.

The rooftop pool is nice, and open until 10pm each day.  One night, we grabbed some Krystal Burgers, and went up there to grub on 'em. Not really for doing laps, or anything, though, because it's fairly shallow, and not all that long. 

Overall, great experience staying at the Intercontinental.

I've been accused of having a big head before, and I resent that comment.  However, I literally have a big ole noggin that makes it difficult to find a hat that actually fits it.  The movie "So, I Married an Axe Murderer" comes to mind when I think about the size of my head when Mike Meyer's Scottish dad says "Well, that's a huge noggin. That's a virtual planetoid." about Meyer's brother, and finally yells "HEAD MOVE!".  Yeah, my head is shaped similarly and it's oh so hard to find a hat that fits.  

Having a shaved head, I need to be particularly careful to make sure that it's shaded from the elements, so finding a hat in my advancing years has become more important.  Living in the San Francisco Bay Area, I haven't come across too many stores that specialize in just hats.  In previous visits to New Orleans, we've walked pass Meyer the Hatter and never gone in.  This past trip, we finally decided to head in to check out their wares, and with any luck, find a hat in the process. 

They advertise themselves as the largest hat store in the South, and they aren't kidding.  This place has hats galore.  Some that are off the rack and you can actually try on right away without help, and some that are literally behind glass that the employees need to assist you to try them on.  The folks at the store are very helpful, and very accommodating and helped me find hats that, drum roll, please ... FIT.  

I walked out with two hats that are quite fashionable and while I spent more than I would normally on a hat (they were $55 a pop) I saw them as investment pieces that I know I'll use for years to come.  I also walked out with knowing what size of hat that I should buy (if I can find 'em).  

Customer service was great and the guy that helped us out went out of his way to try hats that would suit me, and gave great advice on how to pack and transport the hats back home.  Thanks, Meyer the Hatter for all your help!

A lot of good things have already been said about this place so I will keep this simple -- Yummy! Creative! Southern Comfort Food! 
I'm new to NOLA and this is already my favorite brunch place!

I HEART Bacchanal! Imagine if your best friend had a great backyard, the skills of a celebrity chef, had tons of musicians friends  and told you could come by whenever you liked and grab a plate of pure yumminess --- Got the image? OK, now THAT is Bacchanal. . . . Food there is always great (and SO MUCH cheaper than those restaurants that get som much hype)!!

The only reason this place isn't 5 stars is that I often find the layout awkward . . . even more so when it is crowded. You buy wine and cheese in the front . . . have to squeeze through table to get to the counter and place your order and pick it up. . . 

Still, all said, Bacchanal is WONDERFUL and my go-to favorite restaurant in NOLA!
Simply said: Yummy wine . . . Super friendly staff . . . Great location.

Just moved to New Orleans and felt SO happy to have found this store! Having just turned 30, I feel like I am done with veneers and make-do furniture. This place has cool and unique pieces and they are all HARDWOOD! The best part is the price -- very reasonable!

My guy and I had the 3 course lunch menu and (as other reviews mentioned) it was FABULOUS! I am a gal who knows pork (please avoid placing the obligatory dirty joke here. :) and the pork main (pork belly wrapped in crisp lettuce) that my boyfriend had was possibly the BEST piece of pork I've EVER HAD! . . . I had the shrimp and grits, which, while not equally as amazing, was yummy as well. Top that off with beignets for dessert that were melt in your mouth delish! 50 MILLION times better than Cafe Du Monde!
We shared a glass of the bacon bourbon. A big thank you to the waiter for recommending it. 

With the reasonably priced 3 course lunch and great food, this place is wonderful for a relaxing afternoon lunch date! . . . ENJOY!

If I was rating this restaurant purely on it's food, I would give it a 1.5. Add the high price and you get a very disappointed customer, i.e me. 

I chose Atchafalaya for Friday night date night because of a Groupon deal and some great Yelp reviews. Let me review the goo d and the bad of the evening:
The GOOD: 
- I made a reservation online and when we arrived there was no wait, our table was ready. 
- The signature cocktails were YUMMY!
- The atmosphere, dim lighting and music in the background, was romantic and prefect for a date or a night out with friends.
- The service was prompt and polite. 

Now if all of that had been topped off with great food, tis would have become a favorite for me . . .but sadly it was not to bed.

The BAD:
- To put it simply, the food just wasn't very good. The sauce on the seafood pasta was thin and weak. The crawfish stuffed flounder was pretty flavorless except for the sauce on the side. And the presentation was lack luster. 
- My boyfriend and I both were disappointed in our meals and we surprised at the elementary culinary mistakes that were made. 

To put it simply, there are a LOT of great restaurants in NOLA and this just isn't one. I have one Groupon left and I have heard brunch there isn't bad so I guess I will update this review when we try that in a couple of weeks.

We arrived late Saturday night a quarter past nine with a waiting time of about 20 minutes. Not too long a wait since we did have a large party, 7 in our group and not people before us in the waiting area. Along the wall are framed photos of people who have visited the establishment, some of you may or may not recognized. Seems that the restaurant is proud to have a certain POTUS dine in their place of business that they had a Plaque made for the very table and booth that he had sat at along with many framed photos and postcards drawn up with his picture.

Anyhow while we had waited, we had looked over the menu and already knew what we all had wanted by the time we were given our table. I ordered the Carne Seca Combo Plate # 6 which is shredded dried beef with rice, beans, and a large tortilla. This was amazingly sweet and savory. The One had gotten the Albondigas Soup and a Mango Margarita. The soup was good and tasty but the Mango Margarita was on point and almost smoothie-like. Another in our group had the Strawberry and she too enjoyed as much as well. Along with her Chorizo Con Huevos, Beans, Tortilla, Combo Plate # 9. This dish too was exceptionally scrumptious. Either combo plate I wouldn't mind ordering for myself. 

But the Carne Seca plate that I had ordered was so good, that my buddy had the same order and just devoured his plate before everyone else was even halfway thru theirs, myself included. 

Though Mexican restaurants can be found almost anywhere in the West Coast and the Southwest regions, only a few are worthy to be visited over and over again. When back in town I'll be sure to be back at "My Little Nest" and try their other plates.
Delish.... o(^-^)o

This is definitely a must see for those who truly enjoy the Holidays and all of its Seasons Joy. Such a wonderful happening for one neighborhood community to gather together and put such a marvelous show of display of bright lighting and shimmering decors for one and all to enjoy. Some of which are quite grand and extravagant while others are of simple yet joyful sights.

If you've never seen these dazzling array of christmas lighting and decorations, be aware that it does get quite crowded and be prepared to do a lot of walking to take in all the surroundings. Also unless you don't mind parking about half a mile to a mile away, just opt to pay for one of the many nearby parking options for $5.00. It after all a free community event on display by this wonderful neighborhood.

At one of the entrances ( we entered from E Prince Rd onto N Treat Ave ) you'll have volunteers handing out maps and various vendors and tents set up. There is also a trailer and cable trolley ride that you can pay for and just ride along through the neighborhood. But if you're walking, be wary of these trailers as they go by because they tend to be oblivious to pedestrians walking along the streets. 

As you walk, you will encounter an abundance of activities and goings on; a high school band performing songs on the front lawn of one home, carolers singing on a street corner, an area for children of all ages to write letters to Santa and hang on a tree, playing by the snow making machine, even though hardly any snow was coming out of it  o(^-^)o  and much much more. You'll even see several home owners just cozying up outside of their home or in their drive way around a metal fire pit and maybe roasting some marshmallows and have a warm beverage just watching all the revelers walking "THEIR" neighborhood. 

So get on your walking shoes, definitely get the stroller or wagon for the little ones, cash for vendors and beverages, take photos, and enjoy the holiday season.

I don't know what the hype is about this Dunkin Donuts. Maybe its because they don't have any in California, maybe we get to see all the commercials and advertisement and yet we can't go out to get them, maybe "its all just a conspiracy I tell ya" but whatever it is whenever the chance comes that we come across this place, The One always has to grab some Munchkins and coffee and of course I don't mind either and neither does the Lil Princess. ( as our friends look at us with perplexed faces, " We don't have a Dunkin Donuts in California" we tell them )

I do like the Munchkins, almost like donut holes similar in size and all but rather than just your average glazed donut hole, just as you would order an assortment of donuts, Munchkins also come in assorted varieties as well. Same texture as the donut version be it chocolate, glazed, powdered sugar, sprinkles, cocoa glazed, cinnamon glazed, jelly filled or what have you there's a Munchkin version.

Although I haven't tried any, they also serve muffins, bagels, cookies, breakfast sandwich's, bakery sandwich's, and wraps. As well as hot, cold, and iced beverages of your choice. Personally I take black coffee no cream no sugar, the bolder the better. 

Anyways, one of these days maybe I'll get around to trying their other items, but coffee and Munchkins sounds good right about now. 

So until they make it out to California.......

We called in an hour before coming in for brunch, and when we got here, we were seated right away. I really wanted to try the pumpkin waffles or the french toast, but I didn't think I could finish a plate of that, so I opted for something savory instead.

I went with the wild mushroom, asparagus, black truffle cheese scramble which came with a bread of your choice and salad. Oh man, when the plate came, I was debating what to do because I didn't realize that "wild mushrooms" are the mushrooms that I don't eat! I've only seen it in Asian dishes, and when my dad tries to give me some, I always refuse. But I decided to take a bite, and whadaya know? The mushrooms weren't super chewy like how they've always tasted to me, so it wasn't too bad! In fact, they were quite tender, so the dish ended up being okay. The salad and baguette were good. Oh and they have delicious homemade jam that we tried - yum! Banana bread was a little too cakey but dense at the same time, but it wasn't bad! 

The restaurant is cute, service is friendly, and the food is good! I'm sure if it weren't for the mushrooms, I would've enjoyed it more, so a solid 4 stars!

I came here last time I was in SB to try tandem biking for the first time, and it was fun!

It was really easy to rent the bikes, and the staff was friendly. No fuss - you sign some papers, take the bike out, and pay for it when you return.

My friend and I opted for an hour and we rode around the beach. They have some paths for you to follow, and an hour was good for us. We couldn't go that far, but we still got to bike around for a while. 

Besides bikes, they offer other options like surreys, choppers, scoot coups, so you can take your pick! :)

I came here with my friends after dinner, and we got a table and some drinks. The place was super colorful and brightly lit, and most of it was part of the outside patio. It was still pretty cozy though!

Our server was nice, but she disappeared for a while and we had to look for someone else when we wanted to order more. But other than that, the service was okay.

The one thing that I didn't like as much was that there were a handful of bachelorette parties going on. There was clashing music, girls hitting on random strangers, and etc. I mean it wasn't such a big deal that it bothered me much, but it was just a little odd. And if I were having a bachelorette party, I don't think I'd want to look over at the next table and see another bride-to-be with pretty much the same thing going on there.

"Blenders in the Grass" makes me think of lawnmowers or something of the sort, but having been there, I now think of delicious smoothies! 

I had the mocha blend, which was made with non-fat milk, coffee, chocolate, ice milk, and banana! Yummie! It was so smooth and creamy without being overwhelmingly thick or sweet! The banana added a nice touch too. I also tried some of the Red Banana, which was really tasty too. No need to even compare it to Jamba or other places because this is on another level! You can also add supplements to your drink, and they have a wide selection to choose from. Each drink runs about $5, but they're huge! More than enough to split with a friend. :)

Yum!

I wanted to order one of the sandwiches, but since they're known for their burgers, I decided to do it right.

Thus, I ordered the BBQ Bacon Charburger at the window and grabbed one of the tables in their outdoor seating area. (It's outdoor seating only btw!) Reminded me very much of 3rd street promenade in Santa Monica.

I was so hungry that I devoured that burger when it came out! Well, half-devoured, half-savored. There was an ample amount of crispy bacon and tangy bbq sauce (and lettuce), and they tasted perfect with the charred beef! Yes, it's charrgrilled, but it's not like it's overdone or burnt, so you can appreciate the flavor. Some people complained about their burgers being dry, but mine wasn't at all - probably because I ordered the bbq one. The burger itself was a good size - I was stuffed.

If you're in the area looking for something fast, cheap, or just plain good, I'd totally recommend The Habit! :)

I was in SB the other day with my friend, and we were going to try Brophy Bros, but the wait was just too long and we were starving!

So we decided to phone in orders to Opal and take it to go. My friend ordered the stuffed chicken with mushrooms, while I mulled over the menu. Nothing seemed to jump out at me, and then I remembered they had daily specials. I looked at it, and I knew what I wanted - homemade grilled filet mignon pizza with fresh pesto, wild mushrooms, tomatoes, smoked mozzarella cheese, and sliced avocado. Tell me that doesn't sound good! And it was $15! Most things on the menu ranged from $15-30, so it seemed like a steal.

We placed our orders and picked them up in 20 minutes. The staff was really sweet. On the phone, they asked us if we needed utensils and such, and they gave us complimentary bread too! 

The pizza was pretty bomb. Actually, my friend suggested eating at a pizzeria earlier that day, but I didn't feel like eating pizza. But I just had to order this pizza because it sounded so good, and it was! The dough was a little chewier than normal, but the filet mignon was delicious, as were the other toppings. 

The chicken was good and succulent, but it was too bland. If the flavors were stronger, then the dish would've tasted a lot better.

Still, I'd recommend this restaurant. But I do have to warn you that if you dine in, it's super loud in there! You'll probably have to yell, but other than that, it's nice and the staff is friendly.

If you're looking for a quick and mostly easy hike, this could be the one!

I hiked this with my friend, and we didn't have much time before sundown, so we were racing to get to the top. We almost turned back, but we trudged on and made it to the Montecito overlook in time before the sun set! It was only about 1.5 mi up to get there, and you see a nice overview of the city and the ocean. A few steep parts but not bad, and there were lots of trees for shade. 

Another review says there's poison oak, but I wasn't aware of this and did the hike in shorts and was okay. But now that you've been warned, you might not want to take your chances!

I heard some good things about this place before coming, so I was excited to try it (+ it was going to be paid for! :D)

They only take reservations for 5:30, but after that, you just wait in line. We got there around 7pm on a Saturday, and there was a good-sized line, but it moved pretty quickly. They had a band outside that entertains you while you wait, and they sometimes even pass out instruments for you to play along with! The music took me right to the New Orleans Square in Disneyland (closest thing I've been to the real place). :)

After we were seated, we were served some warm cornbread muffins with all sorts of different flavors (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/edJoBsse6nsF0BYh6pATAg?select=vQ-V9CfzT5e9aWoZx32jOg). Good, but not mind-blowing. I tried some of the cajun martini, which was really interesting. It's marinated with jalepenos, which makes it spicy! It definitely had a kick, but I wouldn't be able to finish the jar they give you on my own (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/edJoBsse6nsF0BYh6pATAg?select=vqGfTXwV9Od4uXyD7AhG1w). We then ordered our food, and I had a hard time deciding between the jambalaya  and the paneed veal acadiana, but ended up going with the latter since everyone else seemed to be ordering jambalaya. It was basically fettuccine topped with veal medallions and crawfish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/edJoBsse6nsF0BYh6pATAg?select=_Ues0mzPY88ObCR3STU9TA) The crawfish was really good! The veal was decent, but not that flavorful or tender. The alfredo sauce was really creamy but a little bland as well. The oyster sherry cream sauce was good though. I'd give it a 3.5. The jambalaya was pretty good, both the dirty rice and the penne version (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/edJoBsse6nsF0BYh6pATAg?select=xYB4vwPiFhxMHS0ctdpTig). And word of advice to the guys, you might want to order "huge" because the boys in our group ordered "large," which is actually a pretty standard size and they were still a little hungry.

The 2 things that really stood out though was the dessert and the atmosphere. For dessert, try the Louisiana Bread Pudding Souffle. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/edJoBsse6nsF0BYh6pATAg?select=7GAUV8Yz1YIIkIhxI8S4xQ) It was sooo good! We tried both the chocolate souffle and the bread pudding one, but I liked the bread pudding one a lot better. It came out hot with a cool Grand Marnier whiskey cream sauce that you pour over it, and it was the perfect blend of hot and cold and sweet! As for the atmosphere, it was great! The servers were really friendly and the crowd was lively, which makes it kind of loud in there, but it's fun! And during the middle of your dinner, they bring out these song books and when the music starts, everyone sings along and all the servers come out to clink glasses!

For $5, you can get ... 4 small greasy items off a dollar menu + tax at a fast food joint, parking in LA, or maybe a beer during happy hour. 

Not too impressive.

BUT if you come to Santa Barbara winery, you can wine taste for just $5! That includes 6 tastings, a wine glass, and some crackers to cleanse your palate. This is definitely a steal! If you're around, I don't see why you WOULDN'T come, unless you're allergic to wine.

The tastings included 3 whites and 3 reds. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uBvHmZ7BMT8JW5kxgimPWg?select=E3YK7Zc7lRIOen3pY6kTZA) The room was crowded, and you have to wait for spots around the counter to open up, and then you swoop in. My friends and I were a semi-big group, but they accommodated us well. The servers were friendly, but they mostly just poured and left us alone. I wished they explained more since I don't know too much about wine. However, when we started asking questions, our main server was quick to answer us, and we even had a few extra tastings thrown in! And for people who really like what they taste, they sell by the bottle or case.

So if you're in SB trying to decide what to do, give this place a visit! :) And if you're still feeling okay, there are plenty of other wine tasting spots in the vicinity!

Ribs are amazing!!!!
Like orgasmic, dream inducing, crave worthy delicious.

Everything else is just OK. 
Potato salad was  acceptable
Green beans were bad
Fried. Corn was OK
Beef brisket was mediocre

Ribs were amazing. Go here for the ribs and everything else is bonus.

I took my parents here for their anniversary dinner.

The entrees were AMAZING!!!  Two people had filet mignon dishes and were out of this world. The pasta was perfectly al dente and the sauces were perfection. 

They lost a star for two reasons:
1) the appetizers were not good.  The bruschetta was bland and soggy and the toasted ravs had little flavor
2) the server couldn't have cared less about us. 

One thing to note: the bussers were super friendly and on their game.  They made up for the crappy server.  They should promote them to server.

On a side note: why are all the servers white and the bussers black?  Makes me feel like Paula Deen runs this place. Step it up St Louis, it is 2013. 

So, skip the appetizers, order the filet and pasta and tip the bussers.

I am not sure what the big deal about this place is. The pies are huge?
Is that the big thing?  Cause if so, it's not worth the drive.  Just eat two pieces of regular pie stacked on top of each other. 

The food is solid, nothing special. It's a country kitchen for sure. But I have been to better country kitchens. And I have been to worse.

The poppy seed dressing was a standout weirdly enough. My family all liked their food, but no one was totally in love. 

Overall, a MEH experience

It's the best. I make a pilgrimage for Los Angeles at least once a year for this.

Amazing.
This is affordable decent Chinese food.  Nothing special, but everything is done well and the food arrives hot and the order is accurate.

This place is not great. 

We were stuck in a table under the stairs, the hot pink wall combined with a too strong chandelier, left us feeling like we were dining in a soviet interrogation room. 

The server took forever to come over for the first time.  I think they forgot about us since we were hidden.

The teriyaki was good as was the sushi, the rest was just plain. 

Menu is weird mix of Asian food.  Not exactly sure what they are going for.  

But the kicker for me was the prices.  WAY overpriced for the quality. 

I would not go back.

I came here with my friend as his guest and I was blown away. Literally.  The fans are HUGE!

The gym was clean and the air flow from those giant fans made working out a cool experience. 

Memberships prices are reasonable and everything is brand new. 

A+

Wow!  What a fantastic facility. 

I went there to workout and was totally impressed with the equipment.  There is plenty of it and it is all brand new and state of the art.

While I did not swim, the pools both looked amazing. I was kind of disappointed that I did to bring my suit, because the indoor pool looked so cool

The staff was super friendly and the exercise area was spotless, cool and smelled clean. 

I love this gym.

Fun fun fun

Ferris wheel 11 stories in the air? Check
10 story slide? Check
Giant praying mantis? Check

What more do you need for a fun day?  Booze?  Check!

All in all had a great time.

Went on girls night out here this past Tuesday and there isn't much to say about this place but just mediocre.  Its a fairly narrow restaurant with a pub like feeling.  There were four of us and they seated us at a fairly small table with hardly any wiggle room.  The servers wear white lab coats which remind me of medical students instead of wait staff.  It would be nicer if they used real linen napkins instead of raggedy kitchen rags.  Besides that the food was ah.. I've had better.  We started off with the assiette De charcuterie which is an assortment of the pate.  It was very good and out of all of the 4 pates my favorite was the rabbit and the condiments were also delicious.  For entrees we had the moules-frites (mussels with french fries basically) which was a large serving for dinner, entrecÔte grillÉe et frites (grilled rib eye steak with fries), jÄgerschnitZel (panned veal ) and the ÉtouffÉe of blue crab & brown shrimp.  The food was nothing spectacular but truthfully I think Besh's restaurants are overrated since I've never had a memorable dinner at any of them. So will I be back, probably not.

A true HIDDEN GEM on the Westbank! A Catholic Charity program Only open Monday thru Friday during lunch time.  Food is fantastic and you can't help but love what the program stands for.  We ordered the shrimp salad with a chili lime vigarette which was refreshing and light.  The roasted chicken with root vegetables was also delicious and well cooked.  Great hidden gem for lunch!

I've put off getting a hair cut for at least 6 months because I was weary of trying anyone new. I finally decided it was time to take the plunge and searched around here on Yelp only to find this amazing salon. Without a doubt, they deserve their 5 star rating. Everything was completely painless, from the phone call to make the appointment to the time I paid and went on my way. 

I saw Sarah and told her about my haircut anxiety. She and I went over what I liked and didn't like and she went to work. She's easy to talk to and she did an AMAZING job on my hair. Having waited such a long time between cuts, my hair was a total disaster. I begged her not to cut it all off and she did her best to save what she could. She compromised with me and cut off the split ends and gave me a mask to treat the left over dryer ends. My hair looks and feels amazing without much loss and I honestly couldn't be happier. 

Sarah at Underground Hair will be the only place I go for a great haircut. And now, thankfully, I won't need to put it off for months anymore. Nothing beats a great looking haircut!

I find it kind of funny how I find myself missing this place when I never found it entirely delicious when I lived in SB. Perhaps its just the memories of my 8 friends and I weekly gathering along the long sushi bar after a long 6 hour class at Brooks... Or perhaps it was the half-price weekday lunch special that kept our wallets AND our stomachs pleased. The fish wasn't always daily fresh and the rolls could never be compared to Edomasa but the service was decent and the food usually hit the spot. For poor, hungry college students, something fishy is a great lunch spot.

This place is decent. I prefer it over super cucas down the street but it's still not my first choice. The menu isn't very extensive and the chicken is cut in too large of chunks for my liking but the food as a whole is pretty good. Service is a little slow, I usually have plenty of time to meander over to Blenders and finish 1/3 of it before my food is ready but I do love the patio area. So over all, Mexican Fresh is pretty good for the Mesa area.

I can't believe I haven't given Arigato a review yet. I LOVE them! The food is always amazing and everyone that works there is very friendly. I love the vibe and most importantly the food... We always start off with some woked edamame which is simply amazing. Best edamame you'll find here in Santa Barbara. 

My boyfriend and I do our best to beat the crowds and rarely have to wait for a table. The trick is to get there between 5:30 and 7. Otherwise you'll find yourself waiting outside for a while but they take your cell number down so you can walk down state street and do some window shopping while you wait. Every restaurant should do this! 

Aside from the hefty prices, Arigato is the best sushi place around. Oh and if you haven't tried it yet, you MUST get the green godzilla for desert.  Sooo good.

Edomasa is a dream come true. While the menu prices might be a tad high for college students, the food and the service make it all worthwhile. The atmosphere is cute and cozy and the staff are all SUPER friendly. My ex-boyfriend used to crave Edomasa constantly so we found ourselves here at all the odd hours, especially at 1am which was always full of smiling faces. Not only is their fish always fresh, but the rolls are HUGE and especially delicious. Everything they serve is fantastic so no matter what, you'll leave completely satisfied.

Didn't have anything here but a Bloody Mary, and it was DELICIOUS (it better be for $10...). Their vodka soaks all the garnishes (pearl onions, pickled green beans, olives). Makes a world of difference. Spicy, tomatoey....it will rock your face off.

There's few things I hate more than a bad Bloody Mary but this one did not disappoint. Yum.

5 stars all the way. Even with the crowd. But a crowd usually  means it's good, right?

Mazzaros is huge Italian market in one of the most unexpected places in Florida, I mean really, St. Petersburg?

You can get pretty much get anything here; huge raw meat case where you can get anything from beef tongue to swordfish steaks. Next you'll come to the frozen foods case, don't pass this one up! You can find their homemade lasagna , cannoli cream, and some other frozen, homemade, Italian fare. Some of the best lasagna I've ever had, great to grab and heat up for a crowd.

After the frozen case you'll pass the wine and cheese room. Enormous wine selection and they make their own mozzarella. I always grab some every time I pass through!

The final, and largest area has the coffee bar, dessert case, deli counter, and market area. The sandwiches at the deli are all AMAZING, not to mention super affordable. Just had an ahi tuna sandwich with wasabi mayo recently. GREAT. There is also a large selection of prepared deli items, but frankly it's always so crowded in there it feels rude to crowd up to front and browse......maybe another time.

The dessert case is also enormous, one stand out I can remember is the cannoli cake, which I thought just had a canolli on top. WRONG, it has canolli cream LAYERS. Seriously, when I get married, this is what is going in the layers of my wedding cake.

Every time I come here I always bring an ice chest; so I can take some Mazzaros goodness all the way back to Gainesville.

Awesome! Only would have been better with an additional bathroom/drink break.

Our tour guide was knowledgeable and told the ghost stories without being overly dramatic, giving them a more realistic feel. The history on the tour is great. I've been on many ghost tours throughout the country, and this was by far, my favorite. 

With a "pay what you feel" policy, this tour is a no brainer! 

Although, I'm sure at the end of the tour, you'll have no qualms paying the tour guide an ample sum :)

I wish they were in every city!

What a good find! We came in to Fiorella's one night just before closing (yes, we were those people, sorry), after trying to go to Mojo's and finding out that they were out of a lot of things. Mojo's also didn't seem too keen on a group of 9 people walking in 15 mins before closing, for which I totally don't blame them, but this made us take a walk next door.

The waitress seated us and took a little while to get to us, which is fine since she was the only one working. She was quite patient with us and we didn't feel too rushed. Ordered some beers and put in our food order, I don't remember the food taking an especially long time, but they do have a sign on the wall to be patient as they make most of it fresh. 

It has an interesting mix of Italian and Cajun, but Cajun is a mish mash in of itself, so why not cajun and Italian? I got the meatball po boy (which was basically a meatball sub with crispy po boy bread), and it really hit the spot. Could definitely tell it was made in house and with a lot of love. Fries reminded me of checkers fries, but crispier, which is a big compliment since I love Checker's fries! My boyfriend got the crab and corn bisque...so good! We were both practically licking the bowl. I think they put sherry in it, which is almost always a good call for seafood bisque. Also served a thick slice of toasted Italian bread on top, which was a nice touch. 

Definitely bookmarking this one, so glad we decided to go in!

This may have been my favorite meal the entire weekend I was in NOLA.

My cousin and I came in to grab a quick lunch. We both ordered the fried green tomato and shrimp Po boy, with a side salad. They make almost all their dressings in house, and I ordered the charred onion vinaigrette. 

Everything was fabulous. The Po boy wasn't greasy at all; the shrimp were fresh and the accompanying sauces were a great addition. The dressing on the side salad awesome. It had a great char flavor, which I found to be really unique for a salad dressing. 

This is an easy place to miss, but my advice is, don't pass it up!

Such fun! The bar is located inside the gorgeous Monteleone hotel. It's pretty much exactly what it sounds like; the bar is a carousel! Seats about thirty people, you revolve slowly while the bartenders in the middle remain stationary (don't worry, they were great at remembering who ordered what). Takes about 15 mins for a complete revolution. 

The bar has more seating than at just the carousel, so if you can't get a seat at the bar, you can hang out and wait for one to open up. The drinks are a little pricey, but the bartenders are great, and the experience is just too fun. A must see!

Definitely a must stop for any foodie! 

This was my first visit, but as I was told by others, the place recently expanded their dining area, including the addition of a full bar. 

I ordered the Moroccan spiced lamb, a side of coleslaw, and a bacon praline. 

The pita was sooooo delicious. The meat was tender and thinly sliced, with a nice slow heat. It was topped with cucumbers and yogurt sauce, a nice balance to the hear of the meat. It wasn't a very big pita, but I found it to be satisfying enough. The coleslaw was pretty standard, kind of hard to mess up coleslaw. 

I saved the bacon praline for the plane ride home, and it was finger licking good. I could tell that my fellow passengers were pretty envious. Or they hated the bacon smell. Whatever. I was hungry! A little more gooey and soft than a regular praline, but manageable to eat with your hands. I was worried that the bacon flavor wouldn't be strong enough, but it had nice sized pieces of bacon scattered throughout. A perfect balance of sweet and smokey.

Really, my only complaint is the price. For everything I got, plus a soda, the total was $21. Yikes! The food was delicious though, so the price won't keep me from returning, but if I lived there I might not be a regular.

I have really mixed feelings about the coffee pot....

To start, their A/C (if they have any at all) is terrible. I find this to be pretty unacceptable in the South! 

I ordered a Bloody Mary and it was just meh. The garnish was two string beans and nothing else. No olives...no lime or lemon. The drink itself was pretty bland. 

To eat, I ordered the New Orleans sampler; the red beans and rice were just ok, but the other two were so delicious. I believe they were a crab soup and a gumbo. Flavorful and just the right amount of heat. 

Others in our party ordered traditional breakfast fare, and it was clear that they were all a little disappointed, especially with the portion size and the price. 

Our server was very sweet and she even sang a gospel song to the bride in our Bachelerotte party, which was a very cool experience. 

All in all, it wasn't a bad meal, and some of my food was quite good, but given that you're in NOLA, you can most certainly do better.

An overall very good experience; I would say 3.5, rounding up to 4 stars.

Service: I thought for a large party, we were very well taken care of. Service was attentive and there was always someone checking on us.

One of the biggest reasons that I wouldn't give 4 stars is the salsa and the black bean dip. They kind of make a big deal about the black bean dip and salsa bar, and I found both to be kind of disappointing. The "black bean dip" honestly just tasted like puréed black beans. Very bland. So I decide to use some salsa to liven it up a bit.....unfortunately the salsa was rather bland too. 

Fortunately, the other food we ordered was very good! The menu has a wide array of offerings, but I didn't find it too overwhelming like some Mexican restaurants can be. I ordered the bacon and shrimp tacos, and oh man! Heaven! The shrimp were cooked well and topped with a delicious chipotle sauce, white cheese (is it feta?), and two big strips of bacon. So YUMMY. The other entrees looked quite good as well! 

I'm not from the area, but I would return if I ever found myself there again....I know I'll be craving those tacos!

I was really torn on whether to rate 3 or 4 stars. Really liked the spaciousness of the room, the lobby/bar, staff, and location. 

But the drop off situation was a nightmare. Noise from bourbon was a bit of a downside but was expected due to the location. Front desk will provide ear plugs.  Shower was pretty close to breaking (had to turn it all the way on to get any water out). As others have said, I think the hotel is just in need of some renovations. But for the price and location, really can't be beat. I mean the La Quinta charges more and they're on the other side of canal.

Staff was very friendly and accommodating. I would consider staying again if I had a large group with me. As I said, the suite was quite spacious and that isn't easy to find at an affordable price. Otherwise I might try to find a more updated hotel.

Imo's. If you've ever been to St. Louis or just known someone from there, you've heard this name, probably repeatedly and maybe even in a trance-like manner. What is it?

Gobs of provel (no, not provolone) cheese on a cracker-thin crust. Doesn't sound so appealing, does it?

Oh, but it is. Cheesy, gooey goodness that will almost certainly attach itself to the roof of your mouth. But, 'tis worth it.

So. Make like a local St. Louisan and get yourself some Imo's!

Like most mornings, yesterday's started with a shower and an amateur blow-out (by yours truly). I intended to go over it with a flat iron after walking the Quarter and returning to my hotel as it was an especially humid day. However - after getting dumped on by a scattered shower, I couldn't bear starting completely over with another blow-out.

Enter Paris Parker. They got me in immediately - within minutes, I was sitting in Jonathan's chair, gabbing aways about everything from The Housewives of New Jersey (Teresa's hairline is crazy!) to his buttery blond highlights. Within 45 minutes, my thick tresses had been coaxed into something that resembled a behaving head of hair. While I have had better blow-outs (could have been a bit smoother with some additional round brush tension), this one was really solid especially considering the cost: only $25!

Next, I had my brows ($12) meticulously waxed, shaped and plucked. Inside of an hour, I felt like a new woman. I definitely recommend the Paris Parker for your own beauty emergency!

Holy moly, Milagro's street corn is off the chain! Yes, it's only a side ($1 upgrade with tacos) but if the street corn were offered as an appetizer, I think I'd order only that with a house salad. Their take on street corn is basically elote that's been removed from the husk... it's so much easier to eat it this way! And it's full of that smoky signature flavor along with crumbled cheese and mayo (or perhaps crema). In any case, it's a DO NOT miss dish!

Besides the street corn, I found everything else more than passable but not outstanding. The fish tacos on housemade corn tortillas were good, but not memorable. And I'd recommend eating inside instead of on the patio unless you enjoy gazing at a parking lot.

Next time I'm there, I'll try a margarita or horchata martini (WHAT) as I hear Milagro's cocktail program is quite solid. With some street corn on the side, of course!

I've been going to Grant's Farm since I was an itty bitty with my siblings. What's changed? Not much, except now I'm the grown-up along for the ride with my nieces and nephew... and it's still every bit as fun.

Over Memorial Day weekend, we made the mistake of arriving a few hours after the park opened and ended up aborting our mission as the line for the tram looked to be an hour along. Two days later, we came back right when they opened and breezed through the line. The early bird really does get the worm!

The 'farm' is less country and more like a zoo - except a much smaller, easy-to-navigate version of the zoo. Parrots, camels, cows, zebras, ostriches and even baby goats which you can feed with a bottle live here. And if I'm craving a misty-eyed moment with my hometown, I can go and see the Anheuser-Busch famous Clydesdales. Aww: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wPG7PcI67dE

Besides all the ooh-ing and ahh-ing over baby animals, my favorite part of the Grant's Park experience is the biergarten. There, you can indulge in childhood snacks and adult refreshments alike: sno cones, funnel cakes, warm pretzels and beer. Every 21+ patron of the park receives TWO free beers, with a choice from A-B favorites like Budweiser, Bud Light and even Shock Top.  I tried to tip one of the beer pourers and he refused, informing me that gratuity is not accepted. Wow!

So, to reiterate the basics:
- Arrive early.
- Pet cute animals.
- Pay $12 admission fee per car, no matter how many people are with you.
- Each adult in your party gets two free beers - no tickets, just a tried-and-true honor system.
