How can you not mist over in nostalgia for one of the most wholesome and pure experiences you and your little loved ones can have? Nothing but love for a true local gem - St. Louis pride!

When I'm back home for short stints in the StL, I'm often spending time catching up with old friends that I haven't seen since the Christmas prior. Now that I'm a bit more grown up (*cough*), I prefer wine over Red Bull & vodka and an easygoing wine bar over a Washington Ave. club. 

And Robust Wine Bar is exactly my speed - there's enough of a 'scene' so you still feel like you're sneaking in a bit of nightlife, but it isn't too crammed, too loud or too boring. Really, it's just right.

Because I'm equal parts indecisive and adventurous, I usually go for the wine flights when imbibing at a wine bar. For $12 to $20 (depending on your selection), you'll be greeted with three generous pours. As my friend and I came to Robust specifically for the purpose of planning our upcoming trip to Spain, we of course HAD to choose the 'Run with the Bulls' flight - replete with a Grenache/Syrah blend, a Mencia, and a Tempranillo. All three picks were solid, but the beautifully complicated Tempranillo warranted a full pour after we finished our initial flights.

Naturally, some food was involved, too. The bartender helped us select a cheese sampler and we also tried the olive oil-poached shrimp (decadently delicious) and the Robust olives (served with roasted garlic, feta and artisan bread). Magnifique!

I'm digging what you're throwing down, Robust - I'll definitely be back for some wine, good grub and chit-chat!

Once a year, I go to Starbuck's specifically for heart attack in a grande cup, aka their seasonal egg nog latte. It's the kind of treat that begs you NOT to look up the nutritional information... no no, I'd rather turn a blind eye. But is it good? So good I woke up thinking about it.

This particular Starbuck's is very spacious, with lots of room for lounging, hanging out with friends and working. The baristas are fast - with so much traffic, they really run this place like a well-oiled machine. Always a stop for me when I'm near my aunt and uncle's house in the Lou!

Dive bar rating: An 8. Translation? Pretty damn dive-y.

They're open from 6am until 3am every day of the week. And no, they don't serve food. Cash only, too! All the components of a 'true' dive bar.

The drinks are cheap and the insides are very, very smoky. Why come here? Again, it's a 3am neighborhood bar. And when you don't feel like venturing downtown, spots like the Trophy Room are a viable option for continuing the debauchery. Others have the same idea, so it's usually packed!

Accessories include a pool table and a jukebox. Really, is there anything else you need as closing time approaches? I think not.

Thanks, Courtesy Diner, for serving all of us professional partiers 24/7 all these years... and by professional I mean this: People who wish to avoid the morning-after hangover know to eat before hittin' the hay!

So, the menu isn't that exciting. Cheese sauce and its plebian cousin, American cheese, make prolific appearances. But, what they do well are slingers (a St. Louis original consisting of eggs, cheese, onions, optional chili and hash browns all atop a hamburger patty). Can't say that I've had this potential coronary in recent years, but their standard cheeseburger will also do you just fine. And, they have crinkle fries! There's just something about that added texture.

By far, the best part about spending an hour at the Courtesy Diner is the scenery. Ah, what a vibrant picture of local shenanigans swearing, laughing and trying hard to keep from falling asleep in their selected pile o' grease. You have to give the servers major props for providing such a valuable service to the community. Long live Courtesy Diner!

Cash only kids, but they do have an ATM. However, the other night it was out-of-service though the gas station across the street has one too.

After seeing some Chicago band friends perform a nearby gig, we decided O'Connell's would be the perfect host for continued debauchery in its most primitive form. And you know what? The beer selection is terrible. The burgers? Greasy as hell. The furniture is old, the floors are sticky and the late night crowd was rowdy, smelled of eau de Camel Lights and swore like a bunch of drunken sailors.

Somehow - it all worked! Come to O'Connell's if you're looking for good ol'-fashioned tomfoolery in a no-nonsense, classic Irish dive bar environment but skip it if it's couture cocktails and craft beer you're after. 

Words to the wise:
- If you attempt to split a tab, the bartender may just bark that what you're trying to do is 'too complicated'. 
- Don't set your beer on the bevelled edge of the bar. It will topple over! #itwasntme #okayitwas
- The Jameson shots are very large. As in, obscenely large.
- And most important, they sell 6-packs of crappy beer to go for $8.50 a sixer up until closing time. Ahh, that's why I have an additional $17 charge from O'Connell's showing up in my recent bank account activity!

Can't wait for a reason to come back. Long live O'Connell's!

Lately, I've been staying at Starwood properties almost exclusively. The goal? Platinum status and a mad accumulation of points so I can a.) "upgrade to best available room at check-in, including Standard Suites" (per their website) and b.) cash in on free hotel stays during my next vacation. Additionally, I usually go Starwood because the properties please, the rates work well with my budget and if not, I can turn to one of my besties (a Starwood concierge) for her Starfriend rate hook-up. 

And so far, I've been a happy camper... mostly. From my favorite Starwood property (the W South Beach) to one I've bookmarked for a future visit (W Paris!), I don't ever feel like I'm chancing satisfaction with the W brand. It's a solid marriage of consistency and that inimitable jet-set meets kitschy W 'glamour'... and when you return to home base at the end of an evening, the opportunity for more trouble always awaits in the lobby bar. 

I haven't experienced a blip in consistency among W's until my recent stay in New Orleans. While I understand it's an older hotel (built in 1984), the years of hard partying haven't been good to ol' girl and it shows. Especially in the bathroom, where tile gets grubby and bath time feels only utilitarian. The location suits me (a few blocks away from the Quarter so it's a bit quieter) and the staff is super accommodating, but I just couldn't reconcile the mediocrity of my room with the price.

While this hotel certainly gets the 'job' done - a good night's rest - the discrepancies between the posh lobby, outdated rooms and the inflated prices just don't add up to satisfaction. Paging Mick Jagger: Let's commiserate!

Oh man, this hurts. I love (or loved, to be most correct) iTap but my most recent experience reminded me that indifferent service will probably result in a dispassionate experience. And when the majority of patrons you're encountering are passionate about their beer, well let's pour some passion on their sugar. Know what I mean?

Def Leppard-like references aside, love bites because sometimes, it ends. When my brother asked for the Boulevard Tank 7 saison beer (my recommendation), I noticed he didn't seem to be enjoying it as much as I expected he would. "Try this," he implored my cousin. Two seconds later, my cousin admitted he didn't care for the beer as he's 'not into hops.' Hops? What? My beloved Tank 7 is a saison. As in, low in IBUs (international bitterness units). It's dry, light in color but full in flavor and straight up DELICIOUS. But hoppy? That, it's not.

I decided to get to the bottom of things and without seeing the bottom of the pint glass, instantly realized my brother received either the wrong pour or maybe the keg had just been switched and we were tasting the previously-parked beer. In any case, my brother informed the bartender and she tried the beer. She then had the other bartender try the beer. After several minutes of deliberation they arrived at the conclusion that indeed, the beer did not taste like Tank 7. "And? Can I please get another beer since it isn't what I asked for?" Long pause. "I'll have to talk to the manager to see if it can be taken off your bill."

Just get the kid a beer. If you're having problems with the lines and can't deliver the product in the quality as intended, (nicely) offer him a replacement beer. On the house. Instead, the attitude was free and the replacement beer turned out to be a pain in the ass to get.

Sorry, but you can keep the attitude and I'll take my friends, money and love for great craft beer somewhere else.

Did Chicago's Map Room and Quenchers mate, make a beer belly and raise the baby in St. Louis? Between the 44 rotating taps, another 480 in bottles and the interesting + eclectic live music line-up, I'd say all signs point to yes. 

iTap (I-Tap? I.Tap?) is damn near perfect. On a Wednesday evening, I came in with a small group and was ecstatic to find the bar filled but not overwhelmingly so, and with... grown-ups. Right away, I noticed Boulevard Tank 7 on tap and realized that my hometown finally had a real craft beer bar. After just a few minutes, we were able to snag some rockstar bar stools and start our adventure in seasonal beer tasting. My favorite was the Silly Noel (Silly Belgium): A sugar cookie meets Belgian Tripel (with Christmas spice and lemon zest) makes for the most fun my mouth has had since trying Malheur 12 for the first time. I just upgraded my review from 4-stars to 5... believe me, you would too.

Plain and not-so-simple: This beer list ROCKS! Plotting to get back here again very soon... oh wait, there's Christmas. Ah, and the things I will do to you come summer when your patio re-opens!

I come here for the ricotta cannoli (natch!) but usually also walk out with fresh bread, a gooey butter cake and cheese strudel. 

Thanks, Missouri Baking Company, for making my hips the childbearing kind all these years!

The big three - food, cocktails and service - are all flawless. Let's break it down!

Service: Vicki (the most awesome bar hostess) greeted me with a smile and a cocktail menu and even took the time to clink glasses (a toast to us, yes!). She checked in several times during the evening and was so accommodating, we never left the bar and noshed on our selections there instead.

Cocktails: You can't go wrong with a Bellini or the signature cocktail made with vodka and several types of fresh fruit juices. Though the signature libation borders on juicebox dangerous, it's a dalliance I'll endorse again and again. Sweet perfection.

Food: The menu's loaded with tempting flatbreads, pasta dishes, main meats and small plate treats such as Brussels sprouts with pancetta. I have a difficult time passing up a Flammekuchen flatbread if I spy it, and this German pizza with caramelized onions, pancetta and crème fraiche delivered. 'Twas an ooey, gooey mess of cheese and I completely embarrassed myself by polishing off the entire thing, but the calorie inhalation was worth it. 

Can't wait to return on my next hometown visit! Thank again for making me feel right at home, Vicki.

*Parking can be tough, but valet service can be yours for only $4.

Divey. Diminutive. And honestly, a little dingy. 

But damn - Verti Marte sure knows how to put together a solid sandwich!

What started as a morning running errands 'round the Quarter quickly became a soggy afternoon... and I didn't need to glance at my watch to realize it was lunch time yet I hadn't even had breakfast. After a quick consultation with my know-it-all Yelp app, I realized I was only two blocks away from a quick-serve sandwich spot. Sold!

Walking into this convenience store I was met with a line about half a dozen deep. If you're even slightly claustrophobic, know that the space near the deli area is significantly tight - to the point that I may have unintentionally given the guy standing behind me a dirty look (hey, it was a reflex) for standing a little too close to me. Accidental booty grab aside, the wait was reasonably painless as the sandwich maestro was moving and sweating to get us out of there quickly. Once my small turkey was ready to go, I scored a Blood Orange Pellegrino and was happily on my way to the next destination.

And whoa - for such a tiny place with reasonable prices, Verti Marte delivers on the size! A sandwich size queen I am not, but having access to such a large beast of a sammie was really comforting knowing that I probably wouldn't be able to eat again for another 10 hours. The premise is simple but it hits the culinary spot: crusty bread overstuffed with fresh fillings on the quick and cheap. Oh, and Veri Marte is open 24/7 - don't pass this one by!

I stayed here and I'd do it again... definitely.

From reading the reviews, sounds like a lot of people are bringing up the same beefs - 'room wasn't the nicest', 'hotel was too loud' and so on - you get what you pay for and those guests paying top dollar for their rooms usually get the most deluxe ones and those guests who stay with Starwood the most often (oh hello, loyalty program), are the ones who get upgraded. It's just the hard truth. And in regards to the noise - well, it's a fact that peeps come to NOLA to party and there's just no getting around that. I've stayed at hotels in the Quarter where the street noise from Bourbon will waft into your room well into the hours approaching dawn, but I did not find that to be the case at this property. The location is right on the edge of the Quarter without sitting smack dab in it... I'm not exaggerating when I say I slept like a baby.

The panoramic views from the 11th floor lobby and lounge probably rival some of the best in the city... it's a stunning postcard capturing the enormity of the majestic Mississippi River and the venerable cityscape. Grab a drink, sink into a couch and let the world go by for a few minutes, or an hour!

While the view from my 14th floor room wasn't much to brag about, it was a pretty sweet suite (full disclosure: I am a Starwood Platinum). The upgrade came courtesy of the affable and disarmingly handsome Volker - I was trying to get into my room quickly with a conference call creeping up and Volker made sure I was on my way within mere minutes. 

The hotel connects to The Shops at Canal Place, which houses upscale stores such as department store anchor Saks, Anthropologie, BCBG and Michael Kors. I even had my hair done at the Aveda salon after getting blasted by the rain. The only annoying thing about this property? The elevator situation - you have to take an elevator to 11 to get to the lobby and then transfer to a separate elevator to access the guest rooms. Not terribly inconvenient considering all the good that's going on here, but worth a mention. 

The weekend I was in, rates were available via Starwood's website for $119 (I booked about a month in advance). My advise? Take the deal and run! Doesn't get too much better than the Westin in this range.

There is no such thing as too much frosting. Let me repeat that for emphasis: There is NO such thing as too much frosting!

My boss surprised us in the 'boardroom' yesterday with a box filled with supermodel cupcakes. Seriously, these babies are tall, gorgeous and almost too pretty to eat. Since I'm not big on chocolate, I made a beeline for the first white cupcake I saw. Let me tell you, there was nothing vanilla about my choice. The white chocolate macadamia is yellow cake with white chocolate and macadamia nuts inside then topped with a tower of cream cheese frosting, white chocolate curls and Hawaiian macadamia nuts.

The best way to attack this amazon creation is to slice up the cake and spread individual layers of frosting, piece by piece. This also allows for prolonged gratification... ahhh yes. This beauty was almost perfect save for a slightly dry cake. But, the intentions (and proportions) were indeed perfect. 

I think I shall go try the Italian Cream Wedding Cake (Italian cream cake topped with cream cheese frosting and toasted coconut) today. Jealous? I thought so.

The scene: just after 6am on a Monday morning, and my brother is driving me to the Amtrak. We hear a pop, and then the familiar feel of a blown tire dragging. Argh! I need to get to the Amtrak within 20 minutes or I'll miss my train.

The solution: I call 411, and when the operator mentions Laclede Cab dispatch is located on Vandeventer, I know they're the one! My brother's car is on the shoulder of 40 heading east just shy of Vandeventer. They say they'll be there as soon as they can, and 5 minutes later, my carriage arrives. 

The outcome: I explain my situation and the cab driver says, "don't worry, we'll be there in 5 minutes!" I jump out of the cab to grab cash from an ATM inside the train station, dole out the fare + tip, and I'm on my way to Chicago. Saved by Laclede Cab!

I love this bar so much - really, I just want to wrap it up, check it with my luggage and take it everywhere I go.

First, the insides are very fetching - the wall covered in mirrors of all shapes and sizes always gets my attention... there's something about the Oyster Bar that gives it this vintage Parisian feel, and I think that the stylistically-haphazard display of mirrors might be a big part of it. 

Then there's the cocktail program... I mean, c'mon - a limoncello mule? You had me at first glance of your copper mug.

But most of all, I like this bar because it's easy. So many things in life are difficult, but our downtime shouldn't be. So rest easy and know that the perfect date place really does exist. That neighborhood bar you haven't yet found? You can stop searching; you have arrived. A special somewhere where time doesn't exist and you'll never overstay your welcome?

World, meet your 'just one more' - as it turns out, the nightcap is very much alive and well.

With its warm, glowy lighting and clean, apothecary-inspired styling, SoBou is every bit the inviting hostess. Even from across the street, this sophisticated gastropub-meets-modern-tavern beckoned. Once you get to know the quiet charm of this dignified lady you just may find yourself intoxicated by the beauty of her cocktails and the allure of her artfully-plated food. We tried to leave after our first round of cocktails, but she pulled us right back in after a fruitless 15-minute meander. Lesson learned: when a good thing is right in front of you, recognize!

Over the busy MLK weekend, all tables were booked for the evening but we happened upon seating for two near the end of the bar. Perfect, as it wasn't quite as loud down at that end and we received very dedicated service. Besides sipping on the deliciously complex hibiscus cocktail (aptly-named after Georgia O'Keeffe), we snacked on a smattering of small plates: the highly-addictive cracked olives (cayenne; charred chilies), the luscious cheese plate served with smoked salted honey (wow!) and artisanal preserves, the SoBou burger (a largish slider topped with  bruléed onions, pepper jack cheese and pickled okra mayo) and the wondrous apple & pear salad (green apples, poached Asian pears, Camembert cheese and salted pecan tuile, with muscadine wine vinaigrette). For two people, this was enough to comfortably satiate without putting us in a sleepy comatose state. 

Excellent price points all around to match the stellar food and drink. I have a feeling I'll be back!

It's really not a secret, but I have a thing for Jack White.

And why wouldn't I? "He sings, plays electric guitar, harmonica, bass, piano, marimbas, drums, acoustic guitar, mandolin, maracas, flute and kazoo, weaves clothes from raw thread, cooks, and builds the studios in which they record their music." Oh, and he writes and produces, too. Is there anything Jack White can't do well?

August 1, 2008. I fell for Jack on day one of Lollapalooza 2008. I walked into Grant Park after work, on a solo mission to find my friends watching The Raconteurs. It was hot, sticky and pushing through the masses, I started to panic a bit. Texts weren't going through; I wondered if I'd ever be united with my pals in a crowd of 75,000+. And then, I heard that voice belting out "Steady as She Goes". I stopped, transfixed, and didn't move for the remaining 40 minutes of their set. Suddenly, I didn't need friends. Love at first listen!

August 31, 2009. I'm checking into a San Francisco hotel on business; Jack is checking out after his band The Dead Weather played Outside Lands. Eye contact is made, I'm sure of it. Okay, probably not but the sexual tension is real. I melt!

January 27, 2011. The unconsummated love affair continues. I'm in Nashville for work, and a colleague and I have a total of 1.5 hours (in lieu of lunch) to visit Third Man Records. Food schmood when there's a possibilty of a Jack White sighting! (TMR also doubles as a recording studio). We jump in a cab and head well out of our way to peruse Third Man's collection of all things Jack White. Posters, limited-release vinyls, stickers (see: my laptop) and various music paraphernalia fill the tiny space. I even geeked out and had my colleague snap my photo in the vintage phone booth. I savored my short time there and took in everything Jack, made a few purchases and was back on my merry way.

I loved every minute. Jack wasn't at Third Man Records that day, but I could feel him with us.*

* I'm really not creepy, I swear.

Ode to a dive bar. Well, not really (but keep reading).

On a scale of 1 to 10 with 10 being the most diviest, Sandrina's is a solid 5. Yes, there's way too much smoking and swearing going on, but they also serve Hoeegarden and they have a real front door (as opposed to a screen door, the hallmark of a true dive bar). Sandrina's also features lamb loin burgers and duck confit sliders on their menu. C'mon people, an authentic dive only serves communal pretzels or more randomly, hard-boiled eggs. IF any food at all. Am I complaining? Um, hell no... I most certainly tried one of those lamb loin sliders with caramelized onions, washed it down with a frosty Hoegaarden and I liked it. 

So basically, Sandrina's is a faux dive bar for St. Louis hipsters. It's a 3am bar, so watch your belongings. Just like your mama warned: nothing good happens after 2am. 'Tis true!

There's nothing like wasting time (slow 'n' easy) at the Broadway Oyster Bar.

Feel like hearing some live blues, jazz, reggae and bluegrass? Then head to BOB. Want to show off an institution to out-of-town friends? You should go to the BOB. Crave all sorts of seafood done in the Creole fashion including po' boys, oysters, alligators and mussels? By now, you know what to do.

I love the beer selection and the food is seriously to-die-for. But the band... wow... they kept us entertained for hours! Grab a table on the covered patio near the stage if you can and be ready to dance. I'm still wondering why we left to go to another bar after 5+ hours at the BOB because honestly, nothing compared after that. We were only let down. Next time, pencil me in for an entire day!

Being a good Catholic girl from a good Catholic city, I better have one good excuse for missing Easter Sunday mass. 

I'm thinking the convo at church went something like this:

Cousin Julie: Um, where's Jelena?

My mom: I'm not sure, but if I had to guess I bet she got on her mobile Yelp app and is now blissfully eating beignets at Café Ventana. 

Only, I know it didn't go down that way, not at all. *Cringe*.

Anyway. Truth is, I did find Café Ventana thanks to that super useful mobile app. What I don't understand is, how did my St. Louis friends and family not tell me about this dreamy coffee house meets café on SLU's campus? After making BFFs with the barista, she tells me they've been open for oh, only about 2.5 years. What? 

Café Ventana is a fine replica of the cafés you'll find in Europe, but with a heavy-handed New Orleans influence. There's local art dressing up the wall space, a large outdoor patio, live music, a deep menu featuring soufflés, paninis and salads, and... they serve alcohol! You won't find A-B offerings here - oh no, hot child. But you will see Duvel and New Orleans' own, Abita Brewing Company, have made the thoughtful beer list (much easier to drink it here then to drive across murky Lake Pontchartrain on the wobbly Poltergeist hallway bridge for 23.87 miles. Yes, I did and I'm still shaking).

Cocktails more your fancy? They make those too. Hell, you can even get a Sazerac, Hurricane or Pimm's Cup. But, what will keep me coming back are those deep-fried, powdered sugar-coated pockets of goodness, made daily on the premises. Well beignet me for breakfast, anytime!

As for mass... my excuse? Bad packing and a late-in-the-game discovery of torn stockings. Target, unlike Café Ventana, is not open on Easter Sunday.

PS: They have 14 types of hot sauce available. FOURTEEN!

Though no one can seem to agree on how love works, one thing's for sure: Love is all around.

There's the love you first experience upon being birthed... the instinctual, instantaneous love forged between mother and child. Dad, brothers, sisters and the rest of your extended family - you love 'em, too. And what about puppy love? Not just that first whiff of the stuff that makes knees go week, clouds your reason and eventually breaks your heart, but the love for your family pet (don't ask me about Toby - that little cocker spaniel still makes me cry).

And then there's love for your hometown team. Though I've lived in Chicago for almost five years now, I'll always bleed Cardinals red. I was raised by immigrant parents who didn't have much money left over for life's splurges during those early years, but my father always made sure the entire family caught at least one Cards game at Busch Stadium. Every summer, I looked forward to sitting in those hard, nosebleed seats and cheering on our boys... with peanuts, cotton candy and that ballpark smell! It was usually a school night and we'd be up way too late, but on this one magical evening per year, sleep got a hall pass.

In 2004, my brother and I won the post-season ticket lottery allowing us to buy two tickets to one World Series game at - wait for it - face value! Though we lost that game and ultimately the series, tonight I absentmindedly touch that plastic-encased, $45 stub every so often... for hope.

Tonight I chose to watch the game at home (alone!) without distraction and with complete absorption; I'm on edge and thoroughly, utterly, wholly engrossed (save for clicking the 'post' button on this review). It's been a rollercoaster, all right - my nails are bitten down in protest (no, it's not over yet!) and I'm hanging onto every pitch. But isn't this what the game is all about?

And though my heart may again be broken in about three thousand pieces in less than three hours, I'll always love my Cardinals.

After almost a year of unsuccessfully trying to stage a hook up with this Fozzie guy, we meet. 

First attempt: The parking lot is jammed, and there isn't street parking on busy drag Big Bend. I give up and head to Jimmy John's in Maplewood (don't yell).

Second attempt: I show up, and this time the parking lot is empty. I'm greeted by a sign at the door stating they're closed for some reason or another (don't remember why, hunger gives me a case of the short terms).

Third attempt: The almost charm. After staring at the menu for almost five full minutes, I psych myself out and order something too basic. A hot sandwich - turkey with pepper jack cheese and honey mustard on a pretzel roll. Though the bread was fresh, it was definitely more easy on the pretzel than I would've liked (if that makes sense). The turkey?  Delicious but varying degrees of hot - edge pieces were properly warmed, but as I moved closer to the center of the sandwich, temps dropped. Stone Cold Steve Austin met me in the middle. How many licks does it take to get to the center... never mind, no Tootsie Pops here. The cheese (pepper jack sans the spice) slightly disappointed, and I wasn't in love with the mustard. Still, a strong effort save for some minor snafus. 

There are so many sandwiches, burgers and dogs to choose from... next time (and there will be a next time, as Fozzie's lives in my brother's 'hood) I'll order more selectively.

Even though the word kukhnya means 'kitchen', this divey space reminds me of my parent's friends' basements circa late-1980s when they still had less than a decade of living in the US under their Balkan belts. Living was modest but man, did we know how to enjoy life on a dime. And when I go back to the 'old country', I'm reconnected with life's real pleasures - like simple, unadulterated food cooked by the rough hands of people who work so hard to have just enough.

We arrived with our stomachs on near empty, as we had worked and partied our way through a long day and an epic event. I instantly felt at home when I noticed all the Slavs in the kitchen - really, you can't even begin to understand the meaning of 'stick to your ribs' cooking until your baba (a Slavic nickname for grandma) makes a vat of goulash that's intended to be consumed by just ONE person in just ONE sitting (and if you don't she'll be offended. Believe me, you don't want to be the person who brings pain to a sweet baba). 

But I digress. The food came out about 20 minutes later - they make everything as it's ordered, from scratch. We started with some pierogis (which they bill as 'Slavic soul food') and they hit all my Slavic spots with their pan-fried golden crust, chewy inside and accompaniment of fried onions and sour cream. I also tried the Russki Burger - as the name suggests and the local lore insists, this is a hearty burger, and it's fucking great. Topped with mushrooms, spinach, Cheddar, Swiss, lettuce, tomato, pickles and their housemade I'd-kill-puppies-for-it-Russian dressing (okay, not really but I've made my point), this thing is a beast. And, they make a beet version for your veggie friends!

Service was sincere and welcoming, just as you'd expect from such a warm people. Next time, show me where you're hiding the sljivovica, okay? I won't tell.

I'm Sol-d!

The Buenos Aires connection was in town for a quick visit, and I knew that she'd want to dance. And hard. But without the lists, the lines and the big club hoopla. All we wanted was really good music that we could get down to and space to chill. 

My cousin suggested Sol-- turns out he's been coming since the early underground days. It's connected to the awesome Grind Coffeehouse, so I knew the vibe would be hip but devoid of that superclub pretension.

High ceilings, exposed brick walls, and lots of seating and leaning-opportunities. You know, when you don't feel like lazing but still want a good lean... girlies in towering heels know what I'm talking about! The DJs play house music standards on the lower lever, and an organic hip hop sound (think: The Roots) on the upper floors. 

Cocktails are served quickly and with sweet severity. Don't need much, these guys pour heady concoctions.

My favorite part of the experience? The super-large projector screen. It's almost 3 am, and while listening to an old Faithless track, I'm watching the last few minutes of Troy. No, never saw it, but there was just something so beautiful, so haunting about watching the tragic fight to the death. Maybe it had a little something to do with Brad Pitt and Eric Bana, but I don't think so... there's a certain allure in watching a movie without sound and mysterious-by-default Chinese subtitles. 

Very cool late-night spot... dig dig dig it.

Finally, a really great wine bar to love on in South County! I'm not sure how long Bottle Cellars has been around, but I do know it sat in my Yelp bookmarks for far too long.

A few weekends ago while visiting the fam, my cousin and I made plans to visit Bottle Cellars on a Saturday night. 'Twas the perfect amount of liveliness, and we ended up chatting up the table of folks next to us (two couples around my parents age who were straight up hilarious). There's a range of all ages that frequent this wine bar so absolutely anyone would feel comfortable here! Even if you came alone, you'd make new friends fast.

Our server was very knowledgeable about the wine and the menu (I'm gluten free) and when he wasn't sure about something, he admitted it! And then ran off to quickly get us the answer. Love that kind of honesty, so refreshing! While I pondered ordering a custom flight, we ultimately split a bottle of Pinot Noir (I was so ecstatic to find a favorite from Sonoma County at their attached wine store next door). We also indulged in a fantastic cheese plate that included a very memorable dessert cheese. Except that I can't remember what it was called! It curled almost like a ribbon and had notes of butterscotch and crème brûlée. We were so obsessed that we ordered another serving of just that cheese!

Can't wait to return! So happy to finally have found a going out destination in SoCo that isn't a typical sports bar.

On the recommendation of a friend, my sister suggested we stop by here to pick up lunch and take home. As my sister is a 'girly' girl, I'm not surprised her friend made the rec: The Art of Entertaining is all about cuteness with it's black and pink exterior and matching insides. 

It may be adorable, but I wondered if its allure would be in fact skin deep. I wandered around the store and found plenty of healthy ready-to-serve options such as salads, soups, wraps and sandwiches. They also offer made-to-order counter service in addition to frozen entrees, catering and a bevy of desserts.  

My sister and I both ordered the chicken salad sandwich. For $8.95, you get a gourmet sandwich, a side (I chose a small salad) and a dessert. I loved the classically-prepared white meat chicken salad as well as my dessert (a lemon macaroon bar with toasted coconut). Really, a great buy for a fresh and fantastic lunch which we could barely finish. Also, the package is precious with your lunch all gussied up in its black bag and tied up in a purple bow. 

My niece absolutely loved her chocolate cupcake... it was all we could do to keep her from ravaging it in her car seat. Luckily, she waited to make a chocolate-y mess until we got home!

3 happy girls = success.

Thinking about blowing your wad at the Conrad? Well aye aye, sailor... it's completely worth it!

The lobby is stunning, but not in that ostentatious, over-the-top "I'm a boutique hotel, look at me!" way. And the check-in process took all of 2.5 minutes. For an impatient girl like me, that's priceless.

My room. So stately, so sophisticated. There's a small sofa, an upholstered chair, a coffee table, two end tables, a huge desk, a dresser, my king size bed and there's still plenty of room to spare. In the bathroom, we have a sleek and small flat screen TV to further enhance your soak in the GLORIOUS tub should you want to sneak in some Mad Men. 

The toiletries = designer Italian. I'm smelling like a bed of roses right now... thank you, Conrad!

The location is fab (right downtown off the circle) and the bed is magnificent. Actually, the bed warrants its own sentence. I'm sinking in it right now, and this review is becoming less and less of a priority... on that note, I bid you adieu! Too bad you won't sleep as well as me.

And that is why you should stay at the Conrad.

You're hungover. Turkey leftovers are tired. Gyros sound like more the ticket! But mom can't find out you're skipping the remains of her laborious turkey dinner.

Okay by now, it's clear I'm talking about my cousin... definitely not me!

But I digress. A couple clicks on my Yelp app yielded what would turn out to be a deliciously messy, completely necessary experience with an overstuffed gyro. Sure, Soco Gyros & Deli doesn't look like much on the outside... but tell that to your mouth after putting away one of these stacked sandwiches!

Meat: Most excellent! Tzatziki: Luscious. Pita: Very good. Hot sauce (don't judge): Terrific. Presentation: Perfectly swaddled like a newborn baby (read: ain't no meat falling out of this pita!). Only menu item I can live without is our shared appetizer, the hummus, as it lacked that homemade taste and super creamy texture I love.

Just a little over $20 for a solid lunch of two gyros, two soft drinks and that ho-hum hummus. And mission accomplished: I got back to my cousin's couch and promptly fell asleep for three hours! That's one hell of a gyro-induced coma doing its job and erasing hangovers all over the StL.

I wanted to love it, I really did. But Berix fell a little flat for me in a few key areas.

My mom, brother and I came here for lunch with pita and cevapi specifically on the brain. You order at the counter and then take a table. The restaurant itself is really clean, spacious and has sort of a cozy ski-lodge feel. 

My mom placed an order for our cevapi, a cheese pita and also two pitas to take home. However, when the order came up all the pita was on the tray instead of being packaged to-go as she had asked. Not a biggie, but they also gave her spinach pita instead of cheese for some of the order. No language barrier, just unmindful customer service.

My cevapi themselves were really good, but there's more to cevapi then just the meat. The bread and kajmak also contribute to the total awesomeness. While the bread was perfect (and I mean perfect!), the cevapi were served with ajvar. I asked for some kajmak but received... sour cream! Lack of the ideal (and authentic) cevapi condiment? Somewhat of a letdown. 

The pita was so good my mom served it at Thanksgiving dinner instead of making her own. So we'll definitely be back for that. Berix also makes burek, sarma, gulas, raznici, kebabs and pljeskavica in addition to more Americanized sandwiches.

Trivia: wondering about the name origin? No, it's not Bosnian. It must be derived from the name of the intersection-- Reavis Barracks (Berix) and Lemay Ferry.

I'm loving Northwest Coffee even more now since they started serving eggs several days ago.

Plain eggs, eggs with cheese, eggs in a tortilla, eggs on a bagel, eggs on an English muffin... you get the picture.

They actually steam their eggs under one of their espresso machines! So, they come out extra light and fluffy, and the water expands them nicely. No butter or oils necessary! 

And, their eggs are locally-sourced from the River Hills Poultry Alliance. They're 'happy eggs', as they come from free-range chickens that are free of antibiotics and humanely raised. And yes, you CAN taste the difference.

They still make the meanest latte ever here, too! Try 'em.

Awhile back, I purchased a Sony mirrorless camera and slowly stopped using my Nikon DSLR. Though I actually prefer my Nikon, I found it and all its gear just too bulky when traveling. And I really only use my mirrorless and DSLR cameras when traveling, so the compact Sony camera won.

A few months later, I found out that Schiller's buys used camera equipment in good condition. As I had no real emotional attachment to my Nikon, I decided to visit Schiller's to see what I could get for it. Lo and behold, I was offered $430 for my gently-used camera, 3 lens, and a speedlight flash which I thought was more than fair. 10 minutes later, they cut me a check and I was on my way. 

If you're coming here to peruse camera gear, their selection is second to none! New, used, vintage SLR, DSLR, mirrorless, you name it. Their service is very comprehensive so the only negative may be that you may end up waiting awhile... and there's no clear queuing system. Otherwise, Schiller's is tops within their niche!

New Day Gluten Free is a true sanctuary for those of us who can't process wheat like the rest of you lucky folks. There's even a sign on the door stating no outside food can be brought in, to ensure the environment isn't contaminated!

Indeed, New Day is 100% wheat-free. Visiting their new location had topped my bucket list for the last couple of months, as they were moving their previous shop to a shiny, larger location in Clayton. And what a gorgeous space it is! Just going on 3 weeks new, we snatched the last open table on a busy Saturday.

Nothing can prepare you for the beauty that lies in the glass-encased baked good display case. Generously frosted cupcakes, gooey butter cookies, lemon bars, the cutest cakes and much more! I ordered a carrot cupcake and lemon bar to-go for my mom and me, and for lunch we opted for a turkey club and a California melt.

While both sandwiches were outstanding, I think my mom was a bit envious of the warm bun that hugged the overflowing toppings of my sandwich. Fresh turkey, provolone cheese, a liberal spread of guacamole, onions, lettuce and some mayo. But THAT BREAD! Wow. Just as good as bread made with conventional flour. This was my favorite type of sandwich in my gluten-eating days, so it was a dream to take in. 

After suppressing the temptation for a solid 8 hours, I finally gave in to the decadent carrot cupcake that had been staring me down all day. Holy cream cheese frosting! That was definitely the highlight for me and then some, as the cake portion was slightly dry. Still, it was one of the better gluten-free desserts I've had. Next time, I'll be trying the vanilla cupcake as that's my usual go-to treat.

Thanks for filling in a much-needed void in St. Louis, New Day! You've earned some new lifetime fans.

Love coffee mixed with a heaping side of socializing? Then Northwest Coffee Roasting Company is your spot, yo.

But first let's cover the important stuff-- the beans! I chose a Mocha nonfat latte as my inaugural drink at NCRC. No bitterness, just a smooth, rich caffeination ride. Mocha-choca-latte-ya-ya!

Grab a seat at one of the tables or at my pick, the coffee bar. The super friendly staff is fun to chat up... Emily the barista sensation is a sweetheart! Really, this coffeehouse is more Cheers than coffee depot. After today, I bet they even remember my unusual name. 

Free wi-fi should you feel like being productive.

When the 'lover of sweets' file cabinet is opened, I'm not in there. In fact, when I feel a craving coming on for something outside the realm of savory, I'll turn to Yelp's unofficial guru of all things sweet, Johnny T. A recent conversation with a very indifferent me went something like this:

Me: I think I want something sweet, but I never know what to get. What do you usually go for when craving sweets? 

JT: Ice cream. Chocolate. Cupcakes. Cookies. Pancakes.

Me: Nah... keep going.

JT: Macaroons. Fruity drinks. Pralines.

Ding, ding, ding - PRALINES, people! I'll go on record to say that pralines are the most satisfying form of sugar I've ever put in my mouth, especially if they're from Southern Candymakers. You know you're in for an inimitable treat when you're greeted with that smell - a heady mix of childhood nostalgia that for me, was reminiscent of waffle cones being made at Six Flags (only exponentially better). A candy crafter was busy at work hand-scooping creamy dollops of praline onto a marble slab and cheerfully asked if I'd like a sample, even though I had already acknowledged I was purchasing a few. Oh good gracious, southern hospitality... teach the rest of us, please?

I walked out, practically skipping on a clear, sunny New Orleans day with my decadent collaborations of fresh cream, butter, sugar, and Louisiana pecans swinging in my right hand. The world and my heart stopped for a moment while I took that first bite and contemplated saving the other two pralines for later... but I couldn't. A handmade praline is a gift, and you shouldn't deny yourself the unequivocal, wholly-sating sugar high only a perfect praline can bring on.

It should be noted for tourists that Southern Candymakers' pralines are wrapped very simply (for those considering bringing them back as gifts)... think of the wrapping as expensive lingerie. Is it really necessary when you're about to be passionately consumed with what lies underneath the package? Exactly. Take it from a new-to-the-club praline junkie - these exquisite treasures simply should not be missed!

Modesto just keeps moving, tweaking and re-inventing. Just because you've got a good thing going, you can't rest on your laurels. And these restaurateurs get it-- from menu redesigns to new tapas, evolution is the word @ 5257 Shaw Ave.

I met up with my longtime bestie from Buenos Aires for a night of girl talk, sangria and our favorite small plates. The restaurant was full and we didn't have reservations, but you can reserve a table in the bar area... 10-minute wait, score!

Can't-miss:
Mussels steamed in hard cider with chorizo and peppers
Lamb skewers with yogurt and herb salsa
Baked goat cheese in spicy tomato sauce
Hangar steak with port reduction
Bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with Cabrales cheese

Pass: Flatbread with caramelized onions, olives, garlic and Manchego cheese. Just a bit too sweet.

Service is always courteous and professional, and the sangria... oh the sangria! If you haven't tried sangria made the authentic way with brandy, well then just you wait. It's the champagne of buzzes... exquisite!

The bottom line first: it doesn't matter how good your cevapi are, Bosna Gold, if I'm too thirsty to enjoy 'em. Seriously... waiting for ice cubes to melt so you can suck down an inkling of hydration is not cool.

Argh.

Such is the problem with many European restaurants. You want authentic Bosnian fare? You got it. However, that also comes with a heaping side of blatant disregard for good service. If I may make a suggestion, order a soft drink or Fructal juice in addition to a glass of water (the food is salty and you'll be dying mid-meal if you're depending on a refill). You're welcome!

But I digress. The food is solid-- I tried the salad with feta (no lettuce, just cucumbers, green peppers, tomatoes and feta) as well as the cevapi. The meat is excellent, and the homemade lepinja bread is more buttery than most I've tried... delicious! I did miss the kajmak though... what's up with all the Bosnian restaurants in St. Louis serving sour cream instead? It's just not the same! Sigh... I feel cheated.

Oh, and my take on the restaurant? Jimmy Buffet meets Vermont ski lodge. Quaint, cozy yet hokey. Niiiiice.

This hot brunch spot may be called Half & Half, but it's wholly delicious.

First, the important stuff - this girl's gotta have her caffeine! I didn't see it on the menu, but just because Aimee K wrote about it, I ordered a half coffee/half hot chocolate. Oh.My.Awesomeness!

For my meal, I ordered the cornbread and chorizo dish. Easily the frontrunner on their menu, my plate was perfectly portioned with the headlining ingredients plus two sunny side-up eggs, cilantro and red onion. Spot-on sensational.

My cousin had the fried egg sandwich, which is usually what I would order if it's available. The rest of the menu boasts fairly inventive selections - think Clara cakes (pancakes with raspberry, mascarpone and granola), a Brussel sprout and cheddar omelet (WHAT?!), salmon hash and housemade donuts. All good in this 'hood!

Can't wait to return to eat my way through the rest of the menu. Well done, good folks!

Yes, it's true: the space is very, very pretty.

However, good looks alone shouldn't warrant a restaurant resting on its laurels. Maybe it was just an 'off' night, but my cousin, brother and I certainly weren't overly impressed.

We sat down and were quickly greeted by our server with a smile and an introduction. Nice! She asked us what we wanted to drink, but being that Copia is a wine bar, kind of difficult to do that without a wine and/or drink list in front of us. We also asked for a beer list (which they don't have), but our server was happy to consult her own personal list and recite the anemic selection for us. I know you specialize in wine, but craft beer and good wine go hand in hand!

We ordered the calamari appetizer to start. Though it came out super fast, it was over-breaded, over-cooked and under-seasoned. I tend to love most calamari whether it's fried, sauteed or grilled, but this was an underachieving dish. I should have gone with my gut instinct and ordered the baked brie! At this point, we finished our drinks and decided against ordering more food.

I'll have to return to try additional dishes, but this particular evening proved 'a-okay' at Copia. Though I do love the concept of selling bottles of wine at retail price plus an $8 corkage fee to keep it legit!

Though I'm neither vegan or vegetarian, I really enjoy eating as healthy as I can... most of the time, anyway!

It makes me so happy to see spots like this in my hometown, beautiful eateries celebrating mindful eating with clean ingredients. So often restaurants in this vertical are more casual, which I certainly enjoy, but it's really nice to have a more elegant option as well. And Frida's certainly looks the part! Though you won't feel out of place if you are dressed down.

On a recent weekday afternoon, I met a gal pal for lunch at Frida's. We both ordered the same salad as she highly recommended it: the taco salad with the addition of sunflower taco meat and gluten-free chips for an additional $2.75. Crunchy romaine, cheddar jack, black beans, black olives, tomatoes, red pepper, scallions, avocado, and house-made chipotle ranch made for such a healthy yet unbelievably tasty meal. Coming in at $14.25 for the souped-up large, it's a touch spendy but well worth it! The salad is truly a generous portion, which translated into a very light dinner that evening. 

Can't wait to eat my way through the entire menu, there's truly something for every palate and dietary restriction at Frida's!

Sorry guys, but I really can't get on board with your sushi. Next time, I'll try one of those burgers you keep braggin' on.

But, big props for featuring a $6 cocktail every day! My poison pick? Allow me to recommend Pearl Caramel vodka with soda. Did you know caramel mixed with soda = a dreamy cream soda?

Bell Biv DeVoe... now you know (I've always wanted to drop that).

Now THIS is what a luxury hotel should strive to be like.

As others point out, the amenities are plentiful and they just make good sense. For example - offering free wi-fi not just in the lobby but in every guest room. I can't tell you how often I pay an arm and a leg on wi-fi services that feel like AOL dial-up, circa 1996!

Also, the complimentary courtesy car (available for trips within a 3-mile radius) is such a swell add-on. I used this service at least three times!

But best of all, is the wine hour enjoyed in the lobby every day from 5-6pm. This is something I did not miss! The wine is actually really good and runs like water (free + plentiful) much to our group's delight.

Of course, the hotel is beautiful from trim to fixtures to the stately but small, elegant rooms. Service is wonderfully southern, and the hotel's conscientious environmental efforts are commendable.

Would I come back? In a Nashville heartbeat.

What a gem. Not a hidden gem, but a pretty, polished gem... this sleek, warm brownstone is gorgeous inside and out!

On to the important stuff - the beer. Or is it the food? Well, you won't be forced to split your loyalties at Square One as both are very, very good. Cousin and I tried the charcuterie plate and ate our way through the pub pretzels (that jalapeno cheese sauce is a dipping darling) and would have ordered more if it wasn't for a heavy lunch earlier that day.

I had a difficult time zeroing in on just one beer so I naturally sprang for the beer flight once I discovered it's an option - especially as the individual flight pours are robust at five ounces each. Essentially, you get a pint+ for the same cost as a regular pint! I chose the Maple Stout (my favorite!), Spiced Pumpkin Ale (solid), Spicy Blonde (loved the ginger notes) and the Bavarian Weizen (classic banana + cloves; nice and easy). 

Much joy was had and I look forwarding to visiting again when in my hometown.

Live blues, 365 nights a year 'til 3am. Now that's what I'm talking about!

No, they don't serve food. But you can get that across the street at the Broadway Oyster Bar (fantastic music acts over there as well). But after I've spent a few hours at the Oyster Bar, my friends and I like to change up the scene by heading to Beale. It's a bit darker, a little grimier, and more intimate. The performers on this stage are top-notch, occupational musicians... if you're looking for 'real' blues in St. Louis, you've come to the right venue.

There's always a cover (maybe $5-7) but you're supporting St. Louis' vibrant local music scene... here's to keeping it alive! The bartenders are no-nonsense pros - drinks are strong and the beers are cold. And if you get the chance, visit during the warmer months so you can soak up the sparkle of the Beale on the patio. Cheers!

Vodkaaaa. It's the only spirit that I drink! And with nearly 260 brands at this bar, you're sure to find 'the one'.

Sub Zero has done a fine job of profiling an extensive list of drinks, including a specialty champagne cocktail roster. My favorite? The Bling Bling, comprised of Grey Goose, raspberry puree and simple syrup then topped with champagne. Hello, sweetness!

Sub Zero's the perfect spot for people watching, catching up, meeting up, and just plain loungin'. Also, I haven't yet tried their sushi or burgers but my discerning friends who frequent Sub Zero regularly give the fare a thumbs up. 

But I'll be back here for vodka topped with bubbles... a vodka parfait, mmm!

Marinka is the perfect blend of savvy realtor, outstanding marketer, and wonderful human. She recently sold my childhood home after only being on the market for 3 days. She also went out of her way to help my Croatian-born parents with filling out paperwork, which is obviously beyond her scope of duty but yet she happily offered. When my father fell ill which landed him in the hospital, Marinka worked with us to make sure all the papers could be signed in his hospital room on closing day. It was truly a flawless and stress-free transaction in every way. If you're looking for an empathetic realtor who's at the top of her game, Marinka is your woman. I can't imagine working with anyone else and I'd recommend her to anyone. As we say in Croatian: svaka čast, Marinka! Bravo on a job well-done.

More than two and a half years later, I'm STILL jonesin' for the Creperie every time I'm in St. Louis! What's even funnier - I'm still ordering the same crepe: banana, brown sugar and sour cream. I'm so predictable!

The Creperie is very kid-friendly so go in expecting it to be somewhat of a zoo. However, they've added some tables outside if you'd prefer to read your newspaper with a side of peace and quiet.

The coffee here is still my favorite - really rich yet very smooth! I can't say enough good things about this special spot... so go experience it for yourself!

It's always a treat to see a thriving new restaurant in my hometown... especially one with a creative hand, constantly keeping things fresh with a seasonal menu.

My sister and I took the rare opportunity to have a girls' lunch while her hubby stayed home and the kiddies napped. She recommended we check out Nosh, and after checking out the Yelp reviews and the online menu, I had to agree. 

Not a dealbreaker, but the first thing I noticed is that it's a little cold inside. No biggie - we took a table furthest from the door and I made sure to order a piping hot cup of the French onion soup. Fastest way to a sure warm-up! Quite delicious, too.

For the main act, I ordered the Fried Egg BSRP: Two organic free range eggs cooked medium with bacon, spinach, roasted red peppers, smoked gouda and dijon red pepper aioli served on a butter croissant. Verdict? Even better than it sounds. I could barely finish as it's a sandwich made for a hearty appetite... but it was so good, I couldn't tear myself away. My sis really enjoyed her ham and brie sandwich, though she commented it could have used a touch more brie. So, we like our cheese! But still, spectacular sandwiches indeed. And next time, I'll be sure to try the chicken gouda sandwich or the steak and gorgonzola flatbread. Trust me, I was plenty enticed by a few of the offerings.

Service was attentive without being intrusive. Keep on keeping, Nosh! I'll be seeing you again soon.

If this gives you any idea of how efficient the good people of Nashville International Airport are, here goes:

We left our hotel at 7:50am (approx. 8 miles from the airport).
We checked our bags at counter, went through security and were sitting at the gate by 8:25am!

Whew. That's impressive!

Restrooms are clean, baggage comes up fast, there's a Starbuck's and a 20-minute manicure spot, and best of all... it should be relatively easy to wrangle a ride as it's not a zoo in front. It may not be the prettiest airport, but it's certainly the closest I've come to travel nirvana.

This tiny little place... it really did make my heart sing.

A small bit of history: In River Phoenix' last fully-realized screen performance - The Thing Called Love - we get a glimpse of songwriters auditioning to play at The Bluebird Cafe. Samantha Mathis stars in the flick too (who I fell in love with watching Pump Up the Volume) and though the movie isn't the best, the little cafe stayed with me. 

Fast forward to last night, when a dear friend suggested we hit up The Bluebird Cafe to catch Nashville's finest songwriters singing the hits they never recorded but painstakingly birthed. After waiting in line for about twenty minutes, they started letting us into the intimate venue. Now some may say this is a fantastic date spot, but really it'll only play that part if you're with someone you already know well as conversation is discouraged. The hushed demeanor definitely reminded me of Chicago's famed Green Mill!

But that's where the parallels stop. Where Green Mill is dark, The Bluebird is sweet. While Green Mill's musicians boast with their big sound, the modest artists of The Bluebird make you wonder, 'what if?'

I bet they too wonder, 'what if'.

Take Gary Burr (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Burr), who wowed us with just a taste of his collection of hits, performed by greats such as Kenny Rogers, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Faith Hill and even Ricky Martin and Christina Aguilera. Gary was as accessible as an artist can get, regaling us with his stories and forcing us to re-think music as we already knew it... a musical coup of déjà vu!

Thinking about what could have been usually proves to be a bittersweet road and Gary's performance was no different. Cheers to The Bluebird for introducing audiences to the real legends behind the music and also, for reuniting songwriters with their babies. 

About as special as it gets.

You stop looking at me like that. I know, I know - Penn Station is a chain and eating at chains while traveling is practically a cardinal sin. But, I had only a few minutes to spare... and my choices including walking a few blocks further or grabbing a Penn Station sub next to my hotel (which would ultimately free 15 extra minutes to take a quick soak in the luxurious tub). What would you do? Uh huh. Priorities!

Anyway, the staff was nice enough though one staffer was barking at another woman for ringing people up separately though they were in the same group (awkward!). After ordering my sub, I was told it would be 7-8 minutes. 

I brought the club sandwich back to my room and ate it (okay, devoured it... I did just drive 3+ hours) while I ran my bath. It was a bit more compact than I anticipated but was loaded with bacon. Dare I say, almost too much bacon! It kind of overshadowed the taste of the other ingredients. But, it did hit the spot. Would I eat at Penn Station again? Probably not with all of the fantastic artisan sandwich crafters out there.

But... it was all about the tub in my bathroom at the Conrad.

One large group + light but insistent rain + an overly-crowded Whiskey Kitchen = After-dinner drinks conundrum.
 
Ack.

We were ready to give up and head back to the Hutton for drinks in the lobby bar, when our lovely local tour guide nudged us next door to Virago. And I'm glad she did for otherwise we would've missed a real Nashville hot spot!

So baby, it's a scene all right - it's dark and slick and sophisticated, but still tinged with that unmistakable Southern hospitality. Seriously, are all Nashvillians born with honey in their voice? Right off the bat, our sweet server offered to take separate checks for our group of 10 or so. Thanks, but luckily we've got some manners, too! 

I ordered a drink with strawberry puree, St. Germain and cava... easy does it! I believe it was called a Strawberry Sparkle. Or maybe it was Strawberry Smash. In any case, it's delicious alliteration. If I ever get asked 'if you were a drink, which one would you be?' in an icebreaker game again, I now know the answer! 

So they do sushi, too. Go see. Be seen. Check the scene. Sex and the city? Oh yes.

I've been going to Kaya's for a decade now. Yes it's in a strip mall, but once inside, you'll find a collection of wine and spirits that will make you forget you're in South County. Personally, I frequent Kaya's for the extensive selection of Croatian wine, beer and liquor, but they do a swell job of stocking other worldly spirits.

Every Friday from 5-8pm, Kaya hosts a wine tasting and also serves complimentary cheese, sausage and crackers. Check it out! You're also welcome to purchase a bottle onsite and enjoy it without being charged a corkage fee. 

Don't be surprised if you find yourself walking out with gifts for every family member... Kaya's has something for the imbiber in everyone!

There's a time and a place for a large local supermarket like Schnuck's and a time and a place for Starrs.

Starrs time:
- You'd like some personalized advise on selecting wine or craft beer.
- You're searching for a hard-to-source wine or beer.
- You'd like to take your time to shop sans crowded aisles and grocery cart bumps.
- You enjoy supporting small local businesses.
- You want to impress your boss/potential girlfriend/family with a unique buy.
- You're an oenophile or craft beer connoisseur.

Schnuck's time:
- You're nowhere near Starrs.

I was bamboozled.

Well, not really as I walked out of Saks with an *enhanced* appearance (courtesy of loads of Chanel make-up), but all that prettification sure did cost a pretty penny.

Because I put together a half-assed halfway to Mardi Gras costume consisting of only a long, light purple wig, I needed a dramatic face that could pull its weight. One with super long, fluttery eyelashes (read: faux) and smoldering eyes. I, unfortunately, am not competent when it comes to fake lash application nor at creating the smoky look... sigh.

I first stopped by the MAC counter, knowing full well that they make the best fake lashes and are awesome at creating a theatrical look (also - they're relatively inexpensive among department store cosmetics brands). But alas, they were booked solid and a sales associate at Chanel coaxed me to her chair. After asking what the minimum spend would be to get my make-up done (3 products or $75), I restrained my inner thriftonista, remembering I was also on a strict time budget. Proceed, lady in black!

And so she did. 45 minutes later, I was transformed into a va-va-voomin' vixen with a sexy, smoky eye, mile-long eyelashes (purchased from MAC), what appeared to be cheekbones (oh, hello!) and a demure, rosy lip to balance the strong eye look. Now, for my (not really necessary) product picks: blush, liquid eyeliner and a Glossimer lip gloss. Total cost? $112. Gulp.

But my make-up endured the test of 12 hours out and my new Chanel products will last much longer. When shopping at pricey department stores like Saks, it's best to go in knowing exactly what you need as saying 'yes, I'll take that!' just one too many times can easily result in a 4-digit spend. While the sales associates warm up as you spend some time with them, I did find their reception initially chilly... and a bit too 'sales-y' for my taste. Guess I'll always be a Nordstrom kind of gal - all the brands I want without the pressure or pretense!

Sugga, sugga!

Just because I ended my meal with a dessert (an oversized slightly gooey sugar cookie) doesn't mean I can't start my review with an homage to the sweet. Well done, Fido!

So Fido is this totally cute, totally happenin', totally cool coffehouse/eatery. There's tons of space so you can grab your co-workers for a group meal or to sprawl and sneak in a working lunch. Or, you can do like us and accomplish both!

They serve breakfast all day (huge plus for me, as sometimes I like to have pancakes for dinner), as well as a strong collection of specialty coffee drinks, artisan sandwiches, salads and larger plates. I tried the flank steak sandwich with swiss, roasted onions, garlic mayo, lettuce (hold the tomatoes) on herbed focaccia. GONE in 10 minutes flat... take that Nic Cage!

Yet another reason to frequent Fido? Their mission to find homes for displaced dogs. A feel-good operation right here in Nashville, indeed!

Why why why why why? Why do I continue to eat here?

It's a love/hate relationship.

Rationale: they've got a 24/7 drive-thru (I've never seen them close) that happens to be around the corner from my brother's abode. Convenience is the name of this late-night game... oh Del Taco, you're my faux Mexican booty call!

True story: I found my little dream home driving to Del Taco hungover one morning in a quest for a breakfast burrito. Saw an open house sign, wandered in, fell in love, called my parents and the rest is history! I lived in this cute little house for 4 years before moving, and now it's my brother's nest. Thanks Del Taco!

Looking for a spot for a large group, but can't deal with a wait? Blackstone is just the spot to bring 'em. A table for our group of eleven hungry colleagues was quickly set up... impressive!

Blackstone is the kind of brewery that turns out hearty pub fare. They even have Shepherd's Pie, which I greatly miss from my days as a New Englander. We tried the nachos (the black beans in this dish are so good!), thin crispy onion rings and pretzels for an appetizer. For my main, I went with the chicken, cheddar and bacon sandwich served with fries. The woodsmoked flavor of the chicken was slightly overwhelming, but the honey whiskey dressing I ordered on the side balanced things out a bit. 

The house brewed beer is solid (I tried the Oatmeal Stout and the Coffee Stout) and our server dealt with our large + loud group without skipping a beat. Best of all. Blackstone is walking distance from the Hutton Hotel so if I get a hankerin' for those nachos, I can rest easy knowing I'm only a hop, skip and a jump away.

As tradition dictates, my Mizzou college pals and I are STILL meeting here every year right before Christmas Eve to celebrate shenanigans past. Last night marked a momentous 5 years straight of meeting at J & A's! Though our favorite dive bar still allows smoking inside (ugh), I think we'll continue meeting here until the end of time. Why?

- It's fun watching the sole bartender take care of a room of 40+ people with ease. Impressive, indeed!
- The bar now boasts one of those ultra modern, shiny new jukeboxes. However, the sticky old one seemed much more apropos for J & A's um, ambiance.
- You'd be hard-pressed to find better pizza made in a bar!
- Beers range from $2.25 to $2.50/bottle; pitchers are $6-7.
- This is a REAL dive, people. Randomly situated in the heart of the sophisticated Central West End, it's truly an unexpected treat.
- They now feature a tiny table-top Christmas tree in response to our group's unintentional affiliation with the former larger one's untimely demise. The staff is obviously in tune with the needs of their client base. 

Tip: If you're a wine drinker, make sure they open a new bottle for you as that current bottle may be flatter than still water. Something tells me that wine isn't a beverage often requested at J & A's ;)

I'll always have room in my heart for the magic that is J & A's (supposedly, the oldest bar in St. Louis).

I swear I really do other things besides primp and preen while in NOLA (like eat and drink excessively), but any New Orleanian will affirm that wigs are indeed important in the city that celebrates the year-round fanfare of costume!

Luckily for me, I didn't even have to lift a finger to search for where I'd buy a costume wig on my trusty Yelp mobile app. Instead, I turned to the always well-costumed and perpetually stunning Joi B who insisted I check out Fifi's for a showstopper of a wig.

When I arrived, the sales associates were busy assisting a mom and her 3 daughters with trying on wigs of all different colors, lengths and textures. Curl, straight or wavy - you've got it. Natural shades of red, brunette, blonde and raven-hued wigs dot the walls, but theatrical colors such as pink, purple, yellow, blue and green also live here!  I naturally gravitated toward a light pink hue in the impossibly long and sexy Ginger wig but ended up leaving as a lilac-headed seductress in the same style (looks like this: http://www.polyvore.com/cgi/img-thing?.out=jpg&size=l&tid=22056505).

The staff stuffed my crazy-thick head of hair into the wig cap, carefully pinning everything in place. They also offered to give ol' girl Ginger a free bang trim but I decided to work the flirty, brow-skimming sideswept fringe as is. Even though I wore my wig out of the store 7 hours before the Halfway to Mardi Gras event began, it stayed in place all night, into the wee hours. Work!

It was great fun darting through the Quarter, collecting the approving (and/or curious) glances of many passerby as I hurried to find a cab in between raindrops. And I can't wait to do it again - I think buying a new wig (and a different, more mysterious 'me' for just one night!) on every trip to NOLA is a tradition worth adopting.

Nail Club is the crème de la crème of nail salons. Honestly, I've never experienced a salon where the technicians are so detail-oriented and customer-focused. They offer a menu of deluxe pedicures, and I think the Milk and Money is my favorite. Their foot massages are neverending and so very blissful. I would come here just to purchase a stand-alone foot massage, they are that good! 

Awesome spa chairs, super clean salon and a fantastic array of nail colors. Nail Club has won over my heart and my toes!

Because I don't care for the long, haphazard lines, the gobs of tourists or the camp of pigeons at Café Du Monde, getting my hands on a beignet and café au lait then escaping to nearby Jackson Square is top-of-mind when I awake in New Orleans.

Café Du Monde's to-go window alleviates much of the irritation but then there's still the line: You have to put in your time; there is no other way. The wait eventually produces a bag of beignets and I smugly trot off, fleeing the coop of crowds and chaos.

Jackson Square is the destination and I find an empty bench, take a bite of my beignet and savor this arcane view of the world through the patchy fog. The illuminated lamps, the wrought iron architecture, the Andrew Jackson statue and the silhouette of the beautiful St. Louis Cathedral... baby it's a scene, all right.

But unlike a photo, this scene is best viewed blurry. Come early morning so you can catch fog's blanket cradling the lovely square before she wakes up - it's worth staying up all night for.

Laid-back bar meets gastropub-level food.
Cozy booths.
Good crowd.
Specials every day of the week.

These are a few of my favorite things (when it comes to finding the ideal bar, anyway) :)

My cousin and I wandered into the Red Lion on a lazy Sunday evening (thanks to a quick search on Yelp, natch). We were quite hungry, and in the mood for a good beer. His only real requirement: a bar with TVs suitable for catching the football game. Well, Red Lion has a huge projection screen and a few plasmas so no suffering was endured. 

Our server gave us the best news of the night: happy hour specials run all day on Sundays! Half off all beer and appetizers... score! We split the toasted ravs (not your mama's toasted ravs, mind you, these are filled with pork and beef and served with a cheese dipping sauce). We then moved on to California burgers for both of us. The burgers were delicious and cooked to perfection, our only gripe was that we didn't see/taste any of the promised avocado paste on 'em. Still very good, though.

Service was super friendly and despite having only three beers on draft, they've got a decent bottled beer selection. Love the New Belgium 1554!

If you're looking for atmosphere, then keep walking. But if you're looking for a strong cup of coffee, a spot to get your gossip on with friends and you don't mind feeling like you're in a different world for a few hours, then you'll be quite happy at Korzo.

The coffeehouse is Bosnian-owned, so you can expect a lot of smoking as well as Bosnian music (this afternoon, we heard Croatian music). It's cash only, with a smattering of tables to engage in aforementioned gossiping (for us people from the Balkans, it's a legitimate pastime). The digs may not be fancy, but you'll never feel rushed. Free wi-fi, too! It can get a bit too smoky in the winter so stop by in the summertime for an outdoor table if you're easily affected. Me? I can deal.

I mean.... G&W is a local legend! Not only do they produce an outstanding portfolio of encased meats, but simply visiting the shop is an experience. If you're lucky, you'll be offered an ice cold can of Busch beer whilst waiting in line. While I no longer drink beer, I still appreciate the kitschy locally-relevant gesture. And if you check in on Yelp (at press time, anyway), you'll get a free G&W branded koozie. Too fun!

Back to the sausage: you MUST get the jalapeño cheddar bratwurst! Best bratwurst on earth. They also sell wonderful kraut which we use to make our take on the Bavarian-style with G&W knockwurst at home. Make sure to browse the shelves, where you'll find a smattering of authentic German products, from spätzle to mustard.

Pro tip: arrive right when they open to avoid waiting in a long queue! This place is legit and immensely popular with in-the-know locals. Trust.

Mud House: you have a new fan!

I rolled in here a bit hungry, and sadly under-caffeinated. Though Abby S isn't a coffee drinker, she promised me good joe. Besides espresso drinks, they also offer French Press served with a bottle of water and a housemade pastry for $7. Sweet deal!

Mud House serves breakfast all day long, and I opted for the granola with yogurt and fresh fruit. It was a perfect portion of gooey granola goodness -- sweet satiation.

If you're working, they offer free wi-fi as well as outlets aplenty. Cozy, comfy and a bit quirky... I like your digs, Mud House.

Great little spot in the Quarter if you're seeking a classic po' boy, strong cocktails and a lively scene but sans the heavy overtures of eau de tourist - what a happy find!

We came in on a Saturday, without much time but plenty hungry... and because we only had about 45 minutes before we needed to jet to our next destination, our lunch had to be a somewhat snappy one. The very antithesis of Louisiana dining, yes?

But our bartender extraordinaire hooked us up with front row seats at the bar and got to work on our drinks stat - a strawberry Covington ale for me and a fancy Mardi Gras-themed cocktail for my friend (maybe a bit too sweet for my taste, but he seemed to really enjoy it).

And oh wow, the food. Admittedly, I was a bit put off when I saw that po' boys here will run you $13-$16, but luckily, they were good. VERY good. Try the French Fry po' by with roast beef 'debris' gravy or the fried shrimp laced with rosemary... we couldn't put 'em down. And even the sweet potatoes were perfect - no sog; just the perfect balance of crispy and chewy.

In the end, lunch can get somewhat spendy here but the space is a reprieve from the typical tourist-laden joints in this neighborhood and the drinks and food are spot-on.

Balkan food alert!

Because both of my parents are from Croatia, I grew up on Balkan dishes such as sarma, cheese pita, pršut, punjena paprika, and fritule. I actually didn't try ćevapčići until I was well into my teens - once the Bosnians started settling in the St. Louis area during and after the Yugoslav Wars, they brought with them Balkan food of their own flavor. And while some Croatians do make cevaps, I've always considered them to be much more of a thing within the Bosnian and Serbian households - where they're considered a national dish. And I'm not too big to admit that they do make them better :)

Politics aside, ćevapčići are one of my favorite Balkan treats. These skinless sausages are made with minced beef and lamb (Serbians and Croatians often add pork as a third meat) served on top of a grilled homemade flatbread called lepinja, along with accoutrements such as chopped white onions (raw), ajvar (roasted red pepper and eggplant spread), and/or kajmak (similar to clotted cream but a bit saltier). Curious now?

My parents recently dropped by Biser to surprise my sister, me and her kids with a few orders of cevaps. While the sausages were a little dry, the flavor was great and the lepinja bread was perfectly baked and then finished on a hot grill. They were served with sour cream instead of kajmak, but that's a typical substitute in St. Louis as kajmak is quite labor-intensive. 

Next time, I hope we can get our hands on some of their freshly-baked burek and pita! Last time they were sold out of these popular items, which I'll take as a good sign.

Have you ever went for a drink of water in the middle of the night, only to spit it out because it turned out to be Sprite? The taste isn't bad; it's just that you weren't expecting it.

That's how I feel about this property - it's much different than other Aloft properties, but that's also a-okay. Until very recently, this hotel was a Hotel Indigo and though it may pass as all Aloft in the lobby, once you get to your room you might find yourself scratching your head, 'did I check into the wrong hotel?'. 

The room is very nicely-appointed - in fact, it's a much more sophisticated design scheme than the typical Aloft style. Better linens, hardwood floors, Keurig coffeemaker, chic lamp... and, the water pressure is strong enough to get your hair squeaky clean and the bathroom comes equipped with a freakishly-strong hairdryer. I approve!

Despite all the niceties, something is still lacking... part of the reason why I really enjoy staying at Starwood properties is their employee culture positively impacts every one of my stays. I realize the transition just happened several months ago, but there's still some lingering customer service issues (there was a mix-up on their part in which they only booked me 1 night instead of 2, though I had the email confirmation) and a certain warmth is missing. For just a few bucks more, you could stay at the Hutton across the street and get an A+ boutique hotel experience. Though I love my SPG points, the savings aren't deep enough to justify a ho-hum stay.

Sorry guys - I generally adore Aloft properties but this one is just a little off.

One of the best patios in St. Louis! Seriously, if people-watching was a sport, then Bar Italia's patio is the World Cup champion.
