I ordered a chicken empanada and lechon asado with rice and beans and tostones. I was hoping for Cuban bread, and it actually comes on the platter, not before the meal, so don't get disappointed. The empanada was tasty and crispy. I was underwhelmed with my platter. The bread was good and so were the tostones. But the rice and beans and lechon were not super flavorful and sort of dry. I asked for a side of mojo, which made it better. I was also unimpressed with my friend's ropa vieja.

I might try a sandwich from here, as the bread was really good, and I noticed many take-out sandwich orders. But I wouldn't get a full entree here again.

I will visit Longwood Gardens anytime - it is absolutely beautiful. I was here in early November, on a rather rainy day, unfortunately. I had been wanting to visit, especially due to the perfume exhibit, and luckily, Ariela M. had the same day off as I did, so a quick trip to Philly & Longwood Gardens was in store for me. 

The outside grounds are gorgeous, even without flowers and waterfalls in November. The inside gardens were just as amazing. My favorite was the orchids, of course! 

I had been wanting to see the perfume exhibit, as I am obsessed with perfumes. It was small, but with nice information on scents and perfumeries, as well as a beautiful perfume bottle display of some of the most popular perfumes and prettiest perfume bottles. Though I had been to a perfume bottle museum before, I never tire of seeing the bottles and thinking about new fragrances. 

The cafe was nice and the meals looked tempting, though we only split a slice of pecan pie. The Pierre du Pont house was also nice to walk through, especially as we needed to get out of the cold. A really cute cat lives there! The shop had some really pretty home decor, if you are into flowers. I must get back in the summertime!

I really enjoyed Dook's Place. To clarify, since I couldn't find a website for them, the MSY website sucks, and Yelpers, per usual, are confused: this is NOT Dooky Chase's airport location, which is close to Concourse C. This is an offshoot from his grandson, and is before security in Concourse B, the Southwest terminal. It looks like the only good place to eat, aside from its more famous namesake.

Dook's Place is nice. It's well-lit with a nice bar and colorful artwork. The R&B was bumping and service was good. They kindly made the modifications to my chicken sandwich with no problem. I didn't get to try a drink, but from what I saw, they looked good. I loved my fried chicken sandwich and fries. That sandwich was on point--the chicken was hot, crispy, and flavorful. Fries were great. I'd be happy to return and try more on the menu.

MSY lacks in many areas, most notably dining. If you are going to be hungry before or after your flight, come early/stay late to eat here. The food and ambiance are great and it's also one of the only good options.

I've been to my share of convention centers and this is one of the worst. Yes, it's one of the biggest, but who cares? I never attend a convention here. The design, both interior and exterior, is extremely dated. The food court offerings are awful. In a city known for it's food, at least you could offer excellent food, but not here. And there isn't even any good food right outside, so if you are at the center, you can't leave to grab something good (unless you have plenty of time and can hit up Cochon). It's not in an awful location, but you do have to walk at least a few blocks to find some good food. 

A convention center, much like an airport, can really represent a city, and this one (also much like the New Orleans airport), does not. At least it's named for Morial (the first African-American mayor of New Orleans) and you can hire a jazz band. That's all I got.

I was super hungry and Royal House had no wait, so I stopped in. I was excited to try the shrimp Creole, as it was near the end of my trip, and this was one dish I still had yet to try. I thought it was was just OK. The shrimp were not the big, beautiful Gulf shrimp I was expecting and the sauce had little flavor. It also took a really long time to prepare, given that the restaurant was not that full. Those around me mostly ordered sandwiches, and I wish I had gone that route. Service was really good, though. There are better restaurants in the Quarter.

Backatown is a really cute coffee shop. It's warm, with great music and a great vibe. It's also popular. I was there around 9:30 a.m. on a weekday and it was fairly full. I ordered an iced caramel latte with almond milk. I tried to get a pastry, but they were out of everything except for like a random muffin. The barista was super rude and unfriendly. All she did to make my latte was pour some coffee from a pitcher in the fridge and add milk and caramel sauce. It was as gross as it sounds. Someone told me this place isn't even owned by a local. There's definitely better coffee in New Orleans.

When heading to New Orleans, Commander's Palace was my absolute must-go. I did not care where else I ate, but I knew I had to eat here. What I wish I had done was watched "Ella Brennan: Commanding the Table" before dining here. If you choose to dine here, or anywhere in New Orleans, really, it should be required viewing. As someone who heavily follows food and dining culture (many don't really have food knowledge and understanding but consider themselves "foodies"), I of course knew bits and pieces of the Commander's Palace story, but the documentary really brings everything together.

You need reservations and you need to be dressed appropriately. I recommend calling, as I had trouble with their website. The reservationists are amazing. The service here is nonpareil. I've dined in several fine dining restaurants, throughout the world, and have had excellent service, but it goes above and beyond at Commander's. What they understand is that there is a proper way to serve, but that fine dining is never haughty. It's elegant and refined, yes, but never pretentious. And that right there is crucial. It's what makes Commander's Palace shine. From before I entered the building to when I entered my rideshare, the service was superior, but I always felt welcomed.

The entire restaurant is opulent. From lush gardens to a gorgeous dining room and a beautiful tablescape, it's exactly what I expected. I dream of dining in the courtyard and at the chef's table in the kitchen. 

It goes without saying that the food was fantastic. I had one a drink, that classic New Orleans Sazerac, and it was perfection. I really appreciate the offering of a prix-fixe menu, and my companion and I went with that option. It had exactly what I was looking for: gumbo, redfish, and the bread pudding. The gumbo was rich and hearty and I had all I could do not to eat it all, or all of the warm bread served with it. I love, love, love redfish, and this preparation with potatoes and vegetables was well-sauced and well-seasoned, and the crab topping gave the dish extra panache. For dessert, I actually wanted the strawberry shortcake or pecan pie, but decided I should go with the bread pudding souffle. It was sweet and delicious, but I personally would have been happier with the aforementioned options. However, if you are a bread pudding fan, you must order it here. 

The entire Commander's Palace experience was incredible. I don't often revisit restaurants in cities which I do not live; however, I will be returning each and every time I visit New Orleans.

Zahav, long-known as one of the premier dining destinations in the United States, was recently bestowed yet another award, this time as the 2019 James Beard's Outstanding Restaurant. Zahav has also long been on my list of places to dine and while I do not get to Philadelphia as often as I'd like, I did vow that the next time I was there, I would go to Zahav, and I made good on that promise.

I love Israeli cuisine and Zahav offers a comprehensive tour of its many delights. Between Cook's and Solomonov's restaurants and cookbooks, along with "In Search of Israeli Cuisine", these two have positioned themselves as experts in this cuisine, which is clearly depicted in this award-winning restaurant. 

As for Zahav's infamous wait, I got there at 4:00 p.m. on a Friday (albeit, the day after Thanksgiving) and was the third party in line (the two prior parties had just arrived). I was in a party of two and we were in the first bar seating. There are 16 bar seats and four chef's counter seats, so do note for a visit without reservations.

The service, drink, and food were nonpareil. The hospitality was apparent from when were warmly and kindly welcomed into the restaurant, with the hostess noting how pleased they were to have us, along with greeting us with bags of spiced, roasted chickpeas. The bartenders do a great job of explaining the drinks and the tasting menu. We did the Tayim (tasting menu) and I wasn't sure it was going to be enough food, but it was more than enough. It really doesn't make sense not to do the tasting menu, which at the bar and with three drinks each took us about two hours or so.  

An amuse bouche of pickled vegetables was perfect to whet the appetite. The standouts include the warm, seasoned laffa and creamy, delicious Turkish hummus, along with the crispy haloumi and the delectable fried cauliflower. The savory salatim accompanied everything nicely. I loved our desserts--a decadent chocolate konafi and a sweet apple cake. Plus, you leave with a to-go cookie, which is, as we say in Hebrew, "sababa". Our drinks were great too, with my favorite being the Z&T, an za'atar-infused gin and tonic. I'm za'atar obsessed so this was great. They also offer wine from my favorite Israeli vineyard, the gorgeous and excellent Golan Heights Winery.

Zahav means "gold" in Hebrew; here, you will be treated to a golden experience. I'm looking forward to visiting again whenever I return to Philadelphia (and hopefully trying the lamb and the hazelnut cake).

I think this is apropos for review #1400.  After all, it's me writing about alcohol, my second favorite subject (makeup being the first).

The Corsair Distillery tour is fun and light-hearted, and full of lots of information about the distilling process.  I can't remember our guide's name, but he was great.  The tour doesn't last long, but it's interesting.  You can bring a beer from the taproom in with you.  

After the tour, you get samples in the beautiful tasting room.  My favorite was the Triple Smoke Whiskey.  It's smooth and smoky, and I'm obsessed.  You can stay for a cocktail after the tasting, but we did not, because that was enough hair of the dog for me, but I now wish I had.  All of the staff we encountered were friendly.  If you love whiskey, you must do this tour.

I've had hot chicken once, so I don't have much to compare to.  And unfortunately, I still really don't, because staff at my hotel recommended the mild version, saying that it was still quite hot.  I did not find the mild version to have any amount of spice, whatsoever.  So, if you have any type of tolerance for heat, start with the hot (200 degrees).  

However, the chicken itself was super crisp outside and still tender inside.  And the leg quarter with crinkle fries was huge.  I could not stop eating it, and even though I wanted more, I was super full when I was done.  The chicken takes about twenty minutes to make, so do not go here completely famished, like I did.  

I cannot say enough about the friendliness of the staff.  I think I even got to chat with the owner briefly!  I'm just sad I didn't get back to try the spicier version.

I'd actually say more like 3.5 stars.  It's really good ice cream, but I was not floored by it.  If you're an ice cream fanatic like me, I definitely recommend checking out Jeni's.  The flavor combinations are interesting, which I love.  I went with the brown butter almond brittle and wildberry lavender.  It was a nice a mix, because the sweet berry flavor definitely balances the richer brown butter.  The cone piece was a nice add-on, and probably the best waffle cone I've tasted.

Staff was extremely kind and patient as we tried many flavors.  They were also very explanatory, which is helpful.  The line moved fast and I appreciate the cucumber infused water.

I love Philadelphia because of the historic character, the shopping, and most importantly, BYOB.  And if BYOB brunch doesn't sound fantastic, I don't know what does.  

Wedge+Fig is an extremely cute restaurant in the Old City.  It's back patio can only be described as charming and intimate, with small tables and trellised brick walls.  Service was attentive and friendly.

Three girls brought two bottles of champagne to brunch and we weren't sure it would be enough (but since we all like our mimosas with just a splash of orange juice, it was).  They'll chill your bottles for you, which is a nice touch.  Everything on the brunch menu sounded fantastic, but I went with something I so rarely find:  a make-your-own breakfast sandwich (brunch bar).  It comes with greens and potatoes, which is great.  And Sahar and Victoria went with the same, though someone (Sahar, I believe) ordered double cheese, and that's the way to go.  My sandwich was gouda, tomato, and bacon on white and was delicious.  Potatoes were crisp and greens were fresh.

We ended up getting kicked out because we had a Tanqueray nip with us, and during our last round of mimosas, topped it off with the gin.  While I suppose that's our fault for not reading the rules, I wish we were not lied to and told it was because there was a wait.  There was definitely no wait.  

Not sure I'd return because of that, but I might because Wedge+Fig is definitely delicious.

This is basically an outdoor mall, with plenty of chain restaurants and bars that were open, yet empty on a Saturday night. It was after 9 p.m. and a handful of patrons were in each restaurant, plus there were children running around. 

It's in a good location, and it's nice, plus there's parking, but there's no need to ever come here, unless perhaps you are starving after an aquarium or arena visit.

This was my last stop on my way out of town. I love carousels, so the idea of a carousel-themed bar was definitely appealing. It's in the Hotel Monteleone and I walked through the hotel lobby to get to the bar (not sure if there is a separate entrance as well, but I also needed luggage storage). The staff of both the hotel and the bar provided amazing service. 

I was going to sit at the bar, but then decided a window alcove with plush seating was preferable. I ended up just having one fantastically-made Vieux Carre, though I wanted two. The window seat was nice because I could people-watch those both outside and inside. The bar chairs are ornately painted, so it was fun to watch those go by, though the well-lit, intricately-designed top of the bar is the most reminiscent of a carousel.

I visited around 1:30 p.m. on a Thursday afternoon. There were a few seats at the bar, as well as a few window seats, so that seems like a good time to visit, though it's too early for the live music. Since it's touristy, it's not a dressy spot, despite being a high-end bar (and hotel). I look forward to returning next time I'm in New Orleans.

No frills, low-key sports bar in Clearwater Beach. Friendly staff and inexpensive food and drink make it a chill place. Late on a Wednesday night, this place had a decent crowd and was still serving. And, I did see a tropical bird, which I guess is a toucan.

Drinks are strong, which is always a plus. Typical bar food is good, and my chicken sandwich was one of the better versions I've had. However, it doesn't come with fries, so be sure to ask if you are ordering a non-burger sandwich. My friends shared their fries, and they were tasty.

If you need a place to relax and have a drink, visit Toucans.

Cute, bright, cozy coffee shop that we found on our way to brunch.  Hipster staff was super friendly, so I was happy and impressed.  You usually don't get that with the hipsters.  They have almond milk, which is awesome, and my iced almond milk mocha latte was delicious.  There was plenty of seating, which is nice, though we didn't stay.  I'll keep Menagerie in mind during future Philadelphia visits.

This store is really cute.  They offer a great selection of OPI, NYX, and Essie, along with a myriad of other products, such as Deva and Smith's.  It's not a beauty supply, so prices are retail.  The discounted OPI bin was not really that cheap, so that was disappointing. Staff was friendly enough. But I'd visit again when in the area.

Great liquor store. They have everything you need, in a variety of sizes, and more, plus the prices are fantastic. My only suggestion would be to carry more local/Florida beers. They also sell some tasty look snacks--cheese, crackers, etc., which is helpful.

I found the younger staff to be friendlier and more helpful than the older staff, so if you have questions, ask them. The older staff was a bit rude and failed to answer my questions or help me find what I was looking for. However, it's a great store for all your boozy desires.

Crema makes a fantastic latte.  I had a plain latte with the almond-coconut milk, and loved it.  It was strong and a tad bitter, so I added some sugar in the raw, which helped.  I loved it though, and there was a great foam on top.  The chocolate croissant was flaky and filled with a fantastic rich chocolate.  I highly recommend getting your caffeine fix here.

This is the place to get your day party on. Right on the water, it's the perfect spot to drink, eat, and play volleyball. With the music blasting and drinks flowing, it was a good time. Well, from what I remember of it anyway.

Our service wasn't the best, and in general, it's slower service than I'm used to, so I recommend ordering right away. Drinks are strong--I don't remember what I ordered, but it was whatever drink special they had going ($6 Stoli or something, I believe). 

Food was typical bar food. I thought the calamari was great. Too many mussels were cracked/unopened for my liking. Pizza was fine. You really come here to drink, in case you haven't garnered that by now.

I really look forward to coming back here during my next visit.

This truck offers pierogies and empanadas.  Empanadas have some unusual fillings while the pierogies are your classic potato and cheese, albeit deep fried.  The pierogies are good and well-filled, but could use way more cheese.  The 20 minutes wait (line plus cook time) isn't great, but if you don't mind waiting, it's a good snack.

Both the food and service at Barbuzzo were outstanding. Our server was over-the-top friendly and helpful and extremely knowledgeable about the menu. The restaurant is very small and tables are very close. Low lights and wood decor lends itself to a hip, relaxing ambiance. 

We shared the sheep's milk ricotta appetizer (server's recommendation), and then I had the pacherri and my friend had the ravioli.  The ricotta was salty and creamy, and great on the toasted bread.   I was hoping for more burratta in the pacherri, but it was rich and filling anyways. Ravioli was excellent as well. Portions are small and meant to be shared, but the pasta was filling and the perfect size. We shared the caramel budino for dessert - it was delicious and I do not like pudding type desserts at all. Cocktail list was small, but very interesting - as in I want to go back to try one!

I love this bridge. It's super cool looking and really fun to drive over. Speed limit is low though. The views are amazing. I'm always taken aback by how beautiful this area is. I definitely look forward to driving over this bridge on my road trips.

I really loved my walking tour. Two Chicks was recommend by my sister and I did their St. Louis Cemetery #1 tour. Now, I do regret going to the cemetery because it was boring and a waste of my time. But the tour guide, Steve, was great. And he lives in New Orleans, which I appreciate. I don't want a tour from someone who doesn't live in the city. He was funny and knowledgeable and could answer our questions. Plus, I didn't have cash on me and he took Venmo for my tip, which was super appreciated. I would absolutely do a Two Chicks Walking Tour again (they offer a variety of tours to choose from), but just for something I actually want to see.

Morimoto has the uber-chic, trendy atmosphere that I love, but here, that comes with the uppity service that I hate, which is not always the case at a restaurant like this.  Hosts were not friendly.  The server's attitude was that of "If you have questions about the menu, I don't care to answer, and if you aren't spending hundreds of dollars, I don't care to be friendly".  You know that saying of "looking down your nose at someone"?  That's exactly how I felt with our server here (once it was obvious that our bill was only going be in the low hundreds).  The only good thing about our server was that she knew correct service style and placement. 
 
The food was very good, with the whitefish carpaccio with yuzu being the favorite.  It really does melt-in-your-mouth (as did the other dishes) and I recommend eating the pea shoot accompaniment with the sauce as well.  My hamachi rolls were mostly hamachi, which is appreciated.  I love black cod, and this version, paired with a miso mustard, disappeared quickly.  It's obvious that all of the fish here is super fresh and tasty, and I would expect nothing less.  The carafe of sake held a decent amount, and the one we chose went well with our entire order.  Dessert was great--miso honeycake with shiso, vanilla ice cream, fruit compote, and spun sugar.  Honeycake was delicious and the vanilla ice cream rich and flavorful.  Yet, for as tasty as the food was, I remain underwhelmed.    

Dim lighting, sleek design, and ambient music are nice touches, but awful service and paying for a name brand didn't impress me.  There are better restaurants to choose from in Philadelphia.

We stopped in for a brief snack before going to Corsair.  I and another friend had the Ahi tuna tacos, and another companion had the ceviche.  The ceviche and tuna were super fresh, which is appreciated, and overall, we liked our snacks  The chips and salsa were delicious, as they use a thicker chip, which I love.  The menu is not as pricey as I would expect, given the modern, upscale feel of the place.

Service was slow, and after we mentioned we had a time limit, our server seemed to have an attitude.  I don't recommend making this a destination, but if you need to stop in, you probably wouldn't be disappointed.

Being one of the newest places in Nashville, Acme is extremely popular.  While we were standing in line to order (you order at a counter and then sit at a table and wait for your food), I noticed the hostess, mocking a patron who had left in the midst of some type of tantrum or breakdown, to the security guard.  My friend noticed as well, and that sealed the deal of us not eating here.  It's too bad, because the menu looked interesting and the place had a fun vibe.  However, that type of behavior, while not acceptable from the patron, was extremely unacceptable and inappropriate from Acme staff.

This is such a cute little shop in the French Quarter. I wasn't hungry, but wish I had been, as the food menu looked good. I did have a great, well-made almond milk caramel latte. Staff was friendly and I'd return if in the area.

Not the worst tacos, but not the best either. They are alright, and I'm guessing had I been drinking, these would be better.

I tried a few tacos (al pastor, chicken, fish) and chips with salsa and guacamole. Chips/salsa/guac was good. Tacos are bland and not all that exciting. Even my sister, Stacey M., who had been on a hunger strike all day, was less than impressed.

However, I would not turn away after a late night.

I flew Southwest for both my arrival and departure at MSY. Concourse B is entirely devoted to Southwest, which is nice. The concourse is large, quite cold, and a bit dated. Bathrooms are small and far apart (one bathroom only has three stalls), but they were clean and I appreciate the automatic seat covers. I also appreciate that Southwest offers skycap service here. There's two Hudson stores, which is nice. And a Benefit kiosk. But that's about all that's good there. I arrived early for my flight to eat (Dook's Place, just before security) and work. I couldn't connect my phone or my laptop to the wifi or VPN. The waiting areas at the gates are small.

I'll repeat what others have said: it's disappointing that MSY lacks any notable food options, besides Dooky Chase's and Dook's Place. It's also surprising, given the food-focused nature of the city. Also, the airport website is incredibly dated and sorely needs updating. 

I thought the ground crews were a bit slow, as it took a while to get luggage. Directions to the rideshare area are extremely poor and hard to find.

MSY desperately needs modernizing. New Orleans is a hip, funky city and the airport in no way reflects that. An airport is usually a traveler's first impression of the city and MSY leaves a poor one.

I love Ensemble.  It's a cute boutique with amazing prices and a friendly, welcoming owner.  I ended buying some cold-weather accessories and a foundation piece here.  The clothes are cute, and I'd describe them as trendy with a bit of a Southern/country flair.  It's a great place to shop, and I wish there was one in DC.

What a great place to grab a slice or two (or a whole pie). I was somewhat boring and just got two cheese slices, but they were great. Crust could've been a bit crispier, but they were served piping hot and with plenty of cheese. 

It's nothing fancy, but I'm reminded of the pizza parlors of my childhood. I'm told they deliver, but not sure what the area is. Staff was very gracious and friendly.

Cochon is excellent. I walked in during a convention Sunday without a reservation. Wait for one was about an hour, but I was able to get a seatt at the bar in less than ten minutes, so I ate at the bar.

I started with the Smoke on the Water, a mezcal based cocktail with smoked salt. It wasn't as smoky as I had hoped, but it was refreshing, and strong. I ordered the cochon as my main, with a side of greens. It was a tough choice, as the rabbit and dumplings was super appealing and I love a good courtbouillon. But I figured that I needed to order the namesake dish.

They start you with a soft bread and creamy butter that is out of this world. I could've eaten that and died happy. The cochon is huge, smoky, and flavorful. The cracklins and cabbage provide a delicious textural contrast. And the greens are perfectly tender. I ordered the German chocolate cake to-go and that was underwhelming. It was bad, but just compared to how amazing everything else was, I would order an appetizer instead of dessert when I return. 

I would also definitely make a reservation to sit at a table. The bartenders were fine, but a packed bar, with most patrons eating dinner, is tough on service. But they were friendly enough, my order was correct, and my drink was great.  

When in New Orleans, Cochon is not to be missed.

Honeymoon Island is beautiful, and I felt like I was on a tropical island. Well, somewhat, anyway. The water is not as pretty as some pictures make it seem, and the beach (we were in the Oasis part, I believe) had nice sand, but the shore was rocky. It was quiet and relaxing, and alcohol is not allowed (not that I tried to bring any). 

I'd love to get back and check out the trails, though the rattlesnake signs scare me. I did think it was prettier than Clearwater Beach, though, and it is worth a trip if you are visiting the area.

Best place to eat in Terminal E - the other options are quite lame.  They were out of Shocktop; I had a 6 row honey weizen that I liked.  

Food menu was limited; I went for the pulled pork sandwich and fries.  It was small, so if you are ravenous, you might need something else.  But it was tasty - the roll was toasted, which is always appreciated, and the beer-based BBQ sauce on the shredded pork was thick and tangy.  Fries were crisp.

Service was awful (not friendly, dirty tables) and it took 45 minutes for my food to arrive.  However, the small restaurant and bar were packed, with one server and one cook, so I blame poor management, not the staff.  If ever at STL on a layover again, I'd go here.

Dooky Chase's storied reputation made it a must-stop on my trip to New Orleans, and I'm glad it was. Not only to honor Leah Chase, but to honor everything this restaurant stands for. And because I really liked the food.

I went for the lunch buffet and quite enjoyed it. It's reasonably priced and has a variety of offerings, and I'd stick to that. I went with the greens, fried chicken, red beans and rice, and salad. The soup was chicken vegetable and the dessert was peach cobbler. The greens and fried chicken were great. I could barely eat and still had to get seconds. The chicken vegetable soup was extremely fresh. And the peach cobbler was rich and flavorful, and one of my favorite versions.

The decor is is nice, but worn. The artwork is great. The hostesses are insanely nice and friendly--I tried to be as nice to them as they were to me. My server was good, but I experienced what others have--she disappeared. And when I needed hot sauce it was a while before I saw anyone on the floor that I could flag. So service could definitely be more attentive. I arrived around 11:40 on a Wednesday, and in about ten minutes, Dooky's was packed, so that seems to be the right time to arrive. 

I'd go back for the lunch buffet anytime and you can find me dreaming about that cobbler.

Three stars because this store isn't great. It's still a La Colombe and I love it but it's tiny and it was crowded and noisy at 2 p.m. Nowhere to sit and you could barely get in line. I much prefer the Rittenhouse location. This location is convenient but the setup is awful and combined with the crowds, it was hell. Staff was friendly despite the out-of-order espresso machine, which was impressive. I guess that's when the draft lattes truly come in handy. Great staff but I'd skip this location in the future.

The Row was a good choice for lunch.  Our server, whose name I wish I remembered, was fantastic, especially when I need to sample several beers before choosing.  I eventually chose a Yazoo, but forget which one--it was great though.

We started with the fried pickles, which I never like, but these were super tasty, and as a non-pickle eater, I would eat these again.  I ordered the Nashville hot chicken with a spicy corn cake and bacon mac and cheese.  The chicken was good--I ordered a heat level of hot, which was spicy, but not overly so.  However, the bacon mac and cheese was perfect, with the right amount of bacon and well-cooked macaroni. My sister liked her veggie burger (and I liked her fries) and our friends enjoyed their chicken-fried chicken.

The whole vibe of The Row is friendly and welcoming, and it's definitely music-themed, which I loved.

The coffee here is great. Totally not what I was expecting--off a busy road, with not a lot of parking, and not much else nearby. But we all got iced lattes and loved them. It was a well-balanced, tasty drink.

Pastries looked great, and staff was friendly. It was better than the two coffee shops I tried in Tampa, and I'd go here over those two any day.

I love a great sandwich and DiNic's shaved pork with provolone is one of those sandwiches.  It's huge and filled with plenty of delicious pork and cheese.  The bread is great, too.  My only regret?  Not adding the broccoli rabe.  But I will next time.

Whiskey Kitchen seems to be Nashville's hot spot, in one of the hottest neighborhoods, The Gulch.  While I can't figure out why The Gulch is so popular (maybe because it's new?), I can see why Whiskey Kitchen is popular.  The hip, sexy vibe inside and relaxed patio make it a fun choice.  Would I deal with the two hour wait time if I lived here?  Absolutely not--this isn't a restaurant that warrants that long of a wait, but it is good.  But since I was visiting, I didn't care.

We ended up snagging some spots on the patio in about 40 minutes.  I love the heat lamps that make the patio open year-round.  Our server was really sweet.  I started with the blackberry julep--tasty, but not strong.  Maybe skip the drinks here.  For food, we started with yam fries.  It's a huge serving, and even with four famished females, finishing it just wasn't in the cards.  I got the shrimp and grits with a side of the Tennessee cheddar bacon ale soup as my main course.  The shrimp were decently-sized and not overcooked.  The entire dish was flavorful with the right amount of heat.  But that soup.  I'm not soup person, but when I saw that it was made with Yazoo, which I'd had a day earlier, something told me to try it.  It was rich and the perfect balance of tangy and savory.  I found a lone fry to dip in it, and that was a fantastic choice.  Get the soup. I tried my friend's mac and cheese which was also great. And my sister and friends enjoyed their meals, as well.   

But get the damn soup.

I was expecting greasy, lackluster bar food here and was very pleasantly surprised to enjoy delicious, creative, gourmet food instead! My favorite dish was the smoked trout wontons, but really everything was pretty amazing. Loved the chocolate lava cake. I'll definitely make a point to come back here the next time I take the train to Philly.

I stopped in because I was famished from my 3&1/2 hour drive and had some time before my friend's wedding. The place is SOOO adorable!  As soon as my bf and I walked in, we were greeted by a friendly face. The lady behind the counter gave us a sample to try. Delicious!  I opted for the plain croissant and it was SOOO delicious. Crispy, flaky exterior with a butter and fluffy interior. Yummmmy! :)  I will definitely have to revisit! :)

Beautiful place for a wedding. Parking right outside (first 75 minutes free) or park across the street in the parking structure (first 75 minutes free and $1.50 for every hour after).
There are many floors and hidden gems in this beautiful space. I attended a wedding in the Mural Room and it was stunning.  The judge who married my friends was stellar and even came around to say hello to the rows of attendees before the start.  They have a clock tower here and the history behind it is fascinating. You can also go to the very top and see a beautiful 360 view of Santa Barbara. Truly a great space for guests to entertain themselves and enjoy Santa Barbara. This is preservation and history at its finest.

$16 AYCE Lunch, $22 AYCE Dinner.

Walked in with a party of 7. Got seated at the bar within 15 mins. The bar was the best BC we all had our own space and we could all order at our convenience since there are several dedicated staff members to whip out all your desired food! 
Service: 5 stars
Ease of parking: 5 stars
Nigiri: 
Hamachi- 5 stars
Albacore- 5 stars
Appetizers: 
Tempura Stuffed Calamari- 4 stars 
Moondog Stars- 4 stars
Rolls:
How We Roll- 4 stars
Happy Roll- 3.5 stars
Dessert:
Happy Ending- 2 stars (I personally wasn't a fan).
Coconut & Strawberry Parfait- 3.5 stars (Don't forget to offset the sweetness by eating it with the fried wonton skins).
Orange with optional Plum Wine- 5 stars! (Fruits and dessert wine? Yes, please!)

I'm really happy I decided to try this place and it lives up to it's "best sushi in Reno" awards! :)

I tried their most popular veggie pizza... The garden pizza... I really did not like it. Granted I am a pizza snob and have gone on pizza tours and grew up with NY pizza but the garden pizza had way too many things on it. The sauce was sour. The crust was too crunchy. Bleh... But to each their own I guess.
Really yummy burger. I ordered the DOOBIN' LOOBIN just because it contains pork, sausage, and brisket... drools.

Yay they deliver! With a minimum of $10. Credit card use with minimum of $15. 

First time to have a Chinese fast food place that tastes like actual chinese food. I had house special mai fun which had the fire taste of the wok without all the oil that is normally expected in such a dish. The Vegetable delight was also yummy. None of the dishes were overly salty, which have been my experience with any Chinese take out. 

The only thing I didn't like was that they forgot to give me utensils. Luckily the hotel had two coffee stirrers which I used as makeshift chopsticks... umm it was very interesting eating with such short "utensils"...

The food is amazing! They were very accommodating. I went there with 8 other people an hour before they closed. We ordered one of everything. The food came out pretty quickly considering it was made by one person. The menu was small but everything is delicious. I would definitely go back there again next time I am in town.

Decent quality. The Siu Mai does not look nor tastes like Siu Mai. The salad was drenched in dressing. The miso soup have a hint of bitter tasted but then I have very sensitive taste buds. I ordered the Chirachi bowl which lets me taste the quality of the fishes. Half of them tasted fresh. The other half was okay. So overall assessment... Eh... It's okay. Disclaimer: I'm use to the standards in NYC, and Los Angeles.
Amazing food and gluten friendly too. Go there with friends so that you can pig out on all the yummy appetizers. This is the first time that I had southern food and I am highly impressed by it.

Yummy thai food... love the drunken noodles even though I ordered it non-spicy it was still flavorful. The wonton soup is light and tasty. Spring rolls are crispy and not too oily. Same thing applies to shrimp in a blanket.
Great steak. Poor garden green veggies.

A typical Mexican fast food joint. A cheaper version of Chipotle but perhaps they don't use the same "fresh" ingredients that Chipotle markets to using. 

There are combos and add ons depending on your taste. From everything from burritos, tacos, quesadillas, nachos, salads, to fajitas. If you are a small eater, you may want to share your burrito with whoever you are coming with. They're huge! The best thing is that there are kids menus for the youngster at this family friendly joint. They even have a catering menu for your parties and corporate parties. For the real fans, there are even Mo Gear up for purchase.

Paradise for the gamblers. Everyone else not so much unless you like to people watch, game watch, or grab a bite. Though I don't see why you won't grab a bite outside instead. Overall, it's a casino. It is what it is.

It was the perfect weather for the North TAMPA Market. It is held behind the cultural center. You can park in the front. There are some great vendors here at this location but it seems that it is repetitive of the market at Wiregrass mall. Also, smaller and on a dirt road vs a paved road. Therefore, if you go there - you may not have come here. There are food and plant vendors and craft vendors.

This is the closest American signature furniture store by me and it's not my first time here of course. Parking is decent here since it is part of a large mall strip and you shouldn't have any problems with parking. 

We were greeted as soon as we walked in by a nice gentleman sitting at the entrance. He asked us if we were working with somebody if not he offered his assistance. We were browsing and not looking for anything specific so we proceeded to look around. A few minutes later he actually had offered us bottled water while we continue browsing. That was a nice gesture.

Overall they had a lot of interesting pieces somewhere more modern and some were more traditional. Depending on your taste, you may find something. They have a few pieces in the clearance section. They also have a section dedicated to The Magnolia Story (the Gaines couple).

I enjoyed the service at this restaurant but since I live so close, this review is mainly for their take out service.  They were very friendly and attentive.  They are a small spot with limited seating so good for small parties. They don't have too many staff there so I can see how it can cause an issues for sit in. 

So far, the items I've had I've enjoyed: Thai Spring Roll, Fresh Roll, Beef Spicy Basil, and the other folks in the family enjoy their Pad Thai. Crab Rangoon I didn't enjoy it too much because it was a bit too fried for me.

Located around a bunch of shops and other restaurants, this is some place you can go and know what to expect. 

One of the few places around that is open late. Service is friendly and similar to the other chains. So is the menu. "To go" is easy as you order and then there are "to go" parking where they bring the food and your bill out to you!

We came here late after a day on the beach and we left happy. We were searching and searching for a place to have dinner after sunset. 

Our server, cinnamon, was fantastic. She was there for 12 hours already and she was still friendly and personable. The terrible CB in NC off I95 better take note. They were terrible there. She started off by telling us what they ran out of (and not 30 min after we ordered like the NC branch). 

We had a mix of breakfast folks whose dishes were consistent to that of a CB breakfast. We also tried their new chicken bake and beef bakes which were the meats baked with carrots, corn on the cob, onion, and red potatoes wrapped in tin foil and baked to tenderness. There was a nice juice on the bottom but it wasn't drowning in sauce. 

All in all a great late night meal last night for a starving dreary group!

You can't go wrong with anything you order. The place was larger than expected and well limited outdoor seating. There is a little of everything here and a band playing Saturday night. Fun stuff.  

We had a large crowd but everyone had a good time. The boneless and bone in wings were great and had a kick. The chilli was tasty. The mango quesadilla was different but we liked it. Burgers are always a hit and salads too.

Be still my beating heart! It has been 3 months since I returned to NYC (which was also my last Korean meal) and I was craving hard for some sundubu jjigae and fried tofu and the collection of banchan just added to my excitement.

There were mainly wooden booths inside with a scattered few akward tables for the overflow crowd. The entire layout was like an oval which provided 2 pathways for foot traffic. Service was decent for a small place. 

My kimchi sundubu jjigae was like comfort food. It hit the spot right away. The DuBu BuChim was different version than I expected though. The beef fried rice and pork spring rolls were great also. There was so many more dishes I wanted to order but there was just no more room in my stomach. Until next time, Sa Ri One!

There's not too many people here as lunch is just opening.

Service is friendly and great here. The bartender mid-week today is very personable. 

I agree but expected that the prices are moderate. I wanted the wings but since I will be taking it on the flight.. it might get a little messy... I'll stick with something clean today like the Cheese Chicken and Nuts Salad. Sadly, the salad was mediocre and there wasn't anything special with it. Basically, greens with honey mustard. I'll keep in mind to order a few other items next time!

Great service, Gabriel was wonderful.

Food was tasty as well though sometimes salty. Bang bang shrimp had a kick to it but tasty as an appetizer to share. The shrimp was fresh and smothered w a mayo type sauce. The Ahi Tuna Sashimi crust was a little thicker than I wanted but the tuna was still good. 

The steak dinner was something you'd expect but also can be topped with different sauces. The fishes have different toppings and combinations as you would like. I had ordered the Longfin Tilapia with some Pan Asian sides. I'm not sure why I did that but I didn't think the Chimichurri Sauce would go well.

Sweets galore! A nicely sized bakery right by the restaurant for you to pick up some tasty treats to go or stay and chow if you'd like. 

The flan is fantastic and also you'll have to dig into their pastries. Yum. Guava and cheese. Double yum.

Such a quaint little shopping area.  I enjoy coming here every time even though it's a trek and well parking can be a pain as well. 

They have a few great restaurants and some great fountains and just a great ambiance. Cine Bistro is here too and I've come with a friend to watch some operas.  The coffee shop is great and basically this area has all my favorite stores from Potter Barn Kids to William Sonoma to Anthropologie. They also have some great events. My favorite is the holiday tree lighting event. So much fun!

I enjoy this Bed Bath and Beyond. The service is friendly and attentive.  Everything is normally easy to find or else there would be help. It's nice there are separate customer service and cashier lines.

I had forgotten about this place until I stumbled upon it in person. I'm glad I did because I probably won't forget it now. I tried to go one time during lunch time and it was way too busy and the line was too long. I finally got to come back when it was less busy after the crazy lunch hour. 

The guys were really friendly. There were so many choices and I couldn't choose but ended up with a taco - THE AUSTINITE. It was flavorful and sprinkled with meat. I had a hard time with a large avocado but I still enjoyed it. Since I was able to get a seat this time as well. They had a handful of drinks available some usual and some not so usual. I'll have to go back to try the other items on the menu.

The service was decent as far as mannerism. However, I'm sure they have a business to run too. The quality of work though I was not thrilled or impressed with. They are surely overpriced as well. 

I needed help with a band shortening which I've always been able to do myself. He charged me $12... to shorten a band. He changed a rubber piece on my husband's watch (and charged $17 + another few bucks for a battery) to help it stay waterproof. It turned out to be the complete opposite and water kept running into the watch and rusting it up making it unusable. 

We were so disappointed with this place and couldn't help but feel jipped. It's just not right!

What can you expect? They have cheap pies! $6 each during the weekdays. The crust is a little thicker than I would desire it to be but otherwise the pizzas were okay. Not bad for a mid-week crave to bring home for dinner. 

A chain pizzeria with typical small, medium, and large pies. They have your normal toppings such as Pepperoni, Ham, Mushroom, Onion, Green Pepper, Italian Sausage, Bacon, Ground Beef, Black Olives, Fresh Tomato, Pineapple, Mild Peppers. They have flavored crust! Cheese, Ranch, Cajun, Onion, and Butter!

Of course, there is specialty pizzas:
MEAT EATERS - A must for hearty appetites! Pepperoni, Italian sausage, thinly sliced ham, & seasoned ground beef. Meat Eaters
VEGGIE - A garden fresh delight with mushroom, slivered onions, green pepper, ripe black olives & sliced tomato. Veggie
HOWIES SPECIAL - A classic combination of pepperoni, thinly sliced ham, slivered onion, fresh green pepper & mushroom. Howies Special
HOWIE MAUI - A taste of the islands with generous portions of sweet pineapple, smoked bacon and thinly sliced ham. Howie Maui
PHILLY CHEESE STEAK - This classic East coast specialty starts with a hand tossed crust topped with special cheese sauce, marinated steak, green peppers, mushrooms and onions, smothered with provolone cheese. Cheesesteak
BACON CHEDDAR CHEESEBURGER - The backyard grilled flavor of hamburger & smoked bacon topped with mozzarella & aged cheddar cheese.

Chili's was right by the us airways gate and the only sit down option. They had some terminal seating and some inside the restaurant. The service was friendly and quick which was exactly what I needed.

i ordered the Quesadilla Explosion Salad and loved it! I think they sprinkled a little Old Bay over the salad too which made it so much better!

The first time I came to this store I was blown away. Make sure you come with time if you plan on browsing each aisle. There is so much to see. Some of the items aren't always well priced but they basically have everything. Aisles and aisles of everything for the home. 

There are seasonal items for every holiday. There are items such as outside patio furniture or cushions, vases, greeting cards, books and kids books and activities items, reading glasses, fake flowers, wooden boards with great sayings, different types of letters so you can decorate your home, rugs for different needs and sizes, bathroom curtains, lamps, artwork, clocks, other wall decor items, couches and table sets, glasses, bowls, casserole dishes, mugs, and more! Everything you can think of to decorate your home. 

I find, however, they have a lot of by the sea or beach items which are great for the people who live in St. Pete or by the beach but since I live inland, I won't be able to use those items.

They are by a few fast food places and restaurants in case you need to take a break! There is also a restroom located in the store just in case your trip runs too long!

Great location right by the a few great stores and also the shopping center. They have everything plus the bakery, organic section, pharmacy, and everything for your cooking needs. Service is great and you are usually offered help to your car if needed.

This Target was far off in the distance in this strip mall but it needed the space because of the size of the store! 

Service was fairly friendly and most of the time the folks were more by the cashiers area. The aisles were clean for the most part and items on sale were displayed. 

My favorite part is the $1 (or not $1 section) and of course who doesn't enjoy their Starbucks while browsing through the Target aisles.

I thought it would be a good idea to come by here for dinner the other night with the family. It was so busy and the wait was rather frustrating. Otherwise, service was friendly and decent if you are forgiving that things took longer to come (or not at all) since they're so busy (food, water, extra utensils....). They also kept running out of supplies (kids drink cups, soup to go containers)... better stock up! 

The seating were great since there were booth and table seating. I had really wanted a highchair but gave it up for a booster seat when I found out that I was going to be put back on the waiting list. 

Their strawberry lemonade was tasty and I asked them to keep it coming. Haha. I ended up with the Mahi Mahi tacos (came with 2) and the side of chips and I was content. I just wished it didn't take forever for us to have the meal.

Service was friendly and nice. However, they got my order wrong when I asked for a plain sandwich. 

The bigger issue was the ants all over the drink area. That was a little disturbing. Also their water button doesn't work And that was all I was able to drink. 

A little disappointed.

Friendly staffed and always packed whether it is at the counter or the drive-thru. So far the orders have been correct which is more I can say for some other locations. 

It is connected to the gas station so you can walk right over if you need something. The ventilation isn't that great in there but if you can get in and out quick. There are great combinations and the usual list of Dunkin Donut favorites.

LOVE it here! It's clean, bright and happy feeling, waterfalls, outdoor music, plants, trees, and did I mention clean? What more can I ask for? 

It is set up like an outlet (the outdoors concept) but it a lot more pleasant feeling. You can walk around and enjoy yourself. Tired from shopping? Take a seat on the wooden benches or the rocking chairs. 

They have high scale stores like Williams-Sonoma, teen stores like Hollister and Aeropostale, department stores such as Macys and JC Penny, and a few special boutiques. Barnes & Noble is one of the favorites.

There are many delicious looking restaurants with beautiful decors scattered around the mall. There is even a late nite "club" that I have yet to visit. They do have food shops such as Moe's Southwest Grill, Cosi, a Teriyaki shop, and a Crepe shop. 

Looking for an evening or holiday event? They got it. Just look out for the large banners when you pass by and make sure you pay attention to the details (time and date) since I show up at the wrong times/dates sometimes.

I like this location and its usually tidy and clean which is why I enjoy coming here. 

The cashiers are usually friendly especially the guy with the great animated voice. 

They have everything you would probably need at these stores. everything for different holidays and greeting cards! Kitchenware, toiletries, food!

I've always liked Ker's Winghouse and this time it was no different. They opened in place of the Buffalo Wings that was suppose to open many moons ago and it's a great place. 

Service is fantastic and attentive. The managers were great and friendly. Everyone was there for anything that you may need.  

I always order my wings mild and naked and still love it. I like how their wings are mild and I get to add the amount of hot sauce that I would like especially if I am eating with people who do not like spices. Happy hour is great but beat the crowd! 

Parking is a problem now but I hear that they will have expanded parking soon.

I don't come to this location much since it's not in my neighborhood but it's one of the ones that play some independent films that other do not.  

I came here with some girlfriends the other night and enjoyed our time here.  Loving my large tub of popcorn and soda. A girl gotta splurge some time! The theaters were decently cleaned and the bathrooms weren't terrible even though it was the end of the night already. I was glad.

I've come here for the dim sum or some of the Cantonese dishes. The service is decent. 

However, some of the dim sum dishes aren't the way I remember it from NY or even close. There's been a few instances where I was sorely disappointed with the dishes. One time the sticky rice that just seemed undercooked. I was afraid to even have it. Sadly, I had given it more than a few tries and haven't been back since.

Great corner coffee shop. Friendly staff and nice seating area. I Wasn't up for the bar seating this time but maybe next time! It's all shared seating though so you're pretty close to the people around you.

They had some shirts and coffee for sale on the side but nothing like ordering a nice cappuccino for the morning and sipping it while being engulfed in the scent of coffee.

No wifi here though!

They are located in the GROVE mall towards the back. You can hit this and TJ Maxx back to back.

This old navy is usually a stocked. The service is friendly but the lines are usually long! The clearance section is always great but there is not much items there.

This market was small and had limited items. It was ok for some dry or canned items. Otherwise, I didn't find anything impressive. 

They have your snacks such as shrimp chips, and pocky, and mochi.

They also carried a variety of dry noodles and ramen. Canned vegetables available at most Asian markets. 

There were some prepackaged bags of vegetables in the fridge but I'm not sure how often their shipments come in. 

They also carried a few different cans of Thai curry and prepackaged teas.

We love this park! Discovered it when I met a moms group here and there is so much to it. They have areas where you can plan soccer or basketball or so many other sports. 

There are roads where you can basically go for a walk and circle the entire park. There's a section where there are benches and it's covered so there is plenty of shade and restrooms! It gets REALLY windy though so be warned.  The kids playground has a variety of things to play with for the younger and older kids. The downfall is that it is not covered.  The bigger issue I have are the large ant piles (most likely fire ants) which I am deathly allergic to. What if one of the kids walk through it by accident? One of my bigger fears.....

Do not allow yourself to leave St. Louis before hitting up a restaurant and having their fried ravioli with marinara sauce. This casual restaurant reminded me of a typical American eatery with a few outdoor seating on a nice day. The inside of the restaurant was rather spacious and dull. Don't forget to try the Creole Pasta with Sausages. The portions were pretty large but it was all worth the extra inches on the waistline!

I am so happy that they came up with an outlet by the areas that I don't have to go all the way down past Brandon or to Orlando for an outlet! He gets super busy though especially during the weekends and holidays and there is plenty of parking. 

I like how there are seats everywhere along the way for people to either take a break or wait for their significant others.  There are lots of chargers and outlets everywhere and restrooms! Originally it was only a limited amount of food only in the food court but now since area has expanded tremendously there are a lot of restaurants and fast food choices surrounding it. 

There is also a cute little pirate ship play area for the little kids to play. Also reclining seats by some water fountains for more serene time here. There is even an area with seats and a fireplace.

There are many stores available here and you can still easily spend a few hours here.

The hotel is located right off the highway. Just at the front desk is friendly and usually knowledgeable. 

The lobby is decorated a lot nicer than many of the Hilton Garden instead I have been too. In December they had Decorated for the holidays and it was gorgeous! There is ice tea, coffee, tea, water with lemon and of course cookies in the lobby! There is also a little shop on the side for necessities and munchies. 

I have to say the restaurant food wasn't bad And I normally don't like hotel food. There was the shrimp cocktail which was fancied up. The short ribs are extremely pricey but there is a heap of it that they serve. There is also a hummus platter but the pita wasn't great. There was a battered shrimp salad which I believe was the Asian salad. That was okay. The chocolate cake is on the heavy side and the Apple and puff pastry was mediocre. They have a full meals and small munchies. A variety of things to order. The guy who brings up the food is very friendly. Tip him!!

The business center was always packed and also not always functioning. If you have a plane ticket to print, the front desk is always willing to help. Overall, one of the better Hilton Garden Inn's I have been too even though they are located in the middle of nowhere in Fort Washington!

I wasn't totally surprised when I went to Logan's Roadhouse. It reminded me of Texas Roadhouse. The deco was great with wooden furniture and neon lights. Each table came with a huge bucket of peanuts and peanut shells all over the floor. The staff was friendly and attentive. 

They serve a really large 2 pieces of bread that is light golden on the outside with a glaze over the top. The inside is SOOOOO SOFT... SOOO soft! I have never had such light and soft bread. They have a variety selection of appetizers, sides, desserts, burgers, salads, steaks, ribs, and combo entrees. The side of broccoli was VERY SAD and limpy. The half rack was fall-off-the-bone and the mac and cheese was comforting.

Perfect location for the upcoming hospital that is opening up next year. The service was wonderful even though they were short of staff (it happened to be dinnertime). The prices were decent but expensive if you plan on eating here daily for lunch.

We had ordered the Steak with onions with black beans on rice. The kids menu quesadilla was mediocre. Overall it is good for the area we are in with limited authentic spanish food.

I come about every 12 weeks and always come back for more! 

It's a nice little place and I enjoy their pizza but is their huge salads that get me every time. 

I love the Cobb salad and their Greek salad but heck even Their simple garden salad is great because their is so much toppings on it and their dressing are fabulous.

Bonsai Sushi was good. I wouldn't say out of this world but it was okay. It helps with the craving a little since it has been several weeks since I had sushi. 

There are some typical rolls and there were many creative rolls available for order. Soups and typical hot dishes are available. What totally threw me off is that they serve Bul Go Gi and Kalbi.... ??!!  I'm going to have to figure out how that tastes...

Such a cute neighborhood café. She usually only open from 10-5 so swing by during your breaks!

I've been ordering the latte and the iced teas aren't bad. You can't go wrong with any of the choices really. Service is usually friendly and attentive. She usually had some scones available or light sandwiches. 

Everything in the store is for sale. Mostly. There are photos and greeting cards and jewelry and even paint for your walls. There's a cute little playroom so that your kids and play and let you relax for once! The furniture in the place is awesome and my favorite is the extra long table!

Always love my pottery barn and their products and set ups. It's at a great location at the Wiregrass mall away from people traffic. You're in another world when you step in. 

Staff is friendly and available for help. 

They have classes at this location someone's. Check their website.

I was super excited when I heard about it and it sounded so great. I was able to stop by one Sunday for their "brunch" prices which was $15 per person all day since they opened at noon. I like restaurants with lighting and natural lighting would be great so the mere fact that it was so dark in there even during the day worried me. Sure if it's the even and it's date night, then a dark ambience wouldn't hurt but it was lunch time. Hopefully they would consider some lighting but maybe I'm the only one... 

We had a good number of items off the menu and majority of them were pretty good. The soy paper off the American Dream threw me off a little though. I wasn't crazy about it. Otherwise, my usual rainbow roll, spicy salmon, alaskan, and California were decent. They fill a lot of the rolls with the imitation crabmeat tho and kept the Slices of fish for the topping. The sexy Girl was interesting and had a pretty presentation. I didn't see the nigiri until I was full but I enjoyed the salmon nigiri too. I'll probably be back to try some of the others and maybe try to get seated by the window. LOL.
They had Decent sandwiches and good service. Normal prices for a lunch Cuban sandwich. They have enough seating for one or a small crowd.

The restaurant larger than I expected. Many seats to offer guest coming thought the doors. Service was adequate and friendly but it was also early with few tables. They had booths and tables. 

The olive oil that came with the bread had extra herbs to it that make the dip tastier. The Linguine Pescatore (with shrimp, scallop, and mussels) was good with a side of salad or soup that came with it (all pasta dishes come w that option).

Located in a central location not too far from Bourbon Street and all the bars. Perfect for those days you need painkillers for your hangovers or maybe the extra mouthwash to gargle Or even a T-shirt to replace the one your friend puked all over.

I'm sure there are other locations where you can pick up cheap souvenirs or coffee from Café du monde or beignet mixes But a Walgreens will beat any other souvenir shops along the tourist roads.

There's also a few Chase ATMs in the area but this one is located inside the Walgreens.

We took the slice to-go so I'm not sure about how the sit down service is but the counter service was good. The place was large and had a few full service tables. I was a little disheartened to see that I could not stay there to eat my slice before I left. However, I think that is the trend in this area (no tables).

I wasn't disappointed with their pizza! I bought a regular slice and the crust was not too thick and cheese was just melted and oozed!

I actually had higher expectations of this Ross dress for less because it is located in Carrollwood. It was a lot worse than the one in my neighborhood and I was sorely disappointed. 

They have basically the same items as many of their stores however there was less of everything! In addition, the floors were pretty dirty and there were gaps everywhere. I'm not sure if it's because they have limited merchandise but it looks pretty empty in there and it doesn't look like they were going to refill it anytime soon because this is not my first visit here.

I think the main thing that bothered me was that they need to tidy up the store a little bit and maybe wash the floors.

I love libraries and real books and coming from NY with libraries with rarely have events I was thrilled to see that the ones in the area have so many events available to adults, teens, and kids. To top if off, this location has a play area with toys that the kids can play with after a kid's reading session. 

There are always book sales so look out for those. The books in general are a little more worn than the other branch but at least they aren't ripped apart. 

The branch is roomy and has a lot of space and many different rooms (kids room, teen room, quiet room) and the parking lot is decently sized.

We visited the hot shop came after going to the Chihuly Museum and was thrilled to watch  a 45 minute entertaining demo where they made a candy dish. They showed the whole process and it was beautiful. There was a shop next door that had so many beautiful pieces in a variety of colors and sizes. I really wanted to purchase all of them but I had no place for it.

I enjoyed Liang's China Bistro but not the ultra dim lighting. I couldn't see my food but perhaps that enhanced my taste buds. To summarize the food, I'd say it fancy Asian food. Fancy because of the decor and lighting.

We had the BBQ baby spared ribs which was great. The fried pork dumplings not so much unless they gave us veggie by accident because that did not taste like pork! I should've known but the Tom Yum was rather disappointing. The entrees were large and was good. We had ordered a few things from the Orange Chicken, Sesame Chicken (which was more or less the same thing), Shrimp in Lobster Sauce, and Thai Basil Beef. 

Our server was friendly and helpful and has boxes to go around for the left overs! It ended up being a little pricey since there was a few of us but I cannot deny that it was tasty.

My sister in law recommended this place after going a few times. The decor is great with their columns and marble look it. 

You're greeted as soon as you walk in even if they are with a customer. Sometimes if you don't have an appointment you end up waiting for the next spot to open. 

Manicures are good here but I feel they're a little rushed. I enjoy the pedicures and rubs a bit more and also the massage chairs that they have. I have the "barely there" eyebrows so it was quite a challenge for them to wax my brows and they even complained about it. I didn't think they did a good job with the brow shaping either so I will stick with the nail service with them.

If this is the Starbucks at gate A, I have to say I'm sorely disappointed. Wow. Depending on who it is, the service is decent but they cannot choose slower staff to work here if they wanted to. There are plenty of green aprons around but I've never see folks move so slow. It nearly made me fall asleep watching them. 

Please pick up the pace folks. We need to catch a flight.....

The place was a warm and cozy eatery with regulars and locals. Wolves plaster the walls as it provides a certain look.some booths were available as well as tables. Service was good and servers were attentive. 

Perhaps the breakfast is better but we had arrived for lunch that day and ordered salads. They are generous on the dressing for sure. A lot more than anyone else I have seen. Though it seems as if they cut the veggies and added it to the plates. Presentation was not much of a forte.  Drinks were served in diner plastic cups.  

Overall, it's a nice cozy place if you are in a casual mood.

The space and lobby was nice. There were couches and soothing music. Water was available for customers as well. Service was friendly. My massage therapist was friendly and thorough and offered me water at the end. It was a nice deep tissue massage. However, I needed a little more strength but that is me personally because her level of pressure was decent.

This is in the middle of everything so it is easy to make a pit stop after shopping and running errands. However, there is no drive thru... which leads to long lines. Patience is a virtue! Service is okay, similar to some other mediocre Starbucks. The retail section is a little small which leads to cramped wavy lines where you have to maneuver yourself around the merchandise. 

Seats are limited. Seats by outlets are even more limited. So grab a 2 seat-er while you can! Bathroom was not fantastic....  =-\

I saw the place while I was doing my grocery shopping. I was weary but it couldn't have been as bad as some places I've had around here.

Came by after the crowd on Saturday for some dim sum. The dishes were comparable to the other dim sum place I like in town. 

The sticky rice was good. As well as the fish ball, meat ball, turnip cake, tofu skin rolls, and pork bun. The eggplant filling had more of a fish taste than shrimp taste. The pan fried chive dumpling had more meat than chives. The turnip cake didn't come w oyster sauce. Otherwise, pretty good.

This location is located alongside with a few other stores and restaurants. Unfortunately it is very popular lunch area and you don't always find parking. If you are patient, however ,you can probably grab a spot from after a few minutes. 

The line at this location was definitely long but I wouldn't compare it to New York City long. There is a wait however because usually the line is up to the door. Allow time to wait!

My favorite is always the burrito bowl. I'm not a fan of some of the tortilla skins usually so the goal is always my to go choice. My favorite is the cilantro rice for sure! I love the steak but beware since it's spicy. The pork isn't spicy at all so you have that and also the chicken. The corn is great too. 

Too bad but they give you a smear of guacamole when you order it on the side. The same thing with the salsa. You basically can dip a few chips.

I saw this place when it first opened and made sure I made a stop. Any place I can find Asian goods is a plus around these places. I was actually surprised how big this place is and how many items they had. They have a mix of everything that you would need from frozen items to fresh items to veggies to meats. They even have crackers and cookies and sweets.

I've been to this location before but not sure what has happened in the last few years. I attempted to come back today but I was so turned off on the uncleanliness of the facility.

There was no one on line but of course it is later on in the afternoon. The floors were filthy, and the tables looks like they were cleaned too quickly.  I tried to clean it again myself, a little annoying. I had to use the restroom and of course they had no soap and no toilet paper.
Simple and cozy versus the largely owned places. Friendly service and decent prices.  Clean and tidy. Manicure and pedicure and waxing capabilities.
Limited cars. Small office. Decent service.

Found this by the Delta gate and was glad! 

There was the typical bar and grill foods being served at Casa Bacardi like burgers, salads, sandwiches, and a few other finger foods. There was emphasis on Cuban food and flavor here. 

I paused and saw the Bacardi Mango Citrus Wings with a sweet sauce (mango and citrus flavor) on the side. The wings were not as crispy as I would like but it was bursting with flavor. There is a choice between 8 or 12. I should have went with the 8 but I was greedy and went with the 12. They were able to pack it for me for the next connection flight!

This location is conveniently located next to a few stores and also Sam's Club. There are a number of places to eat around there though. This is One of the smaller Tijuana Flats that I have been to.

The service was decent but I've had better at other locations. The good thing is that there was not much of a wait but of course it is a holiday weekend. The tables and floors were clean, thank goodness

The portions a little smaller than the other competitions. The taco with steak comes with two tacos for $7.99. I normally order their version of the burrito bowl which The steak one is also $7.99. 

Their small salsa is pretty small and you have to purchase it on the side similar to chipotle. I like how Moes offers you the free salsa.

I've been here for a few times and although service is decent, the prices are very high and their products are terrible. They don't have as many products and I am disappointed every time I shop here. I wish there was one of the other "hardware" stores closer to us here.

Seriously. Second time and very disappointed with the service. I Would literally travel to the other two locations even though this is right next-door to my house.

The first time I went we weren't even a party of that many and had a wait. The service was slow and the food took a while to come out. I ended up taking my salad to go since I ran out of time. We all know what happens to salad to go. 

Fast forward to the second try. We love Chilli's and must give it another try. This time we had a large party of 10 and it was already 7pm. It took over an hour to be seated and the restaurant was half empty. We sat and ordered and the food took another hour and change! The menu is the same and the food is the same as they have always prepared it. What was the big issue?  We're not sure ourselves. We called the manager and explained and frustration and the only thing he said was that "I will check on it." He must've said something to him servers because they came out a few minutes after that and just kept giving us more chips while huffing and puffing. Of course, they did not mention that invitation to giving us chips they kept charging us guacamole charges. At the end of our meal (when the food finally came) we had about five guacamole charges! Half of us had the meal but the other half had to take it to go because it was already 9:30 PM! They never offered anything not even an apology for our wait or frustration or even the complaint. 

Needless to say we will only go to the other locations from now on.
Love the location and friendliness of the staff. The place always smells Great and they always have new products and old favorites. There's a great travel section too.

It's a shame I can only come every 12 weeks because that is only when I am in town but they got me hooked since I'm not able to get poke by me. 

I always end up with the large and stuffing myself.  I love the 4 proteins on top of everything. My favs are the octopus, the spicy tuna, albacore, and scallops tho the sauce they cover it in... ehhhhh. Otherwise, love all my toppings and all the difference sauces they have to offer. Top it all off with the spicy flakes and woot woot I got a meal. 

The green tea is interesting and I always go back for more. It's not sweet like most have it, so I like it. The miso soup was okay too.

Typical pizzeria that I'm use to growing up with all the brick internal walls and brick oven. I was surprised to see how large it was inside since there were about about 10-12 tables in total. They serve the basic toppings on the pizzas and different types. There are appetizers, salads, desserts, cold subs, hot subs, pasta dishes, dinners, and even kids meals.

This location was fairly clean and service is decent. There are a lot of people during the lunch hour but turnaround is usually quick. 

I usually like to split the foot longs that they have available. Spicy Italian is always a favorite!
This location is quick and decent. However it's always busy inside. There's seating available outside too on a nice day.

I've gotta say, there were so many cycling classes all over NY when I lived there but I didn't have the opportunity to give it a try. Pura Cycling Studios opened up right by me and this time I didn't resist. If you are new to cycling, be not afraid! The owners and instructors are all friendly and you can set yourself up slowly until you are comfortable to add more resistance. 

The facilities is clean and there is a bathroom! Unfortunately, there is no shower but I'm sure your own shower is much more comfortable! They have different specials and the new yoga classes. In addition, there are contests every now and then. All the info is listed on their website and/or social media pages. 

They have different style classes at all hours of the day depending on if you are a morning or evening person or even if you are able to sneak out mid-day. I suggest to give each instructor a try until you find the style and time that you like! 

Happy Riding!

We knew there was going to be a wait being that it was Valentine's Day and I'm glad they had all the trinkets and quirky items for sale at the store. This was a good way to keep people entertained while they were waiting for seats. If you you tired yourself out from shopping, there are all the different size rocking chairs and checker sets out front where you can sit and listen for your name and party number. 

They decorated the walls with old signs and restaurant with wooden chairs and tables.

Service is friendly and consistent. 

Food especially breakfast is always good here. Eggs and sausage and bacon! The pancakes are fantastic here. Flavorful (maybe due to the butter) to a point where I don't even need the syrup and the extra butter in top lol 

Lunch and dinner here isn't bad but I'd so much rather have a breakfast!
Slow service and usually backed up. They usually get my long order right so it's not that much of a bad thing. Try to come when you have an extra new minutes before your flight.

Alas, bubble tea! I was afraid that I would be missing out on my bubble tea when I moved here from the North. I happened to be in the area and squealed like girl when I saw it. 

The drinks are definitely pricey but at a boba house, when are they not? There is wifi there which I didn't have a chance to take advantage of yet. Couches and tables are available to lounge. They also serve frozen yogurt with toppings of your choice and some cooked munchies and sushi. 

The plus side is that the Asian market is in the same shopping center and you can purchase more munchies to go!

I've heard about this place and always seen it in passing while at Wiregrass.

I finally was able to go on one of the holidays but unfortunately I was not very impressed with the food.  The service was great and they were attentive. We ordered the teriyaki beef dinner box which was decent. The beef had some flavor but I have to say everything else that came with it was mediocre. I ordered the chirashi and there was barely any fish. It was a nice bowl of rice underneath though for the price I wasn't thrilled about. 

Perhaps their hibachi is better?

That store is huge and there's many things to find here. The lighting in the story makes it that bit depressing. There's no coziness feeling to it and service isn't always great.
